paragraph: An acetic-acid mediated solvothermal-method was used to synthesize UiO-66 [42]. Brieﬂy, 0.25 mmol of ZrCl 4 was mixed with 0.25 mmol H 2 bdc before adding 1.75 mmol (0.1 mL) of acetic acid and 2.5 mL of DMF. The mixture was sonicated for 10 min to obtain a clear solution. Subsequently, the clear solution was heated at 120  C in a hydrothermal autoclave and kept at the temperature for 16 h. The resulting solid precipitates were collected by vacuum ﬁltration. Dried powders were obtained using the same puriﬁcation procedure as used for MIL-140A.

2.1.2. Synthesis UiO-66 was synthesized according to a slightly modiﬁed protocol based on previous report by Schaate (2011). In detail, ZrCl 4 (1.00 g, 4.29 mmol) and acetic acid (7.36 mL, 128.7 mmol) were dissolved in DMF (250 mL, 3.23 mol) by ultrasound for about 10 min, which was then supplemented with H 2 BDC (0.713 g, 4.29 mmol). The solution was transferred to a 500 mL Teﬂonlined autoclave and maintained at 393 K under static conditions for 24 h. The precipitates were isolated and then subject to three-time solvent exchange using fresh 30 mL DMF, in which the precipitates were soaked in DMF for 12 h each time. Afterwards, the precipitates were soaked in free ethanol (30 mL) for three-time solvent exchange similarly. Finally, the solids were ﬁrstly dried in oven at 80 °C for 12 h, and then dried under vacuum at 453 K for 12 h.UiO-67 was synthesized using a previously reported method in literature (Oien-Odegaard et al., 2016) with a slight modiﬁcation.

2.2. Preparation of the adsorbents 2.2.1. Synthesis of UiO-66 UiO-66 was synthesized according to reported method with a slight modiﬁcation [33]. In a typical synthesis, ZrCl4 (190 mg, 0.8 mmol) and BDC (133 mg, 0.8 mmol) were dissolved in DMF (82 mL) under the continuous stirring for 60 min and ultrasonic treatment for 20 min.Following that, the mixed solution was placed into a 150 mL Teﬂonlined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. The solid products were collected by centrifugation and wash three times with DMF and methanol to remove the residual reactant and exchange the DMF. The resulting UiO-66 samples were dried at 60 °C overnight.

2.2. Synthesis of diﬀerent MOFs with UiO-66 topology 2.2.1. Synthesis of UiO-66 ZrCl 4 (0.233 g, 1.0 mmol) and PTA (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol) were dissolved in DMF (50 mL), and this mixture was stirred in a ﬂask at room temperature for 30 min. The mixture was subsequently placed in a Teﬂon-lined autoclave and kept in an oven at 120 °C for 48 h. Then, solid samples were obtained via ﬁltration and adequately washed three times with DMF and ethanol. Finally, the resulting white powder was dried at 100 °C in a vacuum oven overnight.2.2.2. Synthesis of UiO-66-NH 2 The solvothermal synthesis of UiO-66-NH 2 followed the same steps as that of UiO-66, except that PTA was replaced with the equivalent molar amount of APTA.

2. Materials and methods 2.1. Materials preparation 2.1.1. Synthesis of UiO-66 All reagents were used in analytical grade obtaining from commercial suppliers (Sigma-Aldrich, Aladdin, TCI) without further puriﬁcation. The synthesis of UiO-66 through solvothermal route was conducted with a small modiﬁcation based on reported [39].Brieﬂy, the ZrCl 4 (0.17 g, 0.73 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL N,Ndimethylformamide (DMF) under sonication for 15 min before adding 1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid (H 2 bdc, 0.12 g, 0.73 mmol).The glacial acetic acid (1.25 mL), acting as a modulator, was added in the mixture with further sonication for 20 min. A homogeneous solution was transferred into a 40 mL Teﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 120 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the resultant white product was isolated by centrifugation and washed with DMF (3  10 mL), followed by soaking in methanol (MeOH) for 3 days and exchanged with fresh MeOH every day. After soaking, the solids were collected and dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 24 h before further used.

2.2.3. Synthesis of UiO-66 UiO-66 was synthesized by the well-established hydrothermal method [29]. 0.136 g ZrCl 4 was dissolved in 100 mL N,N-dimethyl formamide under stirring, and 0.068 g terephthalic acid (TPA) was added as an organic ligand. Stirring was continued until fully dissolution. The mixture was then transferred into a 200 mL Teﬂon M. Zhang, X. Wang, X. Qi et al. Journal of Catalysis 413 (2022) 31–47 32   lined autoclave and kept at 393 K for 24 h. The resulting powder was collected by centrifugation (8000 rpm, 3 min) and washed with ethanol and deionized water, each for 3 times, and then dried overnight at 333 K.

Ltd. The nitrogen (99.9 %) was supplied from Singapore Aerospace Industries Gas Co. Ltd.2.2. Catalysts preparation 2.2.1. Synthesis of UiO-66 UiO-66 was synthesized by the hydrothermal method according to the literature with some modiﬁcations [29]. Firstly, ZrCl 4 (5.825 g, 25 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc, 4.15 g, 25 mmol) were dissolved in the mixed solution containing DMF (200 mL), CH 3 COOH (42 mL) and H 2 O (2.7 mL) by ultrasound and agitation. And then the transparent solution was transferred into a autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. After the solution was cooled down to the room temperature in air, the resulted suspension was centrifugated to obtain the white solid product. The obtained white solid was washed with DMF and ethanol for several times to remove the remaining unreacted ligands. Finally, it was dried at 65 °C under vacuum overnight and the white powdery UiO-66 was obtained.

2.2.Synthesis of UiO-66 UiO-66 was synthesized according to Cavka et al.[44].Brieﬂy, ZrCl 4 (0.159 g, 0.681 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.102 g, 0.681 mmol) were mixed with 20 mL DMF in a 30 mL Teﬂonlined bomb under ultrasonication for 1 min.The Teﬂon-lined bomb was then sealed and placed in a pre-heated oven at 120 ◦ C for 24 h.After cooling to room temperature, the resulting UiO-66 was washed with DMF for three times and collected by centrifugation at 8000 rpm for 5 min.The obtained white UiO-66 was then immersed in ethanol overnight to replace DMF molecules from the cavities of UiO-66.Finally, the UiO-66 was obtained by drying at 200 ◦ C in air.2.3.Fabrication of the UiO-66-coated SPME ﬁbers The 5 ␮L GC microsyringe and stainless steel wires were obtained from Shanghai Gaoge Industrial and Trade Co.Ltd.(Shanghai, China).Stainless steel wires with a length of 20 cm were used to fabricate the UiO-66-coated SPME ﬁbers.Typically, one end of the wire (3.0 cm in length) was etched by diluted aqua regia (aqua regia: water = 1:5, v/v) for 40 min to generate a small stainless steel ﬁber with an approximate diameter of 0.15 mm.

2.3.Synthesis and activation of UiO-66 UiO-66 was synthesized according to the reported procedure [40]: 0.932 g of ZrCl 4 , 1.32 g of terephthalic acid, and 0.665 mL of concentrated hydrochloric acid were mixed with 24 mL of DMF in a Teﬂon-lined bomb, followed by ultrasonic treatment for 5 min.The bomb was then sealed, placed in an oven, and heated at 120 ◦ C for 16 h.After cooling down to room temperature, the mixture was centrifuged and the white solid precipitate was collected.The resulting solid product was washed three times sequentially with DMF and acetone, and then dried at 60 ◦ C under reduced pressure for 10 h.2.4.Preparation of UiO-66 columns for HPLC For NP-HPLC experiments, 1.30 g of UiO-66 was dispersed in 50 mL of hexane under ultrasonication for 5 min.The resultant suspension was then slurried into a stainless steel column (5 cm long, 4.6 mm i.d.) and subjected to 5000 psi of pressure for 20 min.The stationary phase was kept in place with stainless steel frits with a pore size of 2 ␮m.The packed column was conditioned with nhexane at a ﬂow rate of 1.0 mL min −1 for 1 h.

After that, the mixture was centrifuged for 10 min at 4000 rpm, and the supernatant was collected and stored at 4 ◦ C prior to analysis.2.4.Preparation of UiO-66 particles UiO-66 was synthesized according to literature [34].Brieﬂy, terephthalic acid (0.327 g) and ZrCl 4 (0.512 g) were mixed with DMF (25 mL) in a Teﬂon-lined bomb.The Teﬂon-lined bomb was then sealed and placed in an oven at 120 ◦ C for 24 h.The ﬁnal product was collected by centrifuging and washed successively with DMF and methanol several times.

T. Hamieh,  Ali-Ahmad, A. Jrad et al.  Journal of Chromatography A 1666 (2022) 462849  Fig. 1.  Crystal structure of UiO-66 and its defected form (a), PXRD patterns of the synthesized UiO-66 and the simulated UiO-66 (b) and SEM images of UiO-66 synthesized  in this study (c).  thalic  acid  (C  6  H  4  (CO  2  H)  2  ,  99%),  formic  acid  (CH  2  O  2  ,  99%)  and  acetic acid (C  2  H  4  O  2  , 99%) were obtained from Acros Organics. The  n-alkanes  (pentane,  hexane,  heptane,  and  octane),  and  the  polar  solvents  (N,  N-dimethylformamide,  DMF,  dichloromethane,  DCM,  chloroform, benzene, toluene, ether, acetonitrile and tetrahydrofu-  ran,  THF) at  highly  pure grade  (99%) were  purchased from  Fisher  Scientiﬁc.  2.2.  General synthesis procedure of the UiO-66-based MOFs  With  some  modiﬁcations,  UiO-66  was  synthesized  under  con-  ditions  similar  to  those  reported  in  the  literature  [ 39 , 40 ].  In  this  study, the metal source used was ZrCl  4  and the organic linker was  terephthalic  acid.  Brieﬂy,  in  a  500  ml  autoclavable  reagent  bot-  tle,  795 mg  of  ZrCl  4  (3.4  mmol) and  566 mg  of  terephthalic  acid  (3.4  mmol)  were  dissolved  with  250  ml  of  DMF  by  sonication  at  room temperature after the addition of 15 ml of acetic acid to the  mixture.  The  obtained  mixture  was  placed  in  a  preheated  oven  at  120  °C  for  21  h.  After  21  h,  the  bottle  was  removed  from  the  oven  and  was  left  to  cool  to  room  temperature.  The  content  of  the  bottle  was  then  transferred  to  a  falcon  tube  and  the  white  precipitate obtained was collected by centrifugation. The obtained  MOF was washed with two solvents: ﬁrst, four times with approx-  imately 60 ml DMF, and then four times with approximately 60 ml  DCM.  For  each  solvent,  during  the  ﬁrst  three  washes,  the  MOF  were allowed to settle in each wash for 3 h, but in the last wash,  the  MOFs were  soaked  in the  fresh  solvent  overnight.  Then, UiO-  66  was  dried  in  a  vacuum  oven  at  150  °C  overnight  for  thermal  activation.  2.3.  Structural characterization of UiO-66-based MOFs  The  synthesized  UiO-66  was  fully  characterized  using  powder  X- ray diffraction (PXRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), N  2  sorption measurements and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). For  the  PXRD  analysis,  the  patterns  were  recorded  with  an  advanced  Bruker D8 X-ray diffractometer (Bruker AXS GmbH, Karlsruhe, Ger-  many,  operating  at 40  kV  and  current 40  mA,  range  2 θ:  5  –50 °,  increment:  0.01 °)  using  Cu  K α radiation  ( λ =  1.5418  ˙ A).

2.2. Synthesis of pristine and composite MOFs A pristine HKUST-1 was prepared with modiﬁcation from a reported method [46]. In a typical synthesis, 1.087 g of Cu(NO 3 ) 2 3H 2 O was dissolved in 15 mL absolute ethanol while 0.525 g of BTC was dissolved in another 15 mL absolute ethanol.Then, both solutions were transferred into a Teﬂon autoclave and heated in an oven at 125 °C for 24 h. The resultant MOF was ﬁltered under vacuum and dried at 155 °C overnight. The sample was labelled as C.A pristine Zr-UiO-66 was synthesized by a reported procedure with slight modiﬁcation [47]. In a typical synthesis, 1.087 g ZrCl 4 and 0.525 g benzene dicarboxylic acid (BDC) were separately dissolved in a solvent (DMF) of 15 mL. Both solutions were stirred for 15 min, mixed together and then stirred for 20 min. Finally, the solution was transferred to an autoclave and heated in an oven at 125 °C for 24 h. The sample was designated as Z.

2.2. Preparation of microporous UiO-66 UiO-66 was prepared in accordance with the literature [14] by dissolving H 2 BDC (1.45 g) in DMF (24.00 mL) and HCl (0.67 mL) in a 100 mL Teﬂon liner at room temperature, and then ZrCl 4 (0.93 g) was added into the mixture quickly. After stirring for 10 mins, the vessel was sealed and placed in an oven, and increased the temperature up to 220 °C at a heating rate of 1 °C/min, then maintain the temperature at 220 °C for 16 h. After cooling down to room temperature naturally, the solid was isolated by ﬁltration, washed with DMF three times to clean the unreacted reactants, and then washed with acetone three times to replace the trapped DMF subsequently. Then the product was dried at 60 °C for 2 h and then dried under vacuum at 150 °C for 12 h to obtain UiO-66 powder.

2.2. Preparation of UiO-66 UiO-66 was synthesized according to the method reported previously [38]. Brieﬂy, 0.2332 g of ZrCl 4 and 0.1661 g of 1,4benzenedicarboxylic acid were dissolved in 50 mL DMF at room temperature, and then the solution was transferred to a 100 mL Teﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated in an oven at 120 °C for 24 h under autogenous pressure. After being cooled naturally, the obtained material was puriﬁed with anhydrous ethanol four times to guarantee that the DMF molecules were eliminated, and then the off-white UIO-66 product was dried at 60 °C for 12 h.

2.2. Zr-MOFs (UiO-66 and UiO-66-NH 2 ) UiO-66 and UiO-66-NH 2 were synthesized based on literature with a slight modiﬁcation [26]. In a typical synthesis of UiO-66, ZrCl 4 (190.3 mg, 0.8 mmol) and 1,4-benzendicarboxylic acid (133 mg, 0.8 mmol) were dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (81.7 mL), and then 4.6 g of acetic acid (80 mmol) were added into the solution with ultrasonic treatment for 20 min and continuous stirring for 2 h. After that, the mixed solution was placed into a 150 mL Teﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. The solid products were collected by centrifugation and washed three times with DMF and methanol to remove the residual reactant and exchange the DMF. UiO-66-NH 2 was synthesized by the same method with 147 mg of 2-NH 2 -terephthalic acid instead of 133 mg of 1,4-benzendicarboxylic acid.

2.1.1. Preparation of UiO-66 Referring to the synthetic methods reported in the previous literature. The speciﬁc synthesis process of pure UiO-66 is as follows: Typically, ﬁrst of all, we pour 60 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and 20 mL of acetic acid into an 100 mL beaker [36]. Subsequently, 3.68 mmol ZrCl 4 (598.6 mg), 2.56 mmol 1,4benzendicarboxylic acid (BDC) (425.6 mg) are dissolved in the above mixed solution and sonicated for 30 min in the ultrasonic cleaner to obtain uniform solution. Finally, waiting for the end of the ultrasound, the above solution is transferred to the 100 mL polytetraﬂuoroethylene autoclave. Then, place it in an oven to heat to 120 °C for 24 h [37]. After the reaction is ﬁnished and the autoclave is cooled to room temperature, the solution is centrifuged, washed, dried and collected.

2.2. Synthesis of MOFs UiO-66 was synthesized according to previous method reported by Katz [40]. In brief, 0.54 mmol of ZrCl 4 and 0.75 mmol of H 2 BDC were ultrasonically dissolved in 15 mL of DMF with 1 mL of HCl in a 40 mL Pyrex vial and heated at 80 °C for 24 h. The resulting solid was ﬁltered, washed with DMF followed by acetone, and then activated at 120 °C under vacuum for 24 h. The resultant UiO-66 (Fig. S1a) has the molecular formula Zr 6 ( l 3 -O) 4 ( l 3 -OH) 4 (BDC) 6 .

2.2. Preparation of UiO-66 UiO-66 was synthesized by a solvothermal method according to the previous report [40] using the following procedure: 0.125 g of ZrCl 4 was dissolved in 5 mL of N,Ndimethylformamide (DMF) and 1 mL of HCl (37%), while 0.123 g of terephthalic acid (BDC) were dissolved in 10 mL of DMF (Scheme 2). The two solutions were mixed in a 25 mL Teﬂon lined autoclave and heated at 80  C for 16 h.

2.1.3. Synthesis of UiO-66 and UiO-66/GO UiO-66 synthesis was performed by ﬁrst dissolving equimolar amounts of ZrCl 4 (3.5 mmol, 0.82 g) and H 2 BDC (3.5 mmol, 0.58 g) in 40 ml DMF under stirring and sonication. Reaction took place at 120 °C for 24 h [45,51]. The resulting product was centrifuged and washed with DMF and methanol several times. The ﬁnal UiO-66 crystals were vacuum-dried at 105 °C overnight. For the synthesis of UiO-66/GO, 0.82 g of ZrCl 4 and 0.58 g of H 2 BDC with 0.10 g of GO were used yielding a ﬁnal product with 10% GO and 90% MOF. The precursors of UiO-66 were dissolved in 40 ml DMF under stirring and sonication, while dry GO was dispersed in 20 ml DMF under stirring and sonication. The two solutions were mixed together under stirring and sonication to obtain well-dispersed mixture. The reaction took place at 120 °C for 24 h. The ﬁnal UiO-66/GO product was obtained by following similar washing and drying steps to those used for UiO-66.2.1.4. Synthesis of UiO-66-NH 2 and UiO-66-NH 2 /GO UiO-66-NH 2 was synthesized analogously to UiO-66 by increasing the amount of ZrCl 4 to 3.68 mmol and replacing H 2 BDC ligand of UiOJ. Pokhrel et al.

2.3. Synthesis of UiO-66 0.233 g (1 mmol) ZrCl 4 and 0.166 g (1 mmol) H 2 BDC were dissolved in 30 mL DMF with sonication for 15 min. Then 4 mL acetic acid was added with ultrasonic treatment for another 15 min. Finally, the mixture was transferred into a 100 mL Teﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 120  C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the precipitates were washed with DMF and CH 2 Cl 2 and dried at room temperature over night.

2.2.2. UiO-66 and UiO-66/GO UiO-66 was prepared according to the reported solvothermal method [15,24]. Typically, 348 mg of ZrCl 4 and 249 mg of terephthalic acid (H 2 BDC) were ﬁrst added into 60 ml DMF (N,N-Dimethylformamide), and then sonicated for 0.5 h to completely dissolve the solid. The resulting solution was poured into a 100 ml Telfon-lined stainless steel autoclave, and then heated at 120  C for 24 h. After being cooled, the gained product was puriﬁed with DMF and methanol several times and ﬁnally dried at 120  C under vacuum for 24 h. UiO-66/GO was prepared via growing UiO-66 onto GO nanosheets. The preparation method is similar to that of UiO-66 except for adding GO in the precursor before hydrothermal treatment.

2.2. Synthesis 2.2.1. Synthesis of UiO-66-NDC 0.466 g (2 mmol) ZrCl 4 and 8 mL acetic acid were dissolved in 30 mL DMF with stir for 15 min, 0.432 g (2 mmol) 1,4-NDC was dissolved in 30 mL DMF with stir for 15 min. After the complete dissolution of the reagents, the DMF solution of 1,4-NDC was slowly dropped into the DMF solution of ZrCl 4 by stirring treatment to obtain a clear solution. Then, the mixture was placed in a 100 mL Teﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 120  C for 24 h. After cooled to room temperature, the precipitate was separated from the liquid by centrifugation, and washed several times with DMF and CH 2 Cl 2 . Finally, the product was dried overnight at room temperature.2.2.2. Synthesis of UiO-66 According to the above method, the only difference is to replace the ligand 1,4-NDC with 0.332 g (2 mmol) of H 2 BDC.

UiO-66 was obtained following the previous reported method [46]in a solvothermal method: Zirconium tetrachloride (0.233 g, 1.0 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol) were dissolved in N, N-dimethylformamide (42 mL) and acetic acid (3.6 mL), the obtained mixture was then transferred to a 50 mL Teﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave.
The autoclave was sealed and heated in an oven at 120  C for 12 h. The white powder was centrifuged after cooling to room temperature, and washed with ethanol for three times. The white powder was ﬁnally dried at 80  C for 12 h to obtain UiO-66.

Y. Zhou et al. Journal of Solid State Chemistry 300 (2021) 122231 2   2.2.2. Synthesis of UIO-66 n (ZrCl 4 ): n (C 8 H 6 O 4 ) ¼ 1:1, 2.33 g zirconium tetrachloride, 1.66 g terephthalic acid dissolved in 50 ml DMF, stirred until dissolved and putted it into the polytetraﬂuoroethylene reactor. After reacting at 120  C for 24 h, the product was washed by DMF and methanol solution then collected by centrifugation. Finally, the product was dried in a vacuum drying oven at 120  C for 8 h.

2.2. Synthesis of UIO-66 0.615 mmol terephthalic acid as the organic ligand was solved in 25 ml DMF. Meanwhile, 0.615 mmol of zirconium chloride was solved in 25 ml of DMF. Then, the two solutions were mixed evenly, and 6 ml acetic acid was added. After ultrasonic treatment, the mixed solution was solvothermally treated at 120 o C for 4 h. After several times of ethanol cleaning and centrifugation, the obtained material was soaked in methanol for three days, and the methanol solution was updated every day.

Microchemical Journal 160 (2021) 105624 3  2.2. Chemicals and preparation of MOFs  All  reagent  grade  chemicals  for  synthesis  of  MOFs were  commercially  available  products  and  used  without  further  purication.  Zinc  nitrate hexahydrate (Zn[NO 3 ] 2 ⋅6H 2 O, 98%), zirconyl chloride octahydrate (ZrOCl 2 ⋅8H 2 O, ≥ 98%), trimethylamine (TEA, 99%), and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (terephthalic acid, BDC, 98%) were purchased from  Sigma  Aldrich,  USA.  Dimethylformamide  (DMF,  99.0%)  and  ethanol  (99.5%) were obtained from Samchun Chemicals, Seoul, South Korea.  Hydrochloric  acid  (HCl,  35.0–37.0%)  was  purchased  from  Junsei  Chemical Co. Ltd., Seoul, South Korea. Chloroform was purchased from  Daejung Chemicals & Metals, South Korea.  The  UiO-66  and  MOF-5  sorbents  for  TD-based  quantitation  of  FA  were prepared in the laboratory following literature procedures [17,40].  In the case of MOF-5, metal and linker solutions were prepared by dissolving Zn(NO 3 ) 2 ⋅6H 2 O (1.4 g, 4.71 mmol) and BDC (0.3 g, 1.81 mmol)  in separate 25 mL DMF solutions. As the reagent was added, the DMF  was stirred constantly at 1,000 rpm using a magnetic bar on a digital  hotplate stirrer (Daihan Scientic, South Korea).  After both solutions  achieved  complete  dissolution  under  stirring,  they  were  mixed  with  prolonged stirring (10 min). Then, 2 mL of TEA was added drop-wise to  the mixed solution as a catalyst to reduce the reaction time of MOF-5  synthesis to<120 min. The nal solution was covered with aluminum  foil for 2 h at room temperature. The precipitate was retrieved using a  glass microber lter (47 mm diameter, Whatman, UK) with a mini-  diaphragm vacuum  pump  (N86KT.18,  KNF,  UK)  at  a  pressure  difference of 0.01 bar and ltering time of 5 min. The ltrated MOF-5 was  washed twice with DMF to remove excess BDC and impurities. Then, the  DMF was exchanged with 40 mL of chloroform and immersed for 12 h  before it was exchanged with fresh chloroform. After 48 h, the chloroform was ltered, and the solid product was dried for 8 h at 90 ℃ in a  convection oven (CO-150, Hanyang Scientic Equipment Co., Ltd, South  Korea).  In the case of UiO-66, metal solution was prepared by dissolving 125  mg of ZrOCl 2 ⋅8H 2 O (0.38 mmol) in 5 mL of DMF with 3 mL of 37% HCl.  Concurrently, 123 mg of BDC (0.74 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of  DMF, and both solutions were ultra-sonicated for approximately 20 min  (Mujigae  SD-D300H,  Sungdong  Ultrasonics  Co.,  Ltd.,  Seoul,  South  Korea).  Metal  and  linker  solutions  were  mixed  together  and  ultra-  sonicated for an additional 30 min. The resulting solution was heated  for 12 h at 80 ℃. After cooling, the obtained crystals were ltered and  washed  twice  with  30  mL  of  DMF  and  ethanol.  These  crystals  were  soaked in 10 mL of ethanol for 9 days, replenishing at 3-day intervals.  The resulting product was dried at 90  ◦ C for 12 h.  2.3. Characterization of synthesized MOFs  The basic properties of the synthesized MOFs (MOF-5 and UiO-66)  were  assessed  as  crystal  structure,  thermal  stability,  surface  morphology, and chemical functionalities. The powder X-ray diffraction  (PXRD) patterns were obtained by a high-resolution (HR)-XRD diffractometer  (Rigaku  Corporation,  Tokyo,  Japan).  The  HR-PXRD  diffractometer was utilized with a 2θ range of 5, step size of 0.02˚, and a scan  speed of 4˚min − 1 . Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out to  evaluate the thermal stability of MOFs using SDT Q600, Auto-DSCQ20  system (Eden Prairie, Minnesota, USA). During TGA analysis, the material  samples  were  placed  on  alumina  pans  and  heated  from  25  to  800  ◦ C at a rate of 10  ◦ C min − 1  under 100 mL atm min − 1  of nitrogen  ow. The surface morphologies of MOFs were investigated using a eld  emission  scanning  electron  microscope  (FE-SEM,  Hillsboro,  Oregon,  USA).  Fourier  transform infrared  (FTIR)  spectroscopy  was  conducted  using a Perkin Elmer L1600400-IR spectrometer (Akron, Ohio, USA) in  attenuated reectance method at a range of 400–4000 cm − 1  to determine  MOF  chemical  functionalities.  Finally,  the  Brunauer-Emmett-  Teller  (BET)-based  surface  properties  of  MOFs  were  obtained  by  analyzing  the  nitrogen  adsorption  isotherms  at  77  K  using  a  Micromeritics ASAP  2010 (Norcross,  Georgia,  USA) surface  analyzer.  The sorbents were heated at 150  ◦ C for 12 h under vacuum condition to  remove moisture.  2.4. Instrumental setup of an AS/TD-GC/MS system for quantitation of  gaseous FA  For the measurement of gaseous FA by the AS/TD-GC/MS system, a  sample  of  the  FA  G-WS  at  a  owrate  of  50  mL  min − 1  was  pre-  concentrated in the cold trap installed in the AS/TD (Unity-xr, Markes  International,  UK)  (Fig.  1).  For this  study,  in-lab  synthesized  UiO-66  MOFs were used as cold-trap sorbents with Tenax®  TA. Note that the  former sorbent was used to efciently capture FA, while the latter was  used to extend the range of target compounds (>5 carbon atoms: e.g.,  benzene, toluene, and  xylene). As such, this  dual cold trap  system  is  highly effective to increase cold trap applicability, especially the number of targets to cover. Likewise, to test the reliability of this UiO-66  relative to  other  MOFs,  in-lab  synthesized MOF-5  sorbents  were  also  used as reference cold-trap sorbents with Tenax® TA in the identical AS/  TD-GC/MS system [17]. For this reason, each dual-bed cold trap was  prepared by placing MOF (front) and Tenax® TA (back) in line with the  sampling  ow  direction  (i.e.,  UiO-66  + Tenax®  TA  and  MOF-5  + Tenax®  TA, 1:1 by volume) in a quartz tube (length: 100 mm, outer  diameter:  3.2  mm,  and  inner  diameter:  2  mm,  Markes  International,  UK). After sampling, the cold trap was heated, and desorbed FA was  injected  into  the  GC  capillary  column  for  separation  (DB-WAX,  lm  thickness: 0.25  μ m, diameter: 0.25 mm, length: 60 m, Agilent, USA) and  quantied by GC/MS (Shimadzu GCMS-QP 2020 Ultra, Kyoto, Japan).  The  GC/MS  analysis  runtime  was  18  min  with  the  GC  temperature  programming summarized in Table S2. The MS system was operated in  electron impact (EI) ionization mode at 70 eV, and FA was detected in  selected ion monitoring mode using the major ions at m/z 29 (fragment  ion) and 30 (molecular ion) (Fig. S1).  2.5. Experimental procedures  To evaluate the AS/TD-GC/MS analytical characteristics using a UiO-  66 + Tenax® TA cold trap, we designed four types of experiments (E1 to  E4) as outlined in Table 1. At E1 (bench testing), the FA adsorption/  breakthrough/recovery  performance  of  UiO-66  and  MOF-5  (as  reference) was evaluated by an established DNPH/HPLC/UV method (i.e.,  prior to TD testing of the MOFs). To optimize the UiO-66 + Tenax® TA  cold trap in the AS/TD-GC/MS system, FA recovery was determined at a  number of trap-low (absorption) and  trap-high  (desorption)  temperature settings of the TD (E2). In E3, QA using the UiO-66 + Tenax® TA  cold trap was applied to assess the reliability of the developed analytical  approach. Before the UiO-66 + Tenax®  TA’s QA experiment was conducted, QA experiment on MOF-5 + Tenax® TA was performed as rst  described  in  previous  studies  of  MOF-5  as  part  of  E3  [17,18].  A  comparative analysis of cold-trap performance indicated the superiority  of UiO-66 + Tenax® TA with extension of breakthrough to 800 mL at  1250 ppb FA (1143 ng). However, MOF-5 + Tenax®  TA exhibited an  immediate breakthrough of 12.7% after loading 250 mL of 1250 ppb FA  (357  ng).  Finally,  the  FA  concentration  in  indoor  air  samples  was  analyzed by the developed UiO-66 + Tenax® TA–based AS/TD-GC/MS  system (E4). The concentration of FA analyzed by UiO-66 + Tenax®  TA–based  AS/TD-GC/MS  was  compared  with  that  obtained  by  the  reference method (DNPH/HPLC/UV).  3. Results and discussion  3.1. MOF characterization  The  crystal  structure,  thermal  stability,  surface  morphology,  and  chemical  functionalities  of  the  synthesized  MOF-5  and  UiO-66  were  determined by PXRD, TGA, SEM, and FTIR, respectively. As shown in  M.-J. Yoo et al.

2.3. Synthesis of MC The MC was synthesized by conventional hard template method [36]. In brief, 5.0 g of commercial hydrophilic CaCO 3 nanoparticles (ca.40 nm) was dissolved in aqueous solution containing 5.0 g of sucrose and stirred at room temperature to obtained homogeneous suspension, and the suspension was dried with magnetic stirring at 80 °C. The mixture was carbonized at 800 °C in nitrogen (99.999%) for 2 h in tube oven. The hard template was then etched away by overnight soaking in solution of dilute HCl to leave behind mesoporous carbon.2.4. Preparation of UiO-66 and UiO-66/MC composites The UiO-66 was prepared as reported previously [41]. Brieﬂy, 0.357 g of ZrCl 4 and 0.254 g of BDC were dissolved in 21 mL of DMF and 8.6 mL of acetic acid under ultrasonication to form a welldissolved mixture suspension. Subsequently, the mixture was sealed in an autoclave and placed in a preheated oven at 120 °C for 24 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature yielding white crystals. The product was collected by centrifugation and washed with aceton three times. After that, the obtained crystal was stirred in DMF for 12 h and in methanol for 24 h at room temperature to remove unreacted linker.

2.3. Synthesis of MOFs MIL-101(Cr) and MIL-100(Fe) used here were previously synthesized and characterized in our laboratory [25].MIL-53(Al) was synthesized by the hydrothermal method of Loiseau et al. [19] with a slight modiﬁcation. Typically, Al(NO 3 ) 3 ·9H 2 O, H 2 BDC, and ultrapure water were mixed at a molar ratio of 2:1:160 in a 50 mL Teﬂon-lined bomb, which was then sealed and placed in an oven at 210 °C for 3 days. The obtained white powder was then washed with DMF, ethanol, and ultrapure water in sequence, and this procedure was repeated at least three times. The residue was heated in air at 300 °C for 2 h to remove unreacted H 2 BDC before further experiments.UiO-66(Zr) was synthesized based on a previous method [29]. ZrCl 4 (0.318 g, 1.362 mmol) and H 2 BDC (0.204 g, 1.362 mmol) were mixed with 40 mL DMF. After vortexed for 10 min, the mixture was then placed into a Teﬂon-lined steel autoclave and reacted at 120 °C for 24 h.

2.3. Preparation of UiO-66 The synthesis of UiO-66 was performed according to previously reported recipes [36]. Particularly, the microwave method was employed in this article. Clearly, zirconium tetrachloride (ZrCl 4 ) (0.54 mmol) and H 2 BDC (0.75 mmol) were ultrasonically dissolved in 5 mL and 10 mL DMF, respectively. Then hydrochloric acid (HCl) (1 mL) was added to the DMF solution of ZrCl 4 . The resulting solution was sonicated to form a homogeneous and then heated in an MCR-3 microwave reactor at atmospheric pressure with the setting time and temperature were 2 h and 100 °C. The resulting product was cooled down to room temperature and then centrifugally separated and washed three times using DMF and ethanol, respectively. Deﬁnitively, the ﬁnal product was dried by vacuum at 80 °C to produce a white powder.2.4. Preparation of SRB@UiO-66 SRB@UiO-66 was synthesized by utilizing two diﬀerent methods (method A and B), where method B has more stability compared with method A.

2.2. Sample preparation 2.2.1. Synthesis of UiO-66 octahedrons UiO-66 Octahedrons were synthesized by a solvothermal method. 0.2 g ZrCl 4 , and 0.14 g terephthalic acid (H 2 BDC) were dissolved in 40 mL N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) with a continuous stirring for 1 h and then added 8 mL of acetic acid. After that the solution was transferred to a Teﬂon-lined stainless steel reactor and maintained at 120  C for 24 h. The products were washed with DMF and methanol for several times respectively. Finally, the products were dried in oven at 80  C overnight.

2.2. Synthesis of pure MOF nanoparticles UiO-66 was prepared based on the reported procedure in our previous works (Molavi et al., 2018b, 2018d; Aghajanzadeh et al., 2018). Measured amount of terephthalic acid (0.38 g) and ZrCl 4 (0.53 g) were dissolved into 30 mL DMF and stirred at 25  C for 1 h to obtain a homogeneous solution. Then the solution was kept in a Teﬂon autoclave at 120  C for one day. The as-synthesized UiO-66 nanoparticles were collected by centrifuge, washed several times with DMF and chloroform and solvent-exchanged by stirring in chloroform for 5 days. Finally, the synthesized nanoparticles were heated in vacuum oven at 100  C overnight. The yield of the synthesized UiO-66 was about 54% based on the amount of the precursors used in synthesis.2.3. Preparation of thermally oxidized nanodiamond (OND) OND was prepared based on the method reported elsewhere (Molavi et al., 2018c; Zamani et al., 2018). Brieﬂy, 100 mg of asreceived ND was put into a crucible and transferred to a preheated furnace at 425  C for 4.5 h. After oxidation, OND particles were placed into a desiccator to inhibit adsorption of humidity. The weight of prepared OND is about 80 mg and the weight lost is about 20% which might be due to formation of CO 2 because of destruction and decreasing the number of graphitic layers.

L 1 ) was mixed to the methanol solvent and stored at 18  C.2.2. UiO-66 nanoparticle synthesis UiO-66 nanoparticles were synthesized by a solvothermal reaction as previously reported (Ma et al., 2017b). Brieﬂy, 1 14 mg of BDC and 160 mg of ZrCl 4 were ﬁrst dissolved in acetic acid and the DMF mixed solvent (20 mL, the proportion was 9:1) followed by sonication for 0.5 h. The solution was moved to an autoclave of Teﬂon-lined stainless steel and warmed to 120  C for 40 h. The product was subjected to solvent exchange in methanol at room temperature, and puriﬁed by centrifuging and ﬂushing with the DMF solvent. After dried overnight, the UiO-66 nanoparticles was obtained.2.3. Composite membrane synthesis The UiO-66/polyamide TFN membrane was fabricated by the electrospinning method. Brieﬂy, 26 wt% PSF and a certain concentration of UiO-66 nanoparticles (0, 0.1, 0.25, or 0.5 wt%) were dissolved into the DMF and NMP solvent (volume ratio of 7:3) by stirring overnight to obtain the spinning solution. Under the speciﬁc parameters of the electrospinning voltage of 25 kV, a syringeT. Mu, Y. Zhang, W. Shi et al. Chemosphere 269 (2021) 128686 2   pump propulsion speed of 1 mL h 1 , a 4 mL solution volume, and PET non-woven fabric collector, the PSF membrane was prepared by electrospinning. Following drying, the membrane was subjected to a simple hot-pressing process to obtain a stable substrate membrane. The pristine PSF membrane refers to the membrane without UiO-66 particles.

paragraph: 2.2. Synthesis of UiO-66 and ZIF-8 UiO-66 and ZIF-8 NPs were synthesized by following speciﬁed procedure. For UiO-66, 125 mg of ZrCl 4 was dissolved in 15 mL of DMF. A desired amount of acetic acid as a modulator and water were added to ZrCl 4 solution and stirred vigorously. Concurrently,100 mg of terephthalic acid was dissolved in 15 mL of DMF. After that, the precursors were mixed and sonicated for 10 min before being heated in a microwave oven. The reaction was performed at 120  C for 10 min reaction time with constant irradiation power at 350 W.

UiO-66(Zr), 6.86 mmol of ZrOCl 2 ·8H 2 O, 6.86 mmol of terephthalic acid and 1157.54 mmol of acetic acid were dissolved in 100 mL of DMF, then stirred with a magnetic stirrer for 30 min. The reaction mixturewasthenheatedinreﬂux at 140 °C for 24 h. The obtained precipitate was isolated by centrifugation. After that, the powder was washed with fresh methanol for 12 h 3 times. Finally, the powder was dried at 60 °C for 12 h (Rahmawati et al., 2014).

2. Material and methods The two step synthesis of UiO-66 was performed by the following procedures. Step one: 233 mg ZrCl 4 (Alfa Aesar, 98%) was dissolved in 45 mL DMF (Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., Ltd., 99.5%) under stirring and the solution was heated to about 120 °C for 2 h. After that, different amounts of acetic acid (0, 1, 2 and 5 mL, about 0, 17.5, 35.0 and 87.4 equivalents with respect to Zr 4+ , respectively) (Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., Ltd., 99.5%) were separately added and stirred for additional 30 min at 120 °C. Step two: 166 mg H 2 BDC (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., 99.0%) was added and the resulting mixture was introduced in a 100 mL Teﬂon liner and further placed in a metallic bomb. The system was placed in a preheated oven for a solvothermal process at 120 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the precipitates were washed with DMF and puriﬁed by Soxhlet extraction in methanol for two days. Finally, the products were dried over night at room temperature. The derived samples were labeled as UiO-660, UiO-66-1, UiO-66-2 and UiO-66-4, respectively, according to the amounts of acetic acid modulator added. 2.3. Synthesis of UiO-66 The UiO-66 was synthesized as reported by Wei et al. (2018) with slight modiﬁcation [32]. Brieﬂy, ZrCl 4 (0.2330 g, 1.0 mmol) and 1,4BDC (0.1661 g, 1.0 mmol) were dissolved in 40 mL of DMF under vigorous stirring, followed by sonication, and the mixture was sealed into a 100 mL Teﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave, heated to 120 °C, maintained for 24 h, and then the autoclave was left as was, to reach RT naturally. The obtained white crystals were centrifuged at 4000 rpm for 20 min, and rinsed thoroughly with ethanol. Finally, the synthesized UiO-66 was dried at 80 °C for 12 h.

2.3. Preparation of materials 2.3.1. Synthesis of UiO-66 The preparation of UiO-66 was conducted based on our previous work [53]. Initially, 0.095 g of ZrCl 4 and the 0.067 g of H 2 BDC (organic ligand solution) were dissolved in 15 mL of DMF in two separate beakers with ultrasonic vibration for 15 min. Then, the zirconium-containing solution was poured into the ligand solution, subsequently, 6 mL of acetic acid was added. Next, the mixture was stirred for 60 min. After that, the mixed solution was moved into a Teﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave and was heated for 24 h at 120 °C in the oven. After cooling down, the mixture was centrifuged to obtain a white powder. Finally, the UiO-66 powder was washed with fresh DMF and methanol several times and was dried for 12 h at 70 °C.2.3.2. Synthesis of UiO-66-NH 2 The UiO-66-NH 2 nanocrystals were prepared in the same way as the UiO-66 nanoparticles, except that a ligand functionalized with an amino agent, 2-Aminoterephthalic acid, was used. The product yield of 75% UiO-66-NH 2 yellow powder was obtained based on the amount of zirconium tetrachloride salt.

In general, after modiﬁcation with –NH 2 , the adsorbent will adsorb more anionic dyes [27,28].However, it is worth noting that UiO-66-NH 2 exhibits higher adsorption capacity for cationic dyes and lower adsorption capacity for anionic dyes as compared with UiO-66.2.Experimental 2.1.Materials Zirconium tetrachloride, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, N,Ndimethyl formamide (DMF) and chloroform were supplied from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.2-Amino-1,4benzenedicarboxylic acid was purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd.All of the chemicals were used as-received without further puriﬁcation.2.2.Sample preparation Synthesis of UiO-66 was performed by dissolving ZrCl 4 (0.0848 g, 0.363 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.0603 g, 0.363 mmol) in DMF (42 mL, 544 mmol) with ultrasonic vibration for 30 min.The as-obtained mixture was transferred to a stainless steel Teﬂon-lined autoclave of 50 mL capacity and then maintained at 393 K for 24 h.After this time, the autoclave was cooled in air to room temperature and the resulting solid was ﬁltered, repeatedly washed with CHCl 3 and dried at room temperature.

UiO-66 octahedrons were ﬁrst synthesized through a solvothermal route [45].In a typical procedure, ZrCl 4 (298.4 mg) and 1,4-benzendicarboxylic acid (BDC) (212.8 mg) were dissolved in 130.7 mL N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), 30.0 mL of acetic acid (31.47 mg) was added into the solution to tune the morphology of UiO-66.After ultrasonic treatment for 20 min, the obtained homogeneous solution was then transferred into a 40-mL Teﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 120 ◦ C for 24 h.After cooling to room temperature, the products were collected by centrifugation and wash three times with DMF, and then soaked in methanol at 60 ◦ C for 3 days with replacing the methanol every 24 h to exchanging the DMF solvent.

Preparation of UiO-66 MOFs with DES The UiO-66 MOFs used for CO 2 capture were prepared following previous works with some modiﬁcations [47]. 1.06 g of ZrCl 4 , 0.67 g of BDC were dissolved in 50 mL of DMF. After adding 5 mL of formic acid and then under a ultrasonic dispersion for 30 min, the mixture was added into a 100 mL Teﬂon-lined autoclave and heated in a 120 °C oven for 24 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the product was washed by DMF for 3 times. To activate the sample, the solid was suspended in 30 mL acetone overnight to remove DMF. Subsequently, the product was washed with methanol several times and was dried in vacuum. The obtained product was UiO-66.

2. Materials and methods 2.1. Materials UiO-66 was prepared according to a modiﬁed literature procedure [41]. Speciﬁcally, 40 mmol of zirconium chloride (ZrCl 4 ) and 40 mmol of terephthalic acid (H 2 BDC) were dissolved in 200 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) under ultrasonication for 2 min. The resulting solution was then poured into a 500 mL Teﬂon-lined vessel and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed several times with DMF and absolute ethanol. The resulting solid was dried at 50 °C under vacuum for 24 h to obtain UiO-66. The other three UiO-66 derivatives (UiO-66-NO 2 , UiO-66-Br and UiO-66-NH 2 ) were prepared using the same method replacing H 2 BDC with H 2 BDC-NO 2 , H 2 BDC-Br and H 2 BDC-NH 2 , respectively.

Applied Surface Science 655 (2024) 159623 4  2.4. UiO-66 synthesis  UiO-66 was synthesised by oil bath. For this purpose, 3 mmol ZrCl 4  and 3 mmol H 2 BDC were mixed in 80 mL DMF. The mixture was stirred  for 1 h to obtain a homogeneous solution. Afterwards the solution was  put into a bottom ask where the reactor was transferred into an oil bath  and kept at 120 ℃  for 24 h. Upon reaching ambient temperature, the  obtained  powder  was  rinsed  with  DMF  and  ethanol  for  three  times.  Lastly, the sample was collected after drying at 80 ℃ for enough time.  2.5. UiO-66/g-C 3 N 4  synthesis  A series of  heterojunction photocatalysts were prepared by  a  solvothermal method in an oil bath with various mass ratios of g-C 3 N 4  to  ZrCl 4 .  Porous  g-C 3 N 4  nanosheet  was  grown  in-situ  onto  UiO-66.  Generally, 4  mmol ZrCl 4  and  4  mmol H 2 BDC were  dissolved in  200  mL DMF. When the mixture was stirred enough time to get a homogeneous solution, a certain amount of porous g-C 3 N 4  powder was mixed  into the dispersion. The suspension was stirred for 1 h and then put into  a bottom ask. After that, the ask was placed in oil bath at 120 ℃ for  24  h  with  continuously  magnetic  stirring.  After  natural  cooling,  the  materials were washed with fresh DMF and ethanol for three times. Then  nal resultant solids were collected after drying and named as CNU-0.2,  CNU-0.5, CNU-1 and CNU-2, according to different ratio of porous g-  C 3 N 4  to ZrCl 4 .  2.6. Photocatalytic property experiments  The photocatalytic property of the sample was investigated by photocatalytic  decomposition  of  organic  dyes  using  RhB  as  a  target  pollutant. In a typical experiment, 20 mg sample was added into 100 mL  RhB solution (60 mg/L). The suspension was then stirred thoroughly for  1 h to reach equilibrium before photocatalysis. Then the mixture was  illuminated under a 300 W xenon lamp using 420 nm glass philtre as  visible light. Then with a regular 10-minute interval, the samples were  extracted and subjected to centrifugation at 8000 rpm for separation.  The clear RhB solution was measured with UV–Vis spectra (λ max  = 550  nm). To investigate the underlying mechanism in this photodegradation  process, BQ, IPA and EDTA-2Na were applied as scavengers to conrm  the active radicals related to this photocatalysis reaction. Each experiment was conducted in triplicate, and the average value was computed  for subsequent analysis.  3. Results and discussion  3.1. Phase analysis  The XRD results of UiO-66, porous g-C 3 N 4  and CNU-X composites  were recorded in Fig. 2a. The ndings indicated that the pattern of UiO-  66 was  coincident  with the  simulated  pattern from literature,  which  meant that the fabrication of this MOF material was successful [34]. The  crystalline structure of the fabricated porous g-C 3 N 4  also agreed well  with the standard structure (JCPDS 87–1526) [35]. Two characteristic  peaks were observed in this pattern. The weak peak at 2θ = 13.1 ◦ was  assigned to the (100) plane and attributed to the tri-s-triazine units,  while the strong peak at 2θ  = 27.2 ◦ , indicating the (002) plane, represented the typical graphitic layered structure [36]. Moreover, in the  series  of  g-C 3 N 4 /UiO-66  composite  samples,  the  pronounced  peaks  related  to  UiO-66  and  g-C 3 N 4  could  be  distinctly  identied,  and  no  additional impurities were detected, indicating that the original crystallinity of  the parent  compound was  maintained,  and no  additional  impurities generated in the preparation process. Moreover, the peak at  2θ = 27.2 ◦ of g-C 3 N 4  became more distinct with the increment of g-C 3 N 4  ratio, indicating that the precursor components were combined closely  to form a composite rather than just mixing together [37]. In addition,  an FTIR  spectrum  was obtained to conrm  the  functionalities of the  materials. It was illustrated in Fig.2b that the spectra analysis conrmed  the existence of the basic structures of g-C 3 N 4  and UiO-66 in the nanohybrids.  The peak  at  810  cm − 1  of  the  CNU-X  nanohybrids  could  be  corresponding to the s-triazine units  in  g-C 3 N 4 , and the peaks in the  region of 1200 to 1700 cm − 1  could be assigned to the skeletal vibrations  of C-N rings in g-C 3 N 4  [38]. Moreover, the characteristic peaks between  Fig. 3. SEM of (a) porous g-C 3 N 4 , (b) pristine UiO-66, (c-e) CNU-0.5 nanohybrid.   D. Lan et al.

2. Experimental 2.1. Materials Zirconium (IV) propoxide solution, acetic acid (HAc), N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), terephthalic acid (H 2 BDC, 99%) are purchased from Aladdin Ltd in shanghai. Methylene blue is obtained from kelong in chengdu. There is not any further puriﬁcation for all above chemicals and deionized water is used in all experiments.2.2. Synthesis of UiO-66 UiO-66 was prepared at room temperature in two-step according to a report with some modiﬁcation [26]. Firstly, 71ul of 70% zirconium propoxide solution, 7 mL DMF and 4 mL acetic acid were added to a 20 mL vial. The solution was heated at 150 °C for 2 h under the wrapping of aluminum foil and the color turned yellow. Second, a magnetic stirrer and 75 mg terephthalic acid (H 2 BDC) were added to above solution after cooling down, the solution was sonicated for 30 s and stirred at 300 rpm for 18 h at 25 °C. Finally, the crystal was separated by centrifugation, washed several times with DMF and acetone and dried at 80 °C under a vacuum to get the white powder. This was deﬁned as UiO-66 or UiO-66(0). UiO-66 (x) samples with various H 2 O/Zr molar ratio were prepared by adding water at ﬁrst step, they were denoted as UiO-66(x) (x = 10, 30, 60, 100).

Chemical Physics 543 (2021) 111093 2  Ltd and used without further purication, and deionized water was used  in all experiments.  2.2. Synthesis of UiO-66 and UiO-66-X(X = NH 2 , NO 2 , NH 2  and NO 2 )  Materials  were  synthesized  following  procedures  previously  reported [30]. First of all, to a 20 mL vial was sequentially added 142  μ l of  a 70% zirconium propoxide (Zr(OnPr) 4 ) solution in 1-propanol (0.158  mmol), 14 mL DMF and 8 mL acetic acid. The sample bottle was heated  at 150  ◦ C for 2 h in an aluminum foil package, and the solution turned  yellow. Then, the solution was cooled down to room temperature followed by addition of the desired terephthalic acid (75 mg), terephthalic  acid (75 mg) and 2-amino-terephthalic acid (82 mg) (molar ratio is 1:1),  terephthalic acid (75 mg) and 2-nitro-terephthalic acid (95 mg) (molar  ratio is 1:1), 2-amino-terephthalic acid (82 mg) and 2-nitro-terephthalic  acid (95 mg) (molar ratio is 1:1) respectively and sonicated for 30 s.  Next,  the  abovementioned  solution  was  stirred  continuously  with  a  magnetic stirrer at 300 rpm for 18 h at 25  ◦ C. Finally, the adsorbent was  separated  from  the  supernatant  by  centrifugation  and  was  washed  several times with DMF and solvent exchanged with ethanol. Samples  were then heated in a vacuum drying oven at 80  ◦ C for several times to  obtain a white powder.  2.3. Characterization  The samples were characterized by SEM, XRD, Fourier transformed  infrared  spectroscopy  (FT-IR),  Brunauer-Emmett-Teller  (BET)  surface  area and the pore volume and contact angle test. The morphologies and  microstructures were observed using SEM (Hitachi S4800). The crystal  structures and compositions of the samples were analyzed by powder X-  ray diffraction (XRD) (Bruker D2 Focus Powder X-ray diffractometer).  The laser light source  is  CuK α  radiation (λ  = 0.15405 nm), the tube  voltage is 40 kV, and the tube current is 40 mA. The crystal functional  groups were analyzed by Fourier Infrared Spectrometer (SP 2000, USA).  The nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms were obtained using  the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method at 77 K after degassing the  samples at 100  ◦ C for 4 h by an analyzer (Quantachrome, Quadrasorb  evo, Boynton Beach, FL, USA). The hydrophilicity of the samples water  contact  angle  tests  were  conducted  using  XG-CAMB3  Contact  Anglemete.  The  volume  of  the  drops  of  water  was  3  μ l  and  photos  were  recorded 10 s after drip, the test was repeated 3 times and the average  was reported.  2.4. Adsorption of water  Adsorption isotherms of water were measured with a water vapor  adsorption  analyzer  (AQUADYNE  DVS-2)  at  298  K.  Before  the  measurement, the samples were evacuated under vacuum for 12 h at 80  ◦ C.  The measurement humidity range is 2% RH ~ 90% RH.  3. Results and discussion  3.1. Charcterization of UiO-66 and UiO-66-X (X = NH 2 , NO 2 , NH 2  and  NO 2 )  SEM and XRD were used to study the micromorphology and lattice  structure of UiO-66 and UiO-66-X (X = NH 2 , NO 2 , NH 2  and NO 2 ) crystalline power.  Fig.  1 shows  the  SEM  images  of  UiO-66,  UiO-66-NH 2 ,  UiO-66-NO 2  and  UiO-66-(NH 2  + NO 2 ).  All  samples  exhibit  a  similar  crystalline  morphology  with  homogeneous  smooth  cubic  shape  at  different sizes. UiO-66 present particle size around 100 nm, while the  size of UiO-66 decreased after introducing functionalized groups. UiO-  66-(NH 2  + NO 2 ) exhibited the smallest crystal size, however, it aggregated severely.  Fig. 2 shows the XRD pattern of the UiO-66, UiO-66-NH 2 , UiO-66-  NO 2  and UiO-66-(NH 2  + NO 2 ), which shows a crystalline state with the  same peak position as reported in the literature [31]. From the XRD  pattern, it could nd the several main peaks are one-to-one correspondence, but the intensity reduced a little in presence of functional groups.  It  is  conrmed  that  the  functional  groups  have  not  change  crystal  structure of UiO-66. The little broadness of the UiO-66-(NH 2  + NO 2 )  peaks is a result of the smaller sizes of the particles, which is agree with  the results of SEM images.  Fig. 3 show FTIR spectra of UiO-66, UiO-66-NH 2 , UiO-66-NO 2  and  UiO-66-(NH 2  + NO 2 ) samples. The strong absorption band at 1657 cm − 1  assigned  to  the  stretching  vibration  of  C – – O  bond  from  DMF  was  observed. The shear expansion of the unique C – N stretching in the aromatic amine appears at 1267 cm − 1 . The peak of UiO-66-NO 2  at 1540  cm − 1  belongs to the asymmetric stretching vibration of nitro. After cooling, this mixture was centrifuged and excess solvent was removed under vacuum at room temperature for 12 h.The obtained pale yellow powder was denoted as 2Br-UiO-66.UiO-66Br and UiO-66 were synthesized with the same procedure as above described but replaced H 2 BDC-Br 2 to H 2 BDCBr 1 or H 2 BDC.The UiO-66 and active carbon (AC) were also functionalized by impregnation method for comparison with the 2Br-UiO-66 and BrUiO-66 in the Hg 0 capturing and bromine leaching experiments.

Journal of Hazardous Materials 451 (2023) 131113 3  1 day. Then the organic solvent was removed by using a rotary evaporator, and hydrochloric acid (37% w/w) was added dropwise into the  remaining solution until pH = 1. The nal yellow product was further  washed using DI water and later dried in the lyophilizer overnight to  remove the residual solvent.  2.3. Synthesis of zirconium-based metal-organic frameworks  The  VNU-1  synthesis  procedure  is  based  on  previously  reported  methods [16]. Two aqueous solutions had been prepared while solution  A contained a mixture of 109 mg (0.340 mmol) ZrOCl 2 ⋅8 H 2 O, 5 mL  acetic acid, and 20 mL DMF solvent, and solution B was prepared by  dissolving 124 mg (0.340 mmol) H 2 CPEB linker in 15 mL DMF solvent.  After sonicated for 30 min, both solutions A and B were mixed into a  100 mL Duran®  glass bottle and heated under 120  ◦ C for 1 day in an  isothermal oven. The as-synthesized VNU-1 was centrifuged under 20,  000  rpm  for 5  min  with  DMF three  times  and  MeOH  one  time, and  further  dried  in  the  lyophilizer  for  one  day  to  remove  the  residual  solvent.  The procedure for the synthesis of the UiO series MOFs was based on  previous literature [17,19,44]. In a typical UiO-67 synthesis procedure,  93.2 mg (0.4 mmol) of ZrCl 4  was rst dissolved in 0.38 mL acetic acid  and 5 mL DMF solvent. 96.8 mg (0.4 mmol) of H 2 BPDC linker were then  dissolved in 10 mL DMF solvent. Both aqueous solutions were further  mixed in a 50 mL vial and heated under 120  ◦ C in an isothermal oven for  1 day after 30 min ultrasonication. For UiO-66, 0.111 g (0.343 mmol) of  ZrOCl 2 ⋅8 H 2 O and 0.8377 g (6.86 mol) of benzoic acid were dissolved in  20 mL DMF solvent. Then 0.057 g (0.343 mmol) of H 2 BDC were added  and sonicated until they dissolved. The aqueous solution was heated  under 120 ℃ for 1 day to form UiO-66. UiO-66-NH 2  were synthesized  under similar conditions with the previous MOFs. 138 mg (0.428 mmol)  of ZrOCl 2 ⋅8 H 2 O were dissolved into 24 mL acetic acid and 36 mL DMF  solvents. After fully dissolved, 77.6 mg (0.428 mmol) H 2 BDC-NH 2  were  added  and  sonicated  for  another  30  min.  The  mixture  solution  was  heated  under  120  ◦ C  for  1  day  to  synthesize  UiO-66-NH 2 .  All  the  as-synthesized UiO series MOFs were centrifuged with DMF solvent 3  times and MeOH 1 time under 20,000 rpm for 5 min and further vacuumed in lyophilizer for overnight.  2.4. Characterization of metal-organic frameworks  The functional group of H 2 CPEB organic compound was measured by  a Bruker 500 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance with TMS as standard.  The sample was prepared by dissolving the H 2 CPEB organic linker into  deuterated solvent (CDCl 3 ) and ltrated by a 0.22 µm nylon lter into  the NMR tube. Wide-angle patterns of powder X-Ray diffraction (XRD)  were measured by Rigaku Ultima IV with Cu K α  radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å)  to identify the crystallinity of all Zr-based MOFs. The operation condition was xed at a generator voltage of 40 kV and an emission current of  40 mA. The X-ray diffraction results were recorded in the angle range  (2θ) from 3 ◦ to 50 ◦ with a scan rate of 20  ◦ min -1 . The morphology of all  Zr-based MOFs was observed with applying FE-SEM (Nova™ NanoSEM  230). Before SEM observation, the samples on the holder were sputtered  by Pt metal for 2 min under 20 mA to increase the electric conductivity  of samples. The operating voltage was set between 5 and 10 kV and the  spot size was 3.0–4.0. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherm was  measured with BELSORP-series. The specic surface area was evaluated  by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and the pore size distribution  was  estimated  by  the  non-linear  density  functional  theory  (NLDFT).  The  samples  were  degassed  at  120  ◦ C  for  8  h  under  high  vacuum  (0.1  Pa)  and  kept  at  77  K  during  measurement.  The  UV–VIS–NIR spectrophotometer (JASCO V-670) was applied to measure  the light-harvesting properties of Zr-based MOFs between wavelengths  of 250–850 nm. The baseline was measured and offset with the sample  by  using BaSO 4  because of  its  near-perfect diffuse  reectance  in  the  250–2500 nm  wavelength range. The  emission wavelengths  between  350 and 600 nm of Zr-based MOFs were measured by using the photoluminescence (PL) with a pulse laser excitation wavelength of 375 nm. A  lter was added on the detector to ltrate the signal below 400 nm. The  lifetime  of  different  MOFs  was  measured  by  time-resolved  photoluminescence with  a  channel resolution  of 4 ps.  The laser  excitation  wavelength was xed at 375 nm, and the detected emission wavelength  of every MOF was depended on the highest emission wavelength evaluated  by  photoluminescence  spectra.  The  X-ray  photoelectron  spectroscopy (XPS) was performed with a micro focused electron gun and the  multi  position  aluminum  anode  along  with  a  monochromated  X-ray  source. The XPS spectra at the lowest energy were analyzed to obtain the  valence band maxima (VBM), and the conduction band minima (CBM)  was derived from the formula of CBM = CBM + Eg, where Eg was the  energy gap identied in the tauc plot [14,57]. All the samples were dried  under vacuum for 1 day before measuring.  2.5. Adsorption and photocatalytic reaction test  Sulfamethoxazole adsorption and photocatalytic reaction was done  by  SUNTEST  CPS+ sunlight  simulator  with  a  xenon  lamp  under the  conditions of pH 7, ambient temperature, a wavelength from 300 nm to  800 nm and light intensity of 700 W/m 2 . 10 mg of Zr-based MOF were  added into a quartz beaker with 100 mL sulfamethoxazole solution (80  ppb). Before the light irradiation, the suspension was stirred vigorously  under dark condition for an hour to reach adsorption-desorption equilibrium,  then  the  light  was  switched  on  to  run  the  photocatalytic  degradation for 30 min. During the reaction, 0.5 mL of suspension was  taken out at intervals and ltered through a 0.22 µm PVDF membrane  for  further  analysis.  The  sulfamethoxazole  concentration  was  determined based on the LC-MS/MS analysis. The eluent solution was prepared by mixing methanol and deionized water solution with different  volume  ratios  under  different  time,  the  details  were  arranged  in  Table S1. Blank control experiments were done in the absence of catalysts under the same condition. All the experiments were repeated three  times and averaged to get the data points.  2.6. Size-selective test  To study the size-selective property of VNU-1, three different molecule size of antibiotics (SMX, AMP, and LIN) with a concentration of 80  ppb were added along with the big molecule humic acid (20 ppm) into  DI water to form a mixture system. 10 mg of VNU-1 was added into the  mixture solution and stir for 1 h to reach adsorption-desorption equilibrium, followed by a photocatalytic reaction for 1 h. The reaction was  done under the same conditions as the adsorption and photodegradation  experiments. During the reaction, 0.5 mL of suspension is taken out and  ltered through a 0.22 µm PVDF membrane for LC-MS/MS and LC-DAD  analysis.  The eluent solution was prepared by mixing the methanol and 10  mM ammonia bicarbonate in the deionized water solution with different  volume ratios under different time, and  the details were  arranged in  Table S2.  Blank  control  experiments  were  done  in  the  absence  of  catalysts  under the same condition. The result was compared with the commercial  photocatalyst (Degussa P25) to compare the selectivity properties.  2.7. Total organic carbon and Microtox® test  The  mineralization  of  the  antibiotics  was  measured  using  total  organic carbon (TOC) analyser. The experiment was done by preparing  two solutions. The rst solution, solution A, contained 20 mg of VNU-1  and 3 different antibiotics (SMX, AMP, LIN), each with 10 ppm concentration. Solution B acted as a background that contained only 20 mg  of VNU-1 photocatalyst without adding any antibiotics. After adsorbing  in dark condition for 2 h and light irradiation for 2 h, the TOC analysis  has  been  measured.  The  actual  TOC  value  was  then  calculated  by  J.-X. Tan et al.

2.2. Synthesis of UiO-66 and defective UiO-66 UiO-66 was synthesized according to the literature [25] with some modiﬁcations. Typically, ZrCl 4 (0.932 g, 4.0 mmol), H 2 BDC (1.329 g, 8.0 mmol) and 36% HCl (0.67 mL) were dissolved in DMF (25 mL) at room temperature via ultrasonication. The mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teﬂon-lined autoclave, sealed and placed in a preheated oven at 493 K for 20 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed with DMF three times. Then the solid was stirred in DMF at 363 K for 12 h, then in methanol at 333 K for 12 h. The resulting white powder was dried under vacuum at 423 K for 12 h.The argon plasma was generated by using a dielectric barrier discharge (DBD). The pristine MOF samples were added into the DBD plasma reactor and treated under a dynamic argon plasma atmosphere.The peak-to-peak applied voltage was 20 kV with a sinusoidal waveform at a frequency of about 10 kHz. More detailed procedures for the DBD plasma treatment can be found in our previous works [26]. The infrared imaging was applied to measure the bulk temperature of the DBD plasma. The highest temperature measured is lower than 398 K, similar to that reported previously [27]. The thermal eﬀect of the DBD plasma treatment can therefore be ignored on the thermally stable UiO66.

Experimental Synthesis of UiO-66 and MIL-101 frameworks UiO-66 was synthesized by a solvothermal method, using a mixture of zirconium chloride (2.54 g) and terephthalic acid (2.48 g) in 20 mL of hydrochloric acid and 300 mL of dimethylformamide, heated at 80  C for 12 h [31]. The as synthesized material was activated by ethanol reﬂux, after removal of the mother liquor.

ZIF-8 and UiO-66 were synthesized through the typical solvothermal method [41,42]. For the ZIF-8, a solid mixture of Zn(NO 3 ) 2 ,6H 2 O (1.2 g, 3.2 mmol) and 2-methylimidazole (0.3 g, international journal of hydrogen energy 47 (2022) 19690e19701 19691   
3.2 mmol) were ultrasonically dissolved in 90 ml of DMF for about 30 min. The vial was heated to 135  C at a heating rate of 5  C,min 1 in a programmable oven and held at this temperature for about 24 h. The product was collected by centrifugation at 5000 rpm for 20 min. The obtained yellowish product was washed with DI water three times and dried overnight at 80  C. For the UiO-66, 0.83 g (5 mmol) of terephthalic acid and 1.165 g (5 mmol) of ZrCl 4 were ultrasonically dissolved in two separate 100 ml DMF. Then, two solutions were mixed and stirred for about 15 min. The vial was heated to 135  C at a heating rate of 5  Cmin 1 in a programmable oven and held at this temperature for about 24 h. The product was collected by centrifugation at 5000 rpm for 20 min. The obtained whitish product was washed with DI water three times and dried overnight at 80  C.

Experimental section Synthesis of UiO-66 Concisely, 150 mg of ZrCl 4 (0.64 mmol) was dissolved in the mixture of 5 mL of HAc (87.50 mmol)/40 mL of DMF (N,Ndimethylformamide, 51.72 mmol) in a 100 mL round-bottom ﬂask to form a clean solution. After sonicated for 20 min at room temperature, 120 mg of PTA (terephthalic acid, 0.73 mmol) was dissolved into the above solution. The mixture was further sonicated about 20 min at room temperature, and then heated up to 120  C for 5 h. After naturally cooled down to room temperature, the white precipitate was centrifugally separated. The product was washed with methanol for three times and followed by vacuum dry at 150  C for 12 h.

international journal of hydrogen energy 49 (2024) 892e 906 893   The preparation steps of the UiO-66 sample are demonstrated in Fig. S2. Accordingly, 1.39 mL of HCl and 2.079 g of ZrCl 4 were added to the 50 mL of N, N-dimethyl formamide (DMF, C 3 H 7 NO, 99%) and sonicated under a 50 W ultrasonic wave (Bandelin-Sonorex Digitec, Germany) for 15 min. The mixture was sonicated for another 25 min by adding 1.48 g of BDC and 100 mL of DMF. A stainless steel Teﬂon-lined autoclave bomb was used to heat the slurry for 36 h at 120  C. The resulting solid had washed with warm water and DMF to remove the excess unreacted BDC. The sample collected by centrifugation was transferred to a soxhlet extractor with methanol (99%) as the solvent for complete puriﬁcation. The synthesized sample was calcined at 275  C for 24 h as a ﬁnal step. The resulting white powder product was called UiO-66.

paragraph: 2.2. Synthesis of UiO-66 UiO-66 (Zr-MOF) was synthesized by following the procedure reported previously [20]. Brieﬂy, 466 mg of ZrCl 4 was mixed (stirring for 15 min) in a solvent mixture of 3 mL of deionized (DI) water and 15 mL of DMF. Separately, 465 mg of BDC was dispersed in 20 mL of DMF (15 min stirring). The above two solutions were then mixed and stirred for 8 h (80  C). The reaction led to the formation of white precipitates, which were centrifuged and washed several times with DMF and DI water to remove unreacted precursors. The product was dried under vacuum for 24 h (80  C). The ﬁnal sample was ground before further use.

2.2. Preparation of UiO-66 MOFs The preparation of UiO-66 and UiO-66-NH 2 were carried out following the procedures in previous works [43,57]. For UiO-66, ZrCl 4 (4.49 mmol, 1.06 g), Terephthalic acid (4.49 mmol, 0.67 g), 5 mL formic acid were dissolved in 50 mL DMF and then heated at 120 °C for 24 h. The white powder was obtained by centrifugation Fig. 1. Schematic structures of UiO-66-NH 2 , PEBA and UiO-66-NH 2 -PEBA mixed matrix membrane.J. Shen et al. / Journal of Membrane Science 513 (2016) 155–165156   at 8000 rpm for 10 min and were immersed in methanol for solvent exchange for three days and activated under vacuum at 100 °C. Similar process was carried out for the synthesis of UiO-66-NH 2 through replacing the Terephthalic acid (4.49 mmol, 0.67 g) with 2-aminoterephthalic acid (4.49 mmol, 0.81 g).

Aniline (Ani), Ammonium persulfate (APS), N,N′- dimethylformamide (DMF), Ethanol and Methanol were purchased from Tianjin Tianli Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Sulfuric acid (H 2 SO 4 ) and Hydrochloric acid (HCl) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 1,4benzenedicarboxylic acid (H 2 BDC), ZrCl 4 and paminodiphenylamine (AD) were purchased from Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd. Carbon cloth (CC) was purchased from CeTech Co., Ltd. (Taiwan).2.2. Preparation of UiO-66 The synthesis of Zr-MOF(UiO-66) was based on a previously reported procedure with some modiﬁcation [35,36]. First, ZrCl 4 (0.63 g, 2.7 mmol) was dissolved through ultrasound in DMF (25 mL) for 3–5 min, until it became clear, then concentrated HCl (5 mL, 60 mmol) was added and the mixture was sonicated by ultrasound for 5 min.

2.3. Synthesis of adsorption material UIO-66 was synthesized on the basis of a previous study with minor modiﬁcation [44]. ZrCl 4 (827.76 mg, 3.55 mmol) and terephthalic acid (590.73 mg, 3.55 mmol) used as the precursors were dissolved in 60 mL DMF. The subsequent mixture was dispersed by ultrasound and quickly transferred into a Teﬂon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. Then, the sealed stainless-steel autoclave was maintained at the temperature of 120 °C for 24 h. The resulting white powder UIO-66 was washed with DMF and ethanol for several times, respectively, and desiccated overnight at room temperature in a vacuum oven. Subsequently, the UIO-66 white powder was activated at 200 °C for 12 h and preserved in ambient atmosphere for the next use.

2. Experimental 2.1. Synthesis of UIO-66 (Zr) and UIO-66 (NH 2 ) In a typical synthesis, ZrCl 4 (0.2332 g, 1.0 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.1661 g, 1.0 mmol) or 2-NH 2 -terephthalic acid (0.1812 g, 1.0 mmol) were dissolved in DMF (50 mL), and then the solution was transferred to a 100 mL Teﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave [25,26]. The autoclave was sealed and heated in an oven at 120  C for 40 h under autogenous pressure. After being cooled naturally, the obtained sample was puriﬁed with anhydrous ethanol several times to make sure that the DMF molecules were eliminated, and then the off-white UIO-66 (Zr) or yellow UIO-66 (NH 2 ) product was dried at 80  C for 24 h.2.2. Synthesis of ZnTCPc ZnSO 4 $7H 2 O (0.048 mol), trimellitic anhydride (0.176 mol), ammonium chloride (0.085 mol) and urea (1 mol) were mixed with ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate (0.004 mol). The mixture was dissolved in 10 mL nitrobenzene and then reﬂuxed at 185  C during 4 h. The dark blue solid obtained was puriﬁed with 0.1 M NaOH and 1 M HCl solution, respectively.

2. Experiments 2.1. Synthesis of UiO-66 MOF All reagents were analytical grade and were used without further puriﬁcation. UiO-66 photocatalyst was synthesized following a previous synthesis protocol [32]. In a typical synthesis, ZrCl 4 (37.3 mg) and 1,4-benzendicarboxylic acid (BDC) (26.6 mg) were ﬁrst dissolved in 16.34 mL N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF). Acetic acid (3.66 mL, 3.8 mg) was then added into the solution, following the ultrasonic treatment for 20 min. The homogeneous solution was then transferred into a 40-mL Teﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 120 ◦ C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the products were collected by centrifugation and wash three times with DMF, and then soaked in methanol at 60 ◦ C for three days with replacing the methanol every 24 h to exchange the DMF solvent.

2.1.1. Synthesis of UiO-66 UiO-66 was synthesized by a modiﬁed solvothermal method based on a previous work [47]. In a typical synthesis, ZrCl 4 (0.2332 g, 1.0 mmol) and terephthalic acid (H 2 BDC) (0.1661 g, 1.0 mmol) were dissolved in DMF (50 mL), then the solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated in an oven at 120 ◦ C for 24 h. After cooled naturally, the sample was puriﬁed with anhydrous methanol for several times to make sure that the occluded DMF molecules were eliminated, followed by drying under vacuum (100 ◦ C, 12 h), the ﬁnal UiO-66 sample was obtained.

Ltd.2.2.Preparation of photocatalysts 2.2.1.Synthesis of FeUiO-66 A series of FeUiO-66 nanocomposites with different mole ratios of FeCl 3 ·6H 2 O vs ZrCl 4 were synthesized by a facile one-pot solvothermal reaction.In a typical synthesis, ZrCl 4 (1 mmol) and H 2 BDC (1 mmol) were ﬁrst dissolved in 60 mL of DMF.A series of variational amount of FeCl 3 ·6H 2 O were then added into the above solution and continuous stirring for 1 h, respectively.The clear and yellow solution was then transferred into a 100 mL Teﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 120 ◦ C for 48 h.After cooled to room temperature, the products were collected by centrifugation and washed with DMF and anhydrous ethanol three times, respectively, and then the solid was dried at 110 ◦ C under vacuum for 12 h to remove the excess of unreacted organic linkers and DMF.As a contrast, the UiO-66 was also prepared according the same methods; the only difference is the absence of FeCl 3 ·6H 2 O.The obtained products were named as FeUiO(x) (x = 1:1; 1:2; 1:5 and 1:10, which stand for the mole ratios of FeCl 3 ·6H 2 O vs ZrCl 4 ).

2.1. Preparation of catalysts 2.1.1. Preparation of UiO-66 UiO-66 was synthesized according to the process reported elsewhere with a slight modiﬁcation [24]. Typically, ZrCl 4 (0.233 g, 1.0 mmol) and benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1.0 mmol) were dissolved in dimethylformamide (DMF, 50 mL). Then 5 mL of acetic acid was added. The mixture was introduced into a teﬂon-lined autoclave of 100 mL and heated at 393 K for 40 h in an oven under static condition.

2. Experimental 2.1. Chemicals Zirconium (IV) chloride (ZrCl 4 , 98 %, Aladdin), Pd(OAc) 2 (Pd, 47.4 %, Aladdin), terephthalic acid (H 2 BDC, 99 %), N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.5 %), absolute ethanol (99.7 %), acetic acid (36 %) and ethylene glycol (EG, 99 %) were bought from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Sodium tetrahydroborate (NaBH 4 , 98 %) was purchased from Shanghai Titan scientiﬁc Co., Ltd. All the chemicals were analytical grade and were used directly.2.2. Catalysts preparation 2.2.1. Synthesis of UiO-66 The UiO-66 was synthesized by a conventional solvothermal synthesis (Scheme 1(a)) [6]. In this method, 0.053 g ZrCl 4 (0.227 mmol) and 0.034 g H 2 BDC (0.227 mmol) ultrasound dissolved in 5 ml DMF.After that, the obtained mixture was transferred in a Teﬂon-lined autoclave and reacted in an oven at 120 °C for 24 h. After cooling down to ambient temperature, the white powder could be got by centrifugation and washing with ethanol for 3–4 times, and ﬁnally dried at 70 °C overnight in an oven.

The UiO-66 was synthesized by a modiﬁed method [32]. Firstly, 0.0746 g of ZrCl 4 and 0.0532 g of H 2 BTC were dissolved in 32.68 mL of DMF. After stirred for 30 min, 7.32 mL of acetic acid was added in the as-obtained solution and ultrasonicated at room temperature for 10 min. Next, the resulting suspension was sealed in 100 mL Teﬂonlined stainless-steel autoclave and put in an oven with a temperature of 120 °C for 24 h. After the autoclave was cooled down, the sample was ﬁltered oﬀ and washed with methanol for three times. Then, the asobtained solid was immersed in 150 mL of methanol for 12 h to remove the excess DMF and ﬁnally dried at 150 °C for 12 h.

UiO-66 was synthesized by a solvothermal method according to reported procedures [35] with some changes in molar ratio of ZrCl 4 : H 2 BDC: DMF.
In our typical preparation, ZrCl 4 (0.208 g, 0.893 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of DMF, then the mixture was added by 0.148 g of H 2 BDC (0.893 mmol) under nitrogen atmosphere at r.t.
(28 ◦ C).
The obtained mixture was sealed in a solvothermal autoclave and placed in a pre-heated oven at 120 ◦ C for 24 h.
Crystallization was allowed in a static condition.
After cooling to r.t., the mixture was ﬁltered and washed three times with 5 mL of DMF at r.t.
and ﬁltered to give white solid precipitates.
The precipitates were immersed in 10 mL of chloroform at r.t.
and replaced daily for 3 times.
The materials were dried in vacuo at 140 ◦ C for 8 h, yielding white powder crystals.
UiO-67 was synthesized with the same procedure as above by replacing H 2 BDC to H 2 BPDC as the organic linker.
Formations of UiO-66 and UiO-67 were conﬁrmed from their XRD patterns (Supplementary material; Fig.
S2) as reported in the literature [35,41].

2.2. Synthesis of the catalysts UiO-66 was synthesized under conditions similar to those reported in the literature with a few modiﬁcations [41]. In brief, ZrCl 4 (0.795 g, 3.411 mmol) and terephthalic acid (0.566 g, 3.411 mmol) were dissolved in 250 mL of DMF by sonication at room temperature. 15 mL of acetic acid were added to the obtained mixture that was put in a 500 mL autoclavable reagent bottle and placed in a pre-heated oven at 120 °C for 21 h. The obtained white precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed three times with around 50 mL of DMF and then three times with 50 mL of DCM. In the ﬁrst two washes in each solvent, MOFs were allowed to settle for 3 h, whereas in the last wash, MOFs were soaked in the fresh solvent overnight. UiO-66 was then dried in a vacuum oven at 140 °C overnight. The synthesis of UiO-66(COOH) 2 and UiO-66(NH 2 ) was done in the same manner but by replacing the terephthalic acid with 1, 2, 4, 5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid (0.866 g, 3.411 mmol) and 2-aminoterphthalic acid (0.617 g, 3.411 mmol) as the linker respectively.

2. Experimental section 2.1. Synthesis of UiO-66 The pristine UiO-66 samples were prepared by solvothermal method reported by Behrens [32]. ZrCl 4 (300 mg, 1.287 mmol, ≥98 %) and CH 3 COOH (5 mL, ≥99.5 %) modulator were dissolved in dimethylformamide (DMF, 50 mL, ≥99.5 %) with ultrasound applied for 5 min. Deionized water (150 μL) and Benzen-1,4-dicaboxylic (H 2 BDC, 215 mg, 1.287 mmol, ≥99.5 %) were dissolved in the solution by sonication for about 15 min. The solution was transferred into a Teﬂonlined stainless-steel autoclave and reacted at 120 °C for 24 h. The white precipitates were collected by centrifugation after ripening by cooling at room temperature for 12 h. The products were washed ﬁve times and three times with DMF and acetone respectively to remove unreacted reagent and DMF. The obtained powder was dried at 60 °C. The acetone-exchanged UiO-66 samples were activated by evacuating at 90 °C under vacuum for 2 h and at 150 °C for 12 h.

2.2. Preparation of Fe 3 O 4 @UiO-66@UiO-67/CTAB composite 2.2.1. Preparation of UiO-66 69.9 mg ZrCl 4 , 49.8 mg H 2 BDC and 20 mL DMF were mixed together and the solution was sonicated for 10 min. Later, 0.1 mL HCl and 0.5 mL HAc were sequentially added in the mixture solution, then, stirred and placed in a 100 mL Teﬂon-lined hydrothermal reaction kettle, and the hydrothermal reaction kettle was placed in an oven at 120 °C for 24 h, and then cooled down. After that, the resultant solid (UiO-66) was separated by centrifugation, washed alternately with methanol and DMF several times. Finally, it was dried overnight at 80 °C.

All  chemicals were analytical grade and the deionized water was produced  in our laboratory.
