Synthesis methods of adsorbents  UiO-66 was prepared by the solvothermal method [32] as shown in   Fig. 1a. 3.77 g ZrCl 4 , 2.4 mL 37% HCl, 5.38 g H 2 BDC and 97.3 mL DMF  were mixed in a 250 mL beaker by sonication for 20 min. They were  crystallized  in  a  sealed  stainless  steel  autoclave  for  20  h  at  120  ◦ C,  170  ◦ C, and 220  ◦ C, respectively. After the crystallization, they were  washed  twice  with  60  mL  of  DMF,  twice  with  60  mL  of  anhydrous  methanol,  separated  by  centrifugation,  and  nally  vacuum-dried  at  90  ◦ C  for  12  h.  The  prepared  adsorbent  materials  were  named  as  UiO-66-A, UiO-66-B, and UiO-66-C. The NCM-WIT and U-(OH) 2  materials  were  synthesized  by  adjusting  the  different  amounts  of  HCl,  as  shown in Fig. 1b. The NCM-WIT was obtained by adding 2.4 mL of 37%  HCl  (29  mmol)  and  DOBDC  6.42  g  (32.4  mmol),  and  the  resulting  samples were named NCM-WIT-A, NCM-WIT-B, NCM-WIT-C at crystallization  temperature  120  ◦ C,  170  ◦ C  or  220  ◦ C,  respectively.  The  U-(OH) 2  was obtained by increasing to 30 mL of 37% HCl (363 mmol)  and the organic ligand DOBDC (32.4 mmol), which were crystallized for  20 h at 120  ◦ C, 170  ◦ C or 220  ◦ C, respectively, and the obtained crystals  were named as U-(OH) 2 -A, U-(OH) 2 -B, U-(OH) 2 -C(X) (X indicates that it  was the non-crystalline structure or amorphous structure).  2.3. Adsorption and regeneration experiments  All adsorption experiments were performed at an ambient temperature of 25 ◦ C, and the effects of solutions at different pH, adsorption  time and initial MB concentration on adsorption were investigated. First,  the effect of solution pH from 3 to 11 adjusted with 2 mol⋅L − 1  HCl and  NaOH solutions was studied on the adsorption process. The adsorption  performance  was  investigated  by  adding  20 mg  of  the  adsorbent  to  50 mL of a MB solution with a concentration of 400 mg⋅L − 1 . Second, the  adsorbent  materials  of  20 mg  were  added  into  50 mL  MB  solution  (pH=7, C=400 mg⋅L − 1 ) to determine the adsorption kinetics (0–6 h). At  Fig. 2. Zirconium-based MOF of UiO-66 is consist of dodecadentate Zr 6 O 4 (OH) 4 cluster and 1,4-benzene-dicarboxylate linker, interconnection of linker and metal cluster forms inﬁnite octahedral cavities (Cavka et al., 2008). UiO-66 is characterized by very high surface area, excellent thermal stability, resistant to many chemicals and preserves crystalline morphology after exposure to high external pressures (Cavka et al., 2008; Valenzano et al., 2011). This high stability of UiO-66 and porous morphology of MOFs motivated our interest in investigating its functional derivative potential as enzyme cellulase carrier without further chemical modiﬁcation.2. Materials and methods 2.1. Materials Cellulase originated from Trichoderma reesei (10,000 U/g) was purchased from Macklin Biochemical (Shanghai, China); D-glucose, carboxymethyl cellulose, 3,5-dinitrosalicylic acid (DNS), sodium bisul ﬁte, 3,5-dinitro-salicylic acid, potassium sodium tartate tetrahydrate, sodium nitrite, zirconium chloride (ZrCl 4 ), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid and 2-amino benzene dicarboxylic acid, were purchased from Aladdin Chemicals (Shanghai, China).2.2. Zirconium based metal-organic frameworks synthesis The synthesis of UiO-66 follows a method reported by Abid et al.(2013), with slight modiﬁcation. 0.053 g of ZrCl 4 (0.227 mmol) and 0.034 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.227 mmol) were dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (20.5 mL) at room temperature. The solution was placed in a solvothermal reactor and kept in an oven programed for heating at 120 °C for 1440 min followed by cooling to 25 °C in 120 min.

2.2. Preparation of UiO-66 UiO-66 was prepared with the procedure described by Cavka et al.[19]. Typ ically, ZrCl 4 (53 mg, 0.227 mmol), benzoic acid (530 mg, 4.344 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (34 mg, 0.227 mmol) were dissolved in DMF (25 ml), and the solution was heated in an autoclave at 393 K for 24 h. Then the autoclave was cooled to room temperature. The ﬁltered cake was washed with DMF and CHCl 3 ,anddriedat room temperature under reduced pressure. For comparison, UiO-66 was also prepared without adding benzoic acid.

2.2. Synthesis of UiO-66 UiO-66 powder sample was synthesized according to the previously reported method [88,89]. Typically, zirconium chlori de (0.64 g), terephthalic acid (0.456 g) and 4.0 ml of acetic acid were dissolved in 40 ml N, N-dim ethylformamide (DMF) in a PTFE-lined reactor under stirring for 2 h. The reactor was sealed and placed in an oven at 120 °C for 24 h under static conditions [31]. After completion of solvothermal reaction, the reactor was cooled down to room temperature. The precipitates were isolated by centrifugation at 3000 r·min − 1 for 5 min. The collected solid was suspended in DMF (10 ml) to remove unreacted reagents and impurities, and then collected by centrifugation.

2. Experimental 2.1. Materials Sodium sulphide (Na 2 S·9H 2 O), indium nitrate (In(NO 3 ) 3 ·xH 2 O), 1,4benzendicarboxylic acid (H 2 BDC), zirconium tetrachloride (ZrCl 4 ), graphite powder, potassium permanganate (KMnO 4 ), sodium nitrate (NaNO 3 ), hydrogen peroxide solution (H 2 O 2 ), sulfuric acid (H 2 SO 4 ), acetic acid (CH 3 COOH) and N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF) are of analytical grade and used as received without further puriﬁcation.2.2. Synthesis and preparation 2.2.1. Synthesis of UiO-66 UiO-66 octahedrons were synthesized via a solvothermal method following the previous report [41]. Brieﬂy, ZrCl 4 (1.0 mmol, 233.0 mg) and H 2 BDC (1.0 mmol, 166.0 mg) were dissolved in the mixed solution consist of 100 mL N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF) and 23 mL acetic acid which was added to turn the morphology of UiO-66. The obtained mixture was stirred for 1 h under room temperature and then sealed in a Teﬂon-lined autoclave and heated in an oven at 120 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the white solid products were collected by ﬁltration and thoroughly washed by deionized (DI) water and ethanol for three times, and then dried at 60 °C in the vacuum drying oven for 6 h.

(Shanghai, China). N 2 was purchased from Nanjing Special Gas Company. N, N-Dimethylformamide (DMF, AR, 99 %), terephthalic acid (H 2 BDC, AR, 99 %), acetone (C 3 H 6 O, AR, 98 %), copper chloride hydrate (CuCl 2 2H 2 O, AR, 99 %), methanol (CH 4 O, AR, 99 %), acetic acid (C 2 H 4 O 2 , AR, 99 %) and aromatics were provided by Sinopharm Group Chemical Reagents Co., ltd.Preparation of UiO-66 UiO-66 was synthesized as follows[32]: 33.4 mg ZrCl 4 and 25 mg H 2 BDC in 10 mL DMF were stirred for 1 h. Then 0.7 mL of CH 3 COOH was added to the above solution and ultrasonicated for 15 min to disperse the solution. The obtained solution was placed in a 20 mL Teﬂon-lined autoclave reactor and kept at 120 °C for one day. After the reaction was completed, the resulted solution was cooled down to room temperature. Finally, the solid white powder was collected by centrifugation (8000 rpm for 10 min) and washed with DMF and acetone three times to remove impurities, then dried under the vacuum condition at 120 °C overnight to obtain UiO-66.

2.2. Preparation of the samples The UiO-66 was synthesized following a previously described method[36]. Brieﬂy, 0.131 g of ZrCl 4 , 0.190 g of C 8 H 6 O 4 , 82 mL of DMF and 5 mL of CH 3 COOH were added to a beaker and treated with ultrasonic stirring for 40 min until the solids in the beaker had been completely dissolved. Then the mixture was transferred into a hydrothermal vessel and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. After natural cooling to room temperature, the as-obtained white suspension was separated with a centrifuge and washed 3 times with anhydrous methanol.

2. Experimental 2.1. Materials Zirconium tetrachloride (ZrCl 4 ), 1, 4-benzendicarboxylic acid (H 2 BDC), indium nitrate (In(NO 3 ) 3 ·xH 2 O), sodium sulﬁde (Na 2 S·9H 2 O), acetic acid and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) were commercially available and used as received.2.2. Synthesis 2.2.1. Synthesis of UiO-66 UiO-66 were ﬁrst synthesized through a solvothermal route [30].Typically, 1.0 mmol ZrCl 4 and 1.0 mmol 1, 4-benzendicarboxylic acid (H 2 BDC) were dissolved in 100 mL N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), then 23 mL of acetic acid was added into the solution to tune the morphology of UiO-66. After stirring for 30 min, the obtained homogeneous solution was then transferred into Teﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 120 ℃ for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the white products were collected by centrifugation, washed with deionized (DI) water and ethanol for three times and then dried at 60 ℃ in the vacuum drying oven for 6 h.

2.2. Synthesis of adsorbents The synthesis of UiO-66 and NH 2 -UiO-66 was conducted according to the procedure reported by Cavka et al. [58], with a small modiﬁcation. In brief, 2 mmol of ZrCl 4 , 4 mmol of H 2 BDC, 2 mmol of HCl, and 50 mL of DMF were added to a Teﬂon-lined autoclave (volume: 100 mL) and heated in an electric oven for 24 h at 120 °C. For the synthesis of NH 2 -UiO-66, the same molar amount of NH 2 -BDC was used in replace of H 2 BDC. After the synthesis, the resulting solid was ﬁltered and puriﬁed with DMF (1 g of the MOF in 50 mL of DMF and heated at 150 °C for 5 h). After the puriﬁcation process, the products were dried in a vacuum oven at 150 °C for 12 h. The synthesis of SO 3 H-UiO-66 was conducted according to the solvothermal synthetic route reported by Foo et al. [63]. In brief, 1.13 mmol of ZrCl 4 , 0.93 mmol of H 2 BDC, and 0.20 mmol of NaSO 3 H-BDC were added to a Teﬂon-lined autoclave (volume: 100 mL), and 50 mL of a mixture of solvents (ratio of DMF to acetic acid = 9:1 (v/v)) was added. The mixture was stirred for 10 min and heated at 120 °C for 40 h in an electric oven. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting white solid was separated by centrifugation and washed three times with DMF. Finally, the sample was washed again with acetone and dried in a vacuum oven. Syntheses methods of other MOFs (MIL-101(Cr) and MIL100(Al, Ce, Fe)) were described in the supporting information.

The pristine UiO-66 and the functionalized UiO-66 with free – COOH (named UiO-66-COOH) were synthesized by conventional electric heating, following a protocol previously reported [46].The detailed process for UiO-66synthesis is as follows: ZrCl 4 (1.129 g), TPA (1.626 g), HCl (1.009 g), and DMF (27.04 g) were mixed in a beaker. Then, the mixture, with a molar ratio of 1:2:2:76 (ZrCl 4 :TPA:HCl:DMF) was transferred to a 100 mL Teﬂon-lined autoclave and heated at 180 °C in an electric oven for 24 h. The solid product was recovered by ﬁltration, washed with DMF, and dried (24 h, 30 °C) under vacuum.

2. Materials and methods 2.1. MOF syntheses UiO-66 were synthesized and puriﬁed according to the published procedure [44]. ZrCl 4 (4 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H 2 BDC, 8 mmol) were fully dissolved in a mixed solution of N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF) (24 ml) and concentrated HCl (0.67 ml). The obtained solution was sealed in a 50 ml Teﬂon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 220 °C for 16 h. After cooling the vessel, white powders were obtained. The resulting solid was then ﬁltered and puriﬁed with DMF and EtOH at room temperature several times. The functionalized UiO-66-X (X = NO 2 ,NH 2 , Cl, Br, I, Br 2 ) compounds were synthesized and puriﬁed through the same methods except for replacing the original BDC ligand with functionalized BDC ligands of equivalent molar amounts.

(Pyeongtaek, Korea). All starting materials and solvents were used without further puriﬁcation.2.2. Synthesis MOF materials UiO-66 and UiO-66-NH 2 were prepared according to published procedures [42], without signiﬁcant modiﬁcation. An 8-dram vial was loaded with ZrCl 4 (125 mg, 0.54 mmol), DMF (15 mL), concentrated HCl (1.00 mL), and the ligands BDC (123 mg, 0.75 mmol) or BDC-NH 2 (134 mg, 0.75 mmol). The mixture was sonicated for 60 min, before being heated at 120 °C for 24 h. The resultant solid was then ﬁltered, and washed ﬁ rst with DMF (4 × 5 mL), and then with EtOH (4 × 5 mL) for several hours to remove all residual solvent. The resultant solid was freeze-dried for further characterization and adsorption experiments.

2.2. Preparation of N-doped N X -UiO-66 N X -UiO-66 were prepared via “one-pot mechanochemical” approach. 4.0 mmol of ZrCl 4 and an equivalent amount of linker (H 2 BDC), along with 0.3 mL of acetic acid and 1.2 mL of methanol were added to a stainless-steel jar. Then, 0.12 mmol of dopamine, pyrrole or 2-methylimidazol were added into 1.2 mL methanol, and transferred into the jar and ground for 30 min at 50 Hz. These samples were denoted as N D UiO-66, N P -UiO-66 and N I -UiO-66 representing dopamine, pyrrole and 2-methylimidazol versions respectively. For comparison, pristine UiO66 without N-doping was also synthesized via similar procedure. The prepared products were centrifuged and successively washed with DMF and methanol for three times followed by air drying at 393 K for 10 h and then in vacuum oven at 393 K for 12 h for further activation.

UiO-66 octahedrons were solvothermally synthesized following the procedure reported in previous report [24]. The solutions of 40.0 mg ZrCl 4 and 28.5 mg H 2 bdc (benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid) dissolved in 5.0 mL DMF (N,N-dimethylformamide) were mixed completely, in which 3.0 mL acetic acid was added to regulate the UiO-66 ′s morphology. The matrix was transferred into a 25.0 mL teﬂon-lined bomb, followed by being heated at 120 °C for 24 h. Finally, the UiO-66 samples were obtained via centrifugation after cooling to ambient temperature.

2.2. Synthesis of UiO-66 The UiO-66 used in this research was prepared by using the improved method according to the literature [1]. Typically, 233.2 mg ZrCl 4 and 166.1 mg BDC were added in the 50 mL DMF, the obtained mixture solution was then moved to a 100 mL Teﬂon-liner stainless steel autoclave at 120 °C for 48 h. After cooling to room temperature, the white slurry of UiO-66 were harvested by centrifugation and washed with methanol. Finally, the obtained white powders were dried under vacuum at 80 °C for 24 h.2.3. Synthesis of NC The white powders of UiO-66 were placed in a tube furnace and annealed at diﬀerent temperatures (400, 600, 800 and 1000 °C) for 2 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min under a ﬂowing N 2 atmosphere. After cooling back to room temperature naturally, the obtained samples were added into 30 mL 2.8 M HF, and this solution was shaken for 6 h. Then the mixture was centrifuged to extract particles at the bottom and washed to neutral by deionized water. Finally, NC samples were obtained by freezing drying for 24 h. A series of NC samples obtained at diﬀerent temperatures were named as NC-400, NC-600, NC-800 and NC-1000.

The MOFs were prepared using the reported hydrothermal method with a little modiﬁcation[46–49]. For the synthesis of UiO-66, 15 mM of ZrCl 4 and 15 mM of H 2 BDC was ultrasonically dissolved in 155 mL of DMF. Then, the mixture was poured into a 250 mL Telfon-lined autoclave, which then was placed into an oven at 393.15 K for 24 h. The obtained precipitate was washed three times with DMF and then three times with ethanol through being resuspended and centrifuged by using a centrifuge (9000 rpm for 15 min). The precipitate was then dried at 353.15 K under vacuum for 20 h. At last, the dried samples were ground and stored. Diﬀerent kind of linkers and modulators, as shown in L. Wang, et al.

UiO-66 was synthesized based on a reported procedure [21].
Typically, 5.94 mmol of ZrCl 4 dissolved in a DMF-HCl mixture prepared by adding 11 ml of c.HCl to 55 ml of DMF in 250 ml beaker.
BDC (8.25 mmol) was added to another 250 ml beaker containing 110 ml of DMF. The solutions in the two beakers were sonicated for 20 min until all chemicals were dissolved. Thereafter, the solutions were mixed together in a 500 ml capacity glass vessel and sealed.
The vessel was heated at 80  C for 15 h. The white solid product obtained was washed three times with DMF and separated by centrifugation at 7000 rpm. Thereafter, the as-synthesized UiO-66 was soaked in CH 3 OH for 48 h to allow the exchange of entrapped DMF with CH 3 OH. The product was dried in a vacuum oven at 100  C overnight and used for further characterizations.

Terephthalic acid (H 2 BDC, 98%) was purchased from Sinapharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. All chemicals were analytically pure and used as received without further puriﬁcation.2.1.1. Synthesis of UiO-66 In a typical experiment, a 15 mL DMF solution of H 2 BDC (0.13 mmol) was mixed with ZrCl 4 (0.13 mmol), PVP (10 mg), and HAc (20 μL) at room temperature. The mixture was transferred into a 25 mL Teﬂon-lined autoclave, which was sealed and kept at 120 °C for 24 h.The reaction vessel was then removed from the oven and allowed to cool to room temperature. The resulting product was isolated by centrifugation, washed ﬁve times with DMF, and dried in vacuum at 120 °C for 4 h.

2.2. Fabrication of Mn-doped UiO-66 The Mn-doped UiO-66 adsorbent was fabricated through a facile solvothermal process. In detail, H 2 BDC, ZrCl 4 , MnCl 2 ·4H 2 O and DMF were mixed in a breaker with a molar ratio of 1:1:1:162. The solution was magnetic stirred for 1 h to get a clear solution and then placed in a 100 mL Teﬂon liner. The solvothermal process was carried out at 120 °C for 24 h. The obtained precipitates were centrifuged and washed with DMF (removal of redundant H 2 BDC) and ethanol (removal of residual DMF). At last, the products were vacuum dried at 60 °C. Moreover, the pristine UiO-66 was fabricated without MnCl 2 ·4H 2 O on the basis of the above method.

2.2. Synthesis of materials UiO-66. The UiO-66 was prepared via solvothermal method according to procedures reported with some modiﬁcations [18]. Brieﬂy, 0.54 mmol of ZrCl 4 , 0.75 mmol of H 2 BDC, 15 mL of DMF and 1 mL of concentrated HCl were fully mixed under ultrasonic treatment for 60 min, and the mixture was then transferred into a Teﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The reaction was conducted at 120 °C for 24 h in an electric oven. The resulting white solid was collected and washed with ethanol and ultrapure water for several times. Finally, the assynthesized material was dried overnight in a vacuum oven.

In the preparation of UiO-66 [28,29], 0.265 g (1.14 mmol) ZrCl 4 and 0.189 g (1.14 mmol) H 2 BDC were dissoved in 20 mL of DMF, and then heated in a Teﬂon lined autoclave at 120 °C for 36 h. The as-obtained precipitates were centrifuged at 10,000 rpm, and immersed in methanol and THF for 3–5 h respectively, and then dried under vacuum.

Zirconium tetrachloride (ZrCl 4 , 98%), potassium  bromide  (KBr,  98.5%),  glacial  acetic  acid  (>99%),  toluene  (99.5%),  acetone (≥99%) were provided by Merck Life Science Pvt.Ltd. Mumbai,  India.  Polyvinylpyrrolidone  K30  (PVP,  Mw  = 55,000,  90%)  was  obtained  from  Spectrochem  Pvt.Ltd.  Mumbai,  India.  N,  N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99%), 2-methylfuran (98%) were purchased from  Avra  chemicals  Pvt.Ltd.  Hyderabad,  India.  potassium  chloride  (KCl,  99.5%) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H 2 BDC, 98%) were procured  from NICE chemicals and Alfa Aesar respectively. All the chemicals were  used as obtained without purication.  2.2. Synthetic procedures  2.2.1. Synthesis of UiO-66(Hf) MOF  Microcrystalline UiO-66(Hf) MOF material was synthesized via solvothermal method with slight modication in the reported procedure  [66]. Typically, HfCl 4  (208 mg, 0.65 mmol) and H 2 BDC (108 mg, 0.65  mmol) were added to a teon-lined reactor (50 mL) followed by the  addition of DMF (8.3 mL) &  formic acid (2.17 mL). This mixture was  stirred for 15 min to facilitate the complete dissolution of the precursors.  Then the reactor was sealed and placed in an oven maintained at 120  ◦ C  for 48 h. Thereafter, the reactor was allowed to cool to room temperature (RT). The microcrystalline powder of UiO-66(Hf) was isolated from  the  reaction  mixture  by  centrifugation  &  washed  thoroughly  using  acetone to remove the residual reactants. Subsequently, the collected  powdered material was dried under vacuum.  2.2.2. Synthesis of UiO-66(Zr) MOF  The UiO-66(Zr) was synthesized by solvothermal method. Typically,  222.7 mg of ZrCl 4  (0.955 mmol) and 166.7 mg H 2 BDC (1 mmol) were  added to a 100 mL screw capped bottle followed by the addition of 66.6  mL of DMF solvent and 4.66 mL of acetic acid. The mixture was sonicated for 10 min to  aid the complete  dispersion of precursors in the  solvent. Then the bottle was sealed and kept in a pre-heated oven at  100  ◦ C for  24 h. After completion of  the reaction, the screw  capped  bottle was removed from the oven and allowed to cool to RT. Later, the  supernatant was decanted and the UiO-66(Zr) MOF was isolated from  the mixture by centrifugation. Then, the obtained material was washed  with DMF and methanol twice (15 mL each), and dried under the vacuum at RT.  2.2.3. Synthesis of Pd nanoparticles (Pd-NPs)  Pd-NPs were synthesized by following the reported procedure [67].  At rst, the aqueous solution of Pd precursor was prepared by dissolving  228  mg  (0.77  mmol)  of  Na 2 PdCl 4  in  12  mL  distilled  water.  Then,  a  mixture of 420 mg (3.85 mmol) of PVP, 300 mg (2.52 mmol) of KBr, 240  mg (1.36 mmol) of  L-ascorbic acid, and 564 mg (7.56 mmol) of KCl were  added to a 100 mL round-bottom ask containing 32 mL of distilled  water.  This  mixture  is  heated  at  80  ◦ C  under  constant  stirring  and  maintained at this temperature for 10 min. Subsequently, the dropwise  addition of Pd(II) precursor solution to the above clear solution is performed under constant stirring (within 10 min). Further, the reaction is  allowed to proceed for 3h at 80  ◦ C to facilitate the formation of Pd NPs.  Later,  the  colloidal  system  containing  Pd  NPs  was  cooled  and  the  nanoparticles were isolated by centrifugation. The obtained product was  washed with excess of acetone and distilled water. The washed nanoparticles were dried at RT under vacuum.  2.2.4. Synthesis of Pd nanoparticles supported on UiO-66(Hf) MOF [Pd/  UiO-66(Hf)]  In a typical synthesis, 20 mg of Pd-NPs were added to 10 mL of DMF  and it is sonicated for 15 min to make uniform distribution of NPs. Later,  380 mg of activated (vacuum dried) UiO-66(Hf) sample was added to  the Pd-NPs solution and stirred vigorously for 2h at RT. Afterwards, this  reaction mixture was centrifuged to collect the catalytic material. Then,  the obtained product was washed thoroughly with excess of acetone,  dried under vacuum at RT, and designated as Pd/UiO-66 (Hf).  2.2.5. Synthesis of core-shell Pd@UiO-66(Hf) material  In a typical procedure, HfCl 4  (208 mg, 0.65 mmol) and H 2 BDC (108  mg, 0.65 mmol) were added to a vial (30 mL) containing DMF (8.3 mL)  & formic acid (2.17 mL). This mixture was stirred for 15 min to get the  clear solution of precursors. Then 8 mg of Pd-NPs were weighed and  transferred to the above solution and sonicated for 15 min to facilitate  the dispersion. Later, this dispersed solution was transferred to a teon-  lined reactor (50 mL). The reactor containing the solution was sealed  and heated at 120  ◦ C in an oven for 48 h. Thereafter, the reactor was  allowed to cool to RT. The microcrystalline powder was isolated from  the reaction mixture by centrifugation & thoroughly washed ve times  with acetone (30 mL each) to remove the residual reactants. Finally, the  collected material was dried under vacuum and designated as Pd@UiO-  66(Hf).  2.2.6. Synthesis of Pd@UiO-66(Zr) material  In a typical procedure, 222.7 mg of ZrCl 4  (0.955 mmol), 166.7 mg  H 2 BDC (1 mmol), and 4.66 mL of acetic acid were taken in a 100 mL  screw capped bottle. Subsequently, 66.6 mL of DMF solvent was added  and this mixture was sonicated for about 10 min to aid the dispersion of  precursors. To the above solution, 14 mg of as-synthesized Pd NPs were  added and again sonicated for 15 min. Later, the screw-capped bottle  containing black coloured solution was placed in a pre-heated oven at  100  ◦ C for 24 h. On completion of the reaction, the bottle was taken out  and allowed  to  cool  to  RT. Further,  the  obtained  solid  material  was  collected  by  decanting  the  supernatant  followed  by  centrifugation.  Then, the material was washed with DMF and methanol twice (15 mL  each) followed  by drying under  vacuum at RT. Finally, the obtained  material was designated as Pd@UiO-66(Zr).  2.3. Characterization  The Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the materials were  collected on the Bruker D2 Phaser diffractometer. The PXRD patterns of  the samples were recorded using Cu-K α  radiation (λ = 1.542 Å) in the 2θ  range of 5 ◦ –90 ◦ (step increment of 0.02 ◦ & at the rate of 0.3 Sec step − 1 ).  The BET specic surface area (SSA), pore size (PS) distribution, and pore  volume (PV) were measured using Belsorb (II) mini-instrument (BEL,  Japan). The N 2  sorption analysis was performed using liquid-N 2  at 77K  temperature. Prior to the measurements, samples were outgassed for 10  h  at  150  ◦ C  under  vacuum.  X-ray  photoelectron  spectroscopy  (XPS)  spectra of the materials were acquired on ULVAC PHI/PHI5000 Versa  Probell instrument with monochromatic Al K α  radiation of 1486.6 eV  photon energy and X-ray spot size of 100  μ m. The low resolution survey  spectra  were  collected  with  187.85  eV  pass  energy  and  later  high-  resolution scans for each element were recorded. The binding energies  of each element in the materials were calibrated by taking C 1s peak at  284.5 eV as a reference. The actual Pd content in MOF catalysts were  measured  by  ICP-OES  (Inductively  coupled  plasma-optical  emission  spectroscopy) analysis using PerkinElmer Optima 7000 DV instrument.  The thermal  stability of the  pristine  MOF and hybrid materials  were  determined by TGA (Thermogravimetric analysis) analysis on a PerkinElmer, STA6000  instrument. Analyses were  performed  under N 2  atmosphere  with  20  mL  min − 1  ow  rate  in  the  temperature  range  of  30–800  ◦ C with 10  ◦ C min − 1  ramp rate. The HR-TEM (high-resolution  transmission  electron  microscopy)  images  were  recorded  on  a  JEOL  JEM-2100 PLUS electron microscope at the operating voltage of 200 kV.  The acidic properties of the MOFs and hybrid materials were determined  by  NH 3 -TPD  (NH 3 - temperature  programmed  reduction)  measurements using Belcat II (BEL Japan) instrument. Firstly, prior to the  measurements, around 50 mg of the sample was mounted in a quartz U-  tube and pre-treated at 200  ◦ C for 2 h in a helium (He) atmosphere.  Later, the sample was cooled to 50  ◦ C, which was subsequently ushed  with 10% NH 3 /He for 30 min. The physisorbed NH 3  was removed at  B.B. Kulkarni et al.

Pebax®  MH  1657  were  from  Shanghai  Rongtian  Chemical  Co.,  Ltd  (China).1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC, 99%) were from  Adamus  Reagent Co., Ltd (China). Deionized water is made by Milli-Q system. All  the experimental drugs mentioned above were used directly after purchase without special treatment.  2.2. Fabrication of UIO-66  UIO-66 synthesis was consistent with previous report [45]. First, 1  mL  of  ZrOCl 2 •8H 2 O  solution  (DMF,  30  mM)  was  added  to  a  round-bottomed ask and placed in an oil bath at 393 K. Then 50 mL  ZrOCl 2 •8H 2 O stock solution (DMF, 30 mM) and 50 mL BDC stock solution (DMF/formic acid = 9/1, 30 mM) were prepared and pumped  into a round-bottom ask at a feeding rate of 15 mL/h. After the reaction, UIO-66 was obtained through centrifugation, followed by washing  with DMF and ethanol for 3 times successively, in turn, and nally dried  under vacuum (363 K, 18 h).  2.3. Fabrication of MIL-88B (MIL-88(Fe))  MIL-88B  synthesis  was  consistent  with  previous  reports  [35,46].  First,  1,4-benzenedicarboxylic  acid  (132.9  mg,  0.80  mmol)  was  dissolved in 8 mL DMF. Fe(NO 3 )•9H 2 O (323.2 mg, 0.80 mmol) was dissolved in 4 mL DMF. The two solutions were then mixed and 12 mL of  CH 3 CN was added. The  resulting  mixture was dissolved at 363K and  reacted  for  5h.  After  the  reaction,  MIL-88B  was  obtained  through  centrifugation, followed by washing with DMF and ethanol for 5 times  successively, in turn, and nally dried under vacuum (353 K, 24 h).  2.4. Fabrication of MIL-88B-on-UIO-66 (UIO@MIL)  MIL-88B-on-UIO-66 (Hereinafter referred to as UIO@MIL) synthesis  was consistent with previous report [35]. First, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic  acid (99.7 mg, 0.6 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL DMF. Fe(NO 3 )•9H 2 O  (242.4 mg, 0.6 mmol) was dissolved in 3 mL DMF. The two solutions  were then mixed and 9 mL CH 3 CN and 2 mL DMF containing 43 mg  UIO-66  were  successively  added.  After  ultrasonic  dispersion,  the  obtained  mixed  solution  reacts  at  363K  for  5h.  After  the  reaction,  MIL-88B-on-UIO-66 was obtained through centrifugation, followed by  washing with DMF and ethanol for 5 times successively, in turn, and  nally dried under vacuum (353 K, 24 h).  2.5. Fabrication of the Pebax/UIO@MIL membranes  The  UIO@MIL  nanoparticles  were  dispersed  in  4.5  mL  absolute  ethanol solution, and a uniform suspension was obtained by ultrasonic  treatment. The mixture solution of 4 wt% Pebax 1657 (the mass ratio of  water to ethanol was 3:7) was prepared by reux stirring at 80  ◦ C for 2 h.  Fig. 3. Brieﬂy, ZrCl 4 (0.178 g, 0.765 mM), BDC (0.127 g, 0.765 mM) and PVP (0.3 g, MW 40 k) were dissolved in 10.5 mL DMF, 4.3 mL acetic acid and 6.0 mL alcohol mixed solution under ultrasonication. After dissolved thoroughly, a certain amount of 0.025 g mL −1 H 2 PtCl 6 solution (0.3, 0.6 or 1.2 mL) was added. Then, the mixture was transferred to a Teﬂon-lined autoclave and treated at 120 °C for 24 h without stirring. The product was collected by centrifugation and washed with acetone three times. After that, the obtained crystal was stirred in DMF for 12 h and in methanol for 24 h at room temperature to remove unreacted linker. Finally, the sample was dried under vacuum at 65 °C overnight.
Pure UiO-66 was synthesized following the same procedure as above expect for not adding H 2 PtCl 6 and alcohol solution.

2.2. UiO-66 adsorbent preparation The adsorbent was prepared following the rapid solvothermal synthesis reported in the previous work (Bae et al., 2018) by dissolving 0.00106 kg zirconium (IV) chloride (ZrCl 4 ) and 0.00003 m 3 dimethylformamide (DMF). Approximately 0.00078 kg of 1,4 benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) was dissolved with 0.00003 m 3 DMF at room temperature in a volumetric ﬂask. The two solutions were mixed together with 2 ml de-ionized water and placed in an oil bath at 393.15 K for 1800 s. After the solution was cooled down to room temperature in air for 7200 s, the resulting precipitate was ﬁltered and washed repeatedly with absolute ethanol for 3 times before being dried at 343.15 K overnight.

These MOFs were prepared according to reported methods with some changes [30–35].UiO-66 was prepared by dissolving 125 mg of ZrCl 4 and 123 mg of H 2 BDC in 15 mL DMF. The mixture was sonicated for15 min and 1 mL of HCl was then added and again sonicated for 15 min, then transferred into a closed Teﬂon vial and heated at 80 °C for overnight, then autoclave was cooling down to room temperature, the precipitate were collected by centrifugation, washed with ethanol thrice, ﬁltered, dried at 60 °C and then activated at 150 °C. UiO-66-NH 2 was synthesized by putting 127 mg of ZrCl 4 and 134 mg of H 2 BDC-NH 2 acid in 15 mL DMF.The rest of the preparation method was similar to that of UiO-66 [30].The details of synthesis method of other selected water stable MOFs can be found in Supplementary portion S1.

3. Methods 3.1. Material synthesis UiO-66 crystals were prepared by hydrothermal method [9,15]. The metal nodes of UiO-66 are Zr, so ZrCl 4 was used as metal side of crystals. 3 mmol of ZrCl 4 was weighed and put into a beaker. The organic linker side of UiO-66 is terephtalic acid. Same amount of terephtalic acid was weighed, and put into the beaker. This solid mixture was dissolved in DMF. Concentrated HCl solution was chosen as acid modulator, and 2 mL of HCl (37 %) solution was added to the mixture.

2.3. Synthesis of UiO-66 UiO-66 was synthesized by hydrothermal method. To this end, 75 ml DMF was mixed with 1.8 g ZrCl 4 and this solution was sonicated for 0.5 h. Then, 150 ml DMF was mixed with 1.8 g H 2 BDC which was then put into a 300 mL Teﬂon lined stainless-steel autoclave in which the reactions were carried out at 120 °C for 24 h. Afterwards, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature and the product was separated from the mother liquor. In the next step, washing of the resulting product by DMF and methanol was done for several times, followed by drying at 100 °C for 24 h.

2.2. Synthesis of UiO-66 and N 2 -UiO-66 In a typical synthesis procedure of UiO-66, 0.3 M Terephthalic acid was added to 30 mL of DMF under continuous stirring and the resulting solution was named as solution A. Then 0.3 M Zirconium chloride was added to 10 mL DMF under continuous stirring and the resulting solution was named as solution B. The solution B was then added to solution A and the mixture was kept under continuous stirring for about an hour. The mixture was transferred to a Teflon lined autoclave which was then kept inside an oven at 120 ◦ C for 48 h. The autoclave was then removed from the oven and allowed to cool to room temperature. In the autoclave, formation of powdered material was observed. The obtained material was washed with DMF and methanol to increase its crystallinity and then dried in an oven at 150 ◦ C to remove residual linker (Tambat et al., 2018).

2.2. Material synthesis 2.2.1. Synthesis of UiO-66 [Zr 6 O 4 (OH) 4 (BDC) 6 ] nanocrystal Brieﬂy, ZrCl 4 (0.265 g) and BDC (0.188 g) were dissolved in a mixed solvent of DMF and acetic acid (45 mL/5 mL) and sonicated at room temperature until a clear solution was formed. The mixture was then transferred into a glass bottle and heated at 120  C for 48 h. After naturally cooling down, the white precipitate was separated from the mixture solution by centrifugation and washed several times by DMF and ethanol. Then, the as-synthesized product was dried at 80  C in an oven. The white powder of UiO66 nanocrystal was obtained afterward.

2.2. Synthesis of UIO-66 UIO-66 was prepared according to the previous report [43] with a little modiﬁcation. Typically, 233 mg ZrCl 4 , 166 mg H 2 BDC, 45 mL DMF, and 5 mL acetic acid were loaded into a 100 mL stainless steel Teﬂon-lined autoclave, which was then heated at 120  C for 24 h.UIO-66 precipitate was collected by centrifuging, washed three times separately with DMF, deionized water and methanol, and dried by heating at 100  C in a vacuum. The dried UIO-66 powder was activated at 200  C in a vacuum. The activated UIO-66 powder was conserved in an Ar glovebox (H 2 O, O 2 < 0.1 ppm) for further use.

Solvent  N,N’-dimethylformamide  (DMF) (99.9%) was  purchased  from  VWR  Chemicals.  Ethanol  (99.9%)  and  2-propanol  (99.8%)  were  both  purchased  from  Anhui Fulltime. Synthesis of DUT-52, UiO-66, and MOF-808  DUT-52 was prepared solvothermally according to a published procedure [34], with a slight modication. Zirconium(IV) chloride (1.07 g,  4.6 mmol) was dissolved in 40 mL DMF under a nitrogen atmosphere. An  organic linker of H 2 NDC (0.99 g, 4.6 mmol) was added to the mixture  and stirred at room temperature (28  ◦ C) until the solution was clear.  Afterward, HCl 1,2 M (0.4 mL) was added to the mixture. The mixture  was placed in 100 mL Schott glass and heated at 120  ◦ C for 20 h at  ambient  pressure.  The  obtained  solid  was  ltered and washed  three  times with DMF (15 mL) and ethanol (5 mL) to remove the unreacted  linker.  The  powder  was  immersed  in  25  mL  of  chloroform  at  room  temperature  for  4  h,  and  the  solvent  was  replaced  twice.  The  solid  powder was dried at 120  ◦ C for 30 min in the oven, resulting in white  powders of MOF (1.83 g). Finally, the MOF was reheated at 140  ◦ C for 6  h under N 2  ow to remove the remaining guest molecules from pores  before  catalytic  tests.  Other  MOFs,  i.e.,  UiO-66  and  MOF-808,  were  synthesized  according  to  published  methods  [32,53]  with  a  slight  modication in UiO-66, i.e., by adding a concentrated HCl (2 equimolar  of ZrCl 4 ). After the precipitate was formed, a drying process and solvent  replacement  by  chloroform  were  employed.  Formations  of  MOFs  structures were conrmed by powder x-ray diffraction (PXRD). MOFs  were  then  reheated at 140  ◦ C  for  6 h under N 2  ow  to  remove the  trapped solvent. DUT-52 was also prepared in modied forms, i.e., by  reuxing DUT-52 for 6 h in methanol (65  ◦ C) and 2-propanol (80  ◦ C),  respectively. The one reuxed in methanol was labeled DUT-52_MeOH,  while one reuxed in 2-propanol was labeled DUT-52_IPA. The amount  of Zr in the MOF was calculated using a gravimetric method (Supplementary Material, Table S2 &  S3), i.e. 0.1 g of MOF was calcined at  600  ◦ C for 6 h to give ZrO 2  [54]. Formations of ZrO 2  and its phases (i.e.,  monoclinic or tetragonal ZrO 2 ) were conrmed by PXRD. The number of  ZrO 2  was taken as a representation of the mole of Zr in the MOF per  initial mass.  Characterizations  Synthesized Zr-MOFs, recycled Zr-MOFs, and calcined Zr-MOFs were  characterized by PXRD (Rigaku Miniex600, Cu K α  with D/teX ultra 1-D  detector, operated at 40 kV and 15 mA) and Fourier transform infrared  (FTIR; Bruker Alpha with ZnSe beam splitter and 2 cm − 1  resolution).  XRD patterns were recorded at 2θ of 3− 60  ◦ , with a step width of 0.02  ◦ and scanning speed of 10  ◦ min − 1 . Estimated pore diameters and surface  areas of the MOFs were obtained from N 2  physisorption isotherms at 77  K (Micromeritics). For FTIR measurement, samples were immersed in  potassium  bromide  powder  with  a  KBr  background  correction  and  measured for 16 scans.  Computational details  Computational  calculations  were  performed  by  using  an  approximate density-functional theory method, i.e., the extended tight-binding  (xTB) method [55–58]. The method was sufciently accurate to describe  many organometallic systemsand MOFs as calculated by the Grimme  group, with the margin error of only 4 kcal/mol [58]. Calculations of  such a system by DFT/B3LYP-D3 have been reported to result in a larger  error margin of 6 kcal/mol [58]. Initial structures were optimized at the  second  generation  xTB  method,  namely,  GFN2-xTB  that  utilizes  the  approximate  Slater  functions,  polarization  functions,  as  well  as  describing hypervalent states [57]. The DUT-52 and UiO-66 frameworks  were modeled as cluster structures as adopted from our previous work  [40]. The adopted  DUT-52  and UiO-66 structures  were  optimized at  GFN2-xTB level. During the geometry optimizations, all zirconium and  terminal oxygen atoms  in the carboxylic  groups were constrained  to  retain the framework environment. The initial 2-propanol structure was  optimized  under  the  same  computational  condition.  The  optimized  structure was added to DUT-52 and UiO-66 frameworks. To facilitate an  electron pair donation from 2-propanol, a linker from each MOF was  rstly removed, providing a molecular SBU with 11-coordination.  The enthalpy and Gibbs free energies of all optimized structures were  obtained by performing numerical Hessian calculations at the GFN2-xTB  level.  Temperatures  of  298.15  and  413.15  K  were  used  for  thermochemical  properties  calculation.  The  evaluation  of  Lewis  acidity  of  adjacent Zr atoms to the one coordinated by 2-propanol was done by  electrostatic  potential  (ESP)  charges  and  Wiberg  bond  order  (WBO)  calculations at the GFN2-xTB level.  Catalytic test and product analysis  In a typical procedure, DUT-52 (75 mg, 6 mol% of Zr(IV)), FALD  (0.29 g, 3 mmol), 2-propanol (10 mL), and naphthalene (0.064 g, 0.5  mmol)  as  an  internal  standard  were  placed  in  a  50  mL  Teon-lined  stainless steel autoclave. The mixture was stirred (500 rpm) and heated at the desired temperature for a specic time. After the reaction, solid  and liquid phases were separated using a centrifuge (1000 rpm for 30  minutes).  The  used  catalyst  was  rinsed  three  times  thoroughly  with  ethanol (30 mL) and dried at 120  ◦ C for 30 min for a recycle test. FOL  products and remaining  FALD  were analyzed using  Perkin-Elmer  GC  with a ame ionization detector (FID) and an SGE EN5MS (5% optimized  silphenylene)  capillary  column  (30  m  x  0.25  mm  x  0.5  μ m).  Injector and detector were set at 250  ◦ C and 275  ◦ C, respectively. The  oven temperature was set at 100  ◦ C for 2 min, then raised to 105  ◦ C at a  rate of 0.5  ◦ C/min for 1 min and from 105  ◦ C to 170  ◦ C at a rate of 15  ◦ C/  min for 2 min. FALD conversions and FOL yields were determined by  calibration curves, using naphthalene as an internal standard (Supplementary Material, Fig. S1). The obtained FOL was also conrmed by  1 H-  NMR  (60  MHz;  Nanalysis  NMReady-60e)  with  CDCl 3  as  a  d-solvent.  Possible byproducts were conrmed by GC-FID using authentic samples  of THFA, 2-MF, 1,2-PeD, and 1,5-PeD.  Result and discussion  Synthesis and Characterization of Catalysts  Zr-MOFs  of  DUT-52,  UiO-66,  and  MOF-808  were  prepared  solvothermally  in  DMF  at  120  ◦ C  for  20  to  48  h.  They  were  initially  reheated at 140  ◦ C for 6 h under N 2  ow before catalytic evaluations to  optimize the accessibility of FALD into MOFs pores.  DUT-52,  UiO-66,  and MOF-808 were characterized by  PXRD  and  compared with their simulated single-crystal patterns. The 2θ values of  DUT-52 are similar to its simulated pattern, represented by d 111  and d 200  reections at 6.4  ◦ and 7.4  ◦ , respectively (Fig. 1a). PXRD patterns of  UiO-66 and MOF-808 depicted typical 2θ  values at 7.3  ◦ and 8.5  ◦ for  UiO-66  and  8.3  ◦ and  8.7  ◦ for  MOF-808  (Supplementary  Material,  Fig. S2). FTIR spectrum of DUT-52 is given in Fig 1b compared to its  organic linker (H 2 NDC). Coordinated-carboxylate at DUT-52 showed a  weaker  C=O  vibration  (1565  cm − 1 )  than  its  free  one  (1685  cm − 1 ;  Fig. 1b.), indicating a weakened-bond order at carbonyl moiety after  metal-linker  coordination.  Analogous  phenomena  were  observed  in  UiO-66 and MOF-808  (Supplementary Material, Fig. S3.). Zirconium-  oxygen  vibrations  of  oxo-hydroxo  ligands  of  Zr  in  SBUs  of  K.D. Agusta et al.

UiO-66(Ce) was synthesized according to the method reported previously [29]. 35.4 mg (0.213 mmol) H 2 BDC was introduced to the glass  reactor with 1.2 mL DMF, then 400  μ L 0.53 M aqueous solution of Ce  (NH 4 ) 2 (NO 3 ) 6 . The obtained white powder  was  collected  and  quickly  washed  three  times  with  fresh  DMF  and  further dried at 60  ◦ C. UiO-66-(OH) 2  was synthesized according to the  method  reported  previously [31]. 125 mg (0.75 mmol) ZrCl 4  and 147 mg (0.75 mmol)  H 2 BDC-(OH) 2  and 1.0  mL  concentrated  HCl  was  dissolved  in  15  mL  DMF, the mixture was  ultrasonicated  until  fully  dissolved  and  transferred to 8-dram vial, sealed and heated at 100  ◦ C for 8 h. After the  reaction was completed, the product was centrifuged and washed with  DMF and methanol at least three times, respectively. The white solid  powder was collected after vacuum drying at 60  ◦ C.  Characterizations  Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded on Bruker  D8 Advance with Cu K α  radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) operating at 40 kV and  40 mA. The  morphology and the composition of MOFs were characterized using an  SEM instrument (Nova 200 NanoSEM) coupled with an EDX detector. 29,  31,  52-53  Stock solutions for  the  MOF  reagents  were  prepared,  including  0.1  M  ZrCl 4   in  dimethylformamide (DMF), 0.1 M terephthalic acid (BDC) in DMF, and  0.1M HCl in DMF. The following was  combined: 5 mL of  ZrCl 4  stock, 10 mL of BDC and 1.5 mL of HCl stock solution. The MOF solution was heated at 110 o C for 24 hours  and then the solid MOF powder was recovered via vacuum filtration and washing with DMF followed by Methanol. The MOF  solid was activated  by drying  under  vacuum at 120 o C overnight. UiO-66 MOF powder was characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscope (SEM), N 2  adsorption measurements and  thermal  gravimetric  analysis  (TGA)  (see  supporting  information).   2.3 Fabrication of neat Matrimid ®  flat sheet membranes.   Matrimid ®  (0.4 g) was cast as a dense membrane by first  dissolving  it in 3 g of DMF,  after  which  it  was  left  static  for 1 hour to eliminate air bubbles from the solution. The  Matrimid ®  dope solution was then drop cast onto a 3-inch  Pyrex  petri  dish  and  heated  to  110 o C  for  24  hours.  The  Matrimid ®   membrane  was  then  solvent  exchanged  with  methanol  using  Soxhlet  Extraction  for  2  days  and  then  heated  at 100 o C for  24 hours under vacuum, followed by  heating at 340 o C for  4 hours. Neat  Matrimid ®  films  were  characterized  using  TGA,  and  gas  permeance  measurements (see supporting information).   2.4 Fabrication of MMMs with in-situ MOF growth.  Nano-UiO-66 synthesis involves combining precursors in  a  DMF  solution  at  elevated  temperature.  Therefore,  we  chose to fabricate MMMs using our new approach with a  glassy polymer that is stable at those synthesis conditions.  Matrimid ®   is  soluble  in  DMF,  and  is  thermally  stable  to  ~400 o C. Three different MMMs were fabricated with MOF  loadings of 2, 5, and 11 wt% in Matrimid ® . MMMs with 2  and 5 wt% MOF loading were prepared by dissolving 0.4 g  of Matrimid ®  in a portion of the 16.5 mL MOF solution (as  described  in  Section 2.2). MMMs with  2 wt% MOF were  prepared by dissolving Matrimid ®  in 1 g of MOF solution,  with 2 g  of DMF. MMMs with a 5 wt% MOF used 3 g of  MOF solution to dissolve the polymer. For MMMs with 11  wt% MOF, a higher concentration of MOF precursor solution was prepared consisting of 0.15 M ZrCl 4  in DMF, and  0.15 M BDC in DMF. Then, 5 mL of 0.15 M ZrCl 4  stock was  combined with 10 mL of 0.15 M BDC stock and 1.5 mL of  0.1  M  HCl  stock.  The  11  wt%  MMM  dope  solution  was  then  prepared by  dissolving  0.4 g of Matrimid ®   in 3  g of  concentrated  MOF  solution  with  an  additional  0.5  g  of  DMF.  Once  dissolved,  all  MMM  solutions  (2,  5,  and  11  wt%) were drop cast into 3-inch Pyrex petri dishes. MMM  solutions with 2 and 5 wt% MOF were heated in an oven  at 110 o C for 24 hours, while the 11 wt% solution was heated  at  100 o C  for  24  hours.  The  DMF  in  the  MMM  solution  slowly evaporated as the MOF forms and the clear yellow  MMM  solution  transformed  into  an  opaque  yellow  film.  The  11  wt%  MOF  MMM  formed  a  uniform  film  using  a  slightly lower reaction temperature as compared to the 2  and 5 wt% MOF MMMs. Above 100 o C, MMMs with 11 wt%  MOF had some defects and were brittle. All MMMs were  solvent  exchanged  with  methanol  using  Soxhlet  extraction for 2 days and then heated at 100 o C for 24 hours under vacuum, followed by heating at 340 o C for 4 hours. All  MMMs  were  characterized  by  powder  XRD,  SEM,  TGA,  and  gas  permeation  measurements  (see  supporting  information).  2.5 Fabrication of MMMs using post-synthesis MOF mixing.  MMMs with 3, 6, and 10 wt% UiO-66 were prepared using  traditional post-synthesis mixing techniques of MOF and  the polymer dope solution. First a polymer dope solution  was prepared by dissolving 0.4 g of Matrimid ®  in chloroform. Then UiO-66 MOF particles, synthesized according  to Section 2.2,  were  dispersed in chloroform  using  ultrasonication. Next, UiO-66 particles were primed by adding  30%  of  the  total  polymer  dope  solution  to  the  MOF/chloroform  mixture,  and  then  were  roller  mixed  and sonicated  for 2 hours. The rest  of  the polymer dope  solution was added slowly in two more steps, with roller  mixing  and  sonication  performed  after  each  step. UiO-67 and UiO-66 were synthesized and puriﬁed according to published procedures [43].
UiO-66, Zr 6 O 4 (OH) 4 (BDC) 6 , was synthesized as follows: ZrCl 4 (0.625 g) and benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (H 2 BDC, 0.615 g) were fully dissolved in a mixed solution of N, N'-dimethylformamide (DMF, 75 mL) and concentrated HCl (5 mL).
The obtained solution, sealed in a 100 mL jar, was heated at 353 K overnight, followed by cooling down to the ambient temperature.
The resulted white powders were then ﬁltered and puriﬁed with DMF and ethanol several times.
UiO-67, Zr 6 O 4 (OH) 4 (BPDC) 6 , was synthesized as follows: ZrCl 4 (0.536 g) was fully dissolved in a mixed solution of DMF (40 mL) and concentrated HCl (4 mL).
The biphenyl-4,4 0 -dicarboxylate (H 2 BPDC, 0.72 g) was fully dissolved in DMF (80 mL).
The obtained heterogeneous solutions were combined in a 200 mL jar and heated at 353 K overnight.
The resulting solid was then puriﬁed with DMF twice and with acetone three times using a centrifuge at 10,000 rpm.
Zeolite-13X was purchased from UOP (Honeywell Instruments, USA).

2.1.1. UiO-66 UiO-66 was synthesized by adding 0.7768 mg of ZrCl4 in 20.0 mL of DMF. Once the metal salt was completely dissolved, 0.5538 g of BDC was added to the solution. The solution was transferred into a 45 mL Teﬂonliner autoclave and heated to 120  C overnight. The mixture was let cool for a day before the ﬁltration. The ﬁne white powder was recovered and washed with DMF and methanol several times before drying overnight at 70  C. Before calcination, 1.000 g of as-made materials was stirred overnight in 20 mL of methanol and recovered by ﬁltration. After let dried, methanol-treated material was activated at 573 K for 12 h under ambient conditions.2.1.2. UiO-66-0.5ATA Mixed-ligand UiO-66 was synthesized using the same procedure as was in the synthesis of UiO-66. 0.7768 mg of ZrCl 4 was dissolved well in 20.0 mL of DMF before 0.2769 g of BDC and 0.3019 g of ATA were subsequently mixed into the solution and stirred vigorously. The solution was heated in a 45 mL Teﬂon-liner reactor at 120  C for 24 h. Pale yellow powder was recovered and rinsed with DMF and methanol. The product was then let dried at 70  C.

2. Experiment All chemicals and solvents were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Inc. (Shanghai, China) and used as received without further puriﬁcation. UiO-66 MOFs were prepared using a solvothermal method in accordance with [21, 22]. In a typical synthesis, 0.1463 g of ZrOCl 2 ·8H 2 O and 0.1463 g of terephthalic acid (HBDC) with a Zr/HBDC ratio ( f Zr/HBDC ) of 1:2 were dissolved in 50 ml dimethylformamide (DMF). The solution was then transferred to a 100 ml Teﬂon-lined autoclave, sealed and placed in a preheated oven at 120 °C for 24 h, after which it naturally cooled to room temperature. The resulting product was collected by centrifugation and washed three times with DMF to remove the unreacted terephthalic acid. The white powder was further washed with CH 3 OH to remove the DMF adsorbed in the pores of the product and dried at room temperature. Finally, the product was calcined at 373 K in a vacuum oven for 10 h.

UiO-66 Seed Synthesis. Solvothermal reactions were carried out in a Teﬂon lined autoclave by mixing 0.357 g of ZrCl 4 and 0.254 g of terephthalic acid in 21 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) and 8.6 mL of acetic acid. The mixture solution was heated at 120 °C for 24 h, and then slowly cooled to room temperature yielding white crystals. The synthesized sample was obtained by ﬁltration, and dried in air for 24 h before use.

With terephthalic acid, UiO-66 is obtained. Its crystallinity is lower when the methacrylate-functionalised cluster is used instead of ZrCl 4 (see Fig. S2w) but diﬀraction peaks matches those of UiO-66 and its BET surface area is of 905(20) m 2 g 1 , close to the value reported for UiO-66 (S BET = 950(20) m 2 g 1 ).

14 The synthesis of UiO-66 x (x = the particle edge length in nm measured by SEM) at 5 L scale was carried out at 120 °C under atmospheric pressure in DMF using formic acid as a modulator. Two separate 30 mM stock solutions were prepared in 5 L vessels. The terephthalic acid (H 2 bdc) solution was prepared with 22.5 g of H 2 bdc, 4.05 L of DMF, and 450 mL of formic acid, while the ZrOCl 2 ·8H 2 O was prepared with 45 g of ZrOCl 2 · 8H 2 O in 4.5 L of DMF. The reaction procedure is as follows (Figure S1). An initial 100 mL of the ZrOCl 2 ·8H 2 O solution was added to a 5 L round-bottom ﬂask at 120 °C, then both the ZrOCl 2 ·8H 2 O (mM) and H 2 bdc stock solution were separately delivered with feed rate of 12 mL/min for 5 min. The feed rate was accelerated to 32 mL/min for 55 min. After this ﬁrst addition, 2.5 L of the reaction solution was removed from the reactor to obtain the ﬁrst product, UiO-66 80 , and then 1.5 L of metal stock solution and 1.5 L of ligand stock solution were further added into the remaining reaction solution at 30 mL/ min for 50 min. Then 3 L of reaction solution was collected form the reactor to obtain the second product, UiO-66 120 . Finally, 1.55 L of metal stock solution and 1.55 L of ligand stock solution were added into the reactor within 1 h at 25.8 mL/min, and the remaining reaction solution (3.7 L) was collected as the third product UiO66 250 . All products were ﬁrst centrifuged (8000 rpm, 30−60 min) and washed with 2 × 40 mL of DMF, and then solvent exchange was performed by washing with 3 × 40 mL of MeOH. The MOFs were left suspended in MeOH at ∼20 mg/mL until further use. A fraction ACS Nano www.acsnano.org Article https://doi.org/10.1021/acsnano.2c05175 ACS Nano 2022, 16, 18168−18177 18174    of this suspension was removed and dried to determine the exact weight percent of the suspended particles. For PXRD and N 2 sorption experiments the samples were dried in vacuum at 120 °C for 24 h.

Synthesis of UiO-66. UiO-66 was synthesized by the modiﬁed solvothermal procedure 16 using a ZrCl 4 /terephthalic acid molar ratio of 1:1. Zirconium chloride (106 mg, 0.455 mmol) was dissolved in DMF (20 mL) in a 40 mL Wheaton vial under sonication. Then, terephthalic acid (75.6 mg, 0.455 mmol) was added, followed by sonication to obtain a transparent solution. The solution was mixed with acetic acid (99.8%, 2.5 mL), and the vial was sealed. The crystallization was carried out in an oven at 120 °C for 24 h without stirring. The precipitate was separated by centrifugation (Hettich Rotina 35, 10 000 rpm, 5 min), washed four times with DMF and ﬁve times with acetone. The resulting white powder was air-dried overnight and activated at 90 °C under a dynamic vacuum for 24 h.

Synthesis. UiO-66 was prepared via a modified method reported previous.52 In a typical synthesis, ZrCl 4 (0.2332 g, 1.0 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.161 g, 1.0 mmol) were dissolved in DMF (50 mL), and then the solution was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and heated in an oven at 120 °C for 48 h under autogenous pressure. After cooling naturally, the resulting sample was purified with anhydrous methanol several times to make sure that the occluded DMF molecules were eliminated. Following drying under vacuum at 100 °C for 12 h, the final UiO-66 was obtained. UiO-66(NH 2 ) was prepared by a similar process except that H 2 ATA was used as a starting material instead of H 2 BDC.2.2. Characterizations The as-prepared samples were characterized by powder X-ray diﬀraction (XRD) on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diﬀractometer operated at 40 kV and 40 mA with Ni-filtered Cu Kα irradiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). UV-vis diﬀuse reflectance spectra (UV-vis DRS) were obtained using a UV-vis spectrophotometer (Varian Cary 500) in which barium sulfate (BaSO 4 ) powder was used as a reference. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a PHI Quantum 2000 XPS system with a monochromatic Al Kα source and a charge neutralizer.

23 Since Cavka et al.11 first synthesized UIO-66 using a simple system of ZrCl 4 /terephthalic acid (BDC)/DMF and det ermined its structure by powder X-ray diffraction from very small and aggregated crystals, attempts have been made to prepare high quality and functional UIO-66. Currently, several methods canbeemployedtoprepareUIO-66,includingdirectsynthesis, precursor synthesis and additive synthesis with a monocarboxylic acid (e.g., formic acid, acetic acid, benzoic acid and so on) as the additive. In the case of direct synthesis , 11 UIO-66 cannot always be obtained and the crystalli nity and yield cannot be guaranteed. For the precursor synthesis, Guillerm et al. firstly utilized Zr 6 (OH) 4 O 4 (OMc) 12 (OMc = methacrylate) 24 as a source of Zr 6 (OH) 4 O 4 clusters and then exchanged OMc with either terephthalic or trans,transmuconic acid to synthesize UIO-66 and derivative of UIO-66.

Typically, 0.64 g of ZrCl 4 in 40 mL of DMF, 0.456 g of H 2 BDC in 40 mL of DMF and 4.0 mL of acetic acid were mixed in a 250 mL round-bottom ask, and then the mixture was stirred at 120  C for 24 h. Aer cooling down to room temperature, the white solid was collected by centrifugation and washed thoroughly with DMF. Experimental The synthesis of UiO-66 The UiO-66 crystals was obtained followed a reported literature procedure.18 The synthesis of UiO-66-(COOH) 2 According to the literature procedure, in a 100 mL round bottom ask with 50 mL of water and stir bar, 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid (4.3 g, 17 mmol) and zirconium tetrachloride (2.3 g, 10 mmol) were added. The solution was then heated to reux and further stirred for 24 h without inert gas protection. The resulting solid was ltered oﬀ and washed three times with water. The solid was then dispersed in water and reuxed for another 16 h. The as-synthesized UiO-66-(COOH) 2 without morphology control was ltered oﬀ, washed with acetone and dried.The synthesis of ower-like UiO-66-(COOH) 2 (F-UiO-66(COOH) 2 ) To a 250 mL round bottom ask containing 75 mL DMF was added zirconium tetrachloride (0.4 g, 1.7 mmol), then to it was added acetic acid (2.85 mL, 0.85 mmol) and 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid (0.432 g, 1.7 mmol) separately. To the ask was then added additional DMF (25 mL), H 2 O (0.125 mL) and Pluronic® F-127 (0.76 g) and the solution was stirred at 90  C for 24 h. The resulting solid was ltered oﬀ and washed three times with acetone.

15 In a 2 L Erlenmeyer flask, ZrCl 4 (1.86 g, 8 mmol) was dissolved by stirring in DMF (500 mL) and glacial acetic acid (144 g, 137.3 mL, 2.4 mol). In a separate 1 L Erlenmeyer flask, terephthalic acid (1.33 g, 8 mmol) was dissolved completely in DMF (500 mL). This terephthalic acid solution was then added slowly to the ZrCl 4 solution and stirred until homogenized. The resulting mixture was partitioned among fifteen 100 mL vials. The vials were capped and heated at 120 °C in an oven for 24 h before being cooled to room temperature. The contents of the vials were combined and the white powder UiO-66 product was collected over a fine-fritted funnel and rinsed with methanol.

Synthesis of UiO-66 The UiO-66 used in this study was synthesized according to a modied procedure reported previously.40 Typically, 80.4 mg ZrCl 4 (0.345 mmol) and 57.3 mg terephthalic acid (0.345 mmol) were dissolved in 40 mL N ,N 0 -dimethylformamide (DMF). At the same time, 30 equivalents (with respect to ZrCl 4 ) acetic acid was added as a modulator, and the obtained mixture was stirred at room temperature for 30 min. Thereaer, the mixture was transferred in a 50 mL Teon-lined autoclave, sealed and heated in an oven at 120  C for 24 h. The resulting white solid was collected by ltration, thoroughly washed by ethanol, and dried in vacuum oven at 80  C.

2.3 Synthesis of HDBB The synthesis of HDBB was performed as per our previous report.34 Typically, 4-formyl-3-hydroxybenzoic acid (166.2 mg, 1.0 mmol) was dissolved in methanol (10 mL). Then hydrazine hydrate (24 μL, 0.5 mmol, 80%) was added and refluxed at 75 °C. After refluxing overnight, the resulting precipitate was filtered and washed with 30 mL methanol. After drying, HDBB was obtained as yellow powder. The molecular structure of HDBB was verified by NMR and mass spectroscopy.2.4 Preparation of UiO-66 The preparation of UiO-66 was performed as reported previously.35 Typically, nanoscale UiO-66 was synthesized by dissolving zirconium( IV) chloride (ZrCl 4 ) (115.5 mg, 0.5 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) (82 mg, 0.5 mmol) in 20 mL DMF at room temperature. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 100 mL flask. The flask was kept in an oil bath at 120 °C for 24 h. The final product was cooled to room temperature and then centrifuged and washed with DMF and ethanol three times to remove the unreacted reactants before activation at 100 °C. The microcrystals of UiO-66 were prepared by a similar process of nanoscale UiO-66, additionally, (288.5 mg, 2.5 mmol) proline and 100 μL 1 M HCl were added into the reactant mixtures before heating at 120 °C.

Results and discussion Crystalline UiO-66 can be obtained following the general procedure as shown in Scheme 1 (see ESI† for details). 2.3. Synthesis of UiO-66(Zr) In the typical synthesis method, 5 mmol of zirconyl nitrate hydrate and 5 mmol of PET derived BDC were dispersed in 50 mL of the DMF solvent. Then, 0.5 mol of formic acid was added into the resultant mixture. Formic acid served as a modulator in the reaction. The flask was sealed and placed on a hot plate at 150 1C. As the temperature reached 150 1C, it was maintained and the entire reaction was carried out at that temperature for 4 h. The solid white precipitates formed were collected by centrifugation at 3000 rpm for 5 min, filtered and washed several times with ethanol. The product was then dried overnight in an oven at 50 1C.2.4. 2.2 Synthesis of the samples The synthesis of the parent UiO-66 was carried out by dissolving 1.362 mmol of ZrCl 4 (0.317 g) and H 2 BDC (0.226 g) in 30 mL of DMF; 2.5 mL of acetic acid was then added to the solution. The obtained solution was loaded into a 100 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and then placed in a preheated oven at 120 °C for 24 h under static conditions. The UiO-66nTi MOFs (n represents the mass fraction of Ti 4+ ) were synthesized by following the same procedure but with varying amounts of Ti 4+ being added (titanium isopropoxide was used as the Ti 4+ precursor). The selected molar ratios of Ti/Zr were 5%, 10%, 15%, 20% and 30%. After crystallization, the white products were collected by centrifugation, thoroughly washed with DMF and methanol, and then dried overnight under vacuum at 60 °C.

Experimental Synthesis of MOFs The Zr-based MOFs of UiO-66 and UiO-66-NH 2 were made according to a recently published but modied procedure.29 An 8-dram vial was loaded with ZrCl 4 (125 mg, 0.54 mmol), N,N 0 dimethylformamide (DMF, 15 mL), concentrated HCl (1.00 mL), and the ligand, BDC (123 mg, 0.75 mmol) or BDC-NH 2 (134 mg, 0.75 mmol). The mixture was sonicated for 40 minutes before being heated at 120  C for 24 hours. The resultant solid was then ltered and washed rst with DMF (4  5 mL) and then with ethyl alcohol (EtOH, 4  5 mL) for several hours to remove all residual solvents. The samples were freeze-dried for further adsorption experiments.Materials and instruments All general chemicals and solvents (analytically pure grade or higher) were commercially available and used as received.

deionized (DI) water were added into the DMF solution which was stirred until the chemicals dissolved completely. The molar ratio of the chemicals in the precursor solution is 1 ZrCl 4 :1H 2 BDC : 1 H 2 O : 500 acetic acid : 1500 DMF. With the help of a commercial GIX II Microplotter (Sonoplot Inc.), an ink-jet printing technique was used to precisely load the precursor onto the Parylene-C reservoir.A solvothermal method is always adopted to treat precursors for UiO-66 nanocrystal synthesis. In this study, the precursor-loaded microcantilevers were put into a Teflon bottle and kept in an oven at 120 °C for 24 hours to simulate the solvothermal method. After thermal treatment, the sensing film with UiO-66 crystal structure is formed in situ on the reservoir.

Preparation of UiO-66 and PVBA-UiO-66 UiO-66 was prepared following the procedure reported by Cavka et al.33 ZrCl 4 (0.050 g, 0.214 mmol) and H 2 BDC (0.038 g, 0.229 mmol) were dissolved in 6 mL of DMF. The mixture was transferred into a 10 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and was kept at 120 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the solution was decanted and the product was washed with DMF and methanol three times. UiO-66 was finally obtained after drying at 373 K overnight (the yield: 17.4%).PVBA-UiO-66 were also synthesized using a similar procedure with the feed molar proportion of carboxyl groups of PVBA to the total carboxyl groups of 12%, 30%, 50%, 75% and 100%.

Synthesis of Ce( III)-doped UiO-66 Typically, ZrCl 4 (45 mg), CeCl 3 ·7H 2 O (66 mg), H 2 BDC (30 mg), PVP (10 mg), and HAc (0.2 mL) were dissolved in DMF (15 mL) at room temperature. The obtained mixture was transferred into a 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave that was sealed and maintained at 120 °C for 24 h, being subsequently removed from the oven and allowed to cool to room temperature. The solid was isolated by centrifugation and washed three times with DMF to aﬀord Ce( III)-doped UiO-66, which was dried in vacuum at 100 °C for 4 h prior to being utilized for the adsorptive removal of organic dyes.Synthesis of UiO-66 UiO-66 was synthesized using the procedure described in section 2.1.1, except for the fact that CeCl 3 ·7H 2 O was not used.Characterization Powder X-ray diﬀ raction (PXRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diﬀractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at room temperature. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were measured on a field emission scanning electron micro-analyzer (Hitachi S-4800) employing an accelerating voltage of 5 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained on a JEM-2100 highresolution transmission microscope with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Ultraviolet-visible (UV-Vis) spectra were collected on a UV-3600 UV-vis spectrophotometer (Shimadzu).

38 Typically, ZrCl 4 (0.18 g) and 1,4benzenedicarboxylic acid (H 2 BDC, 0.128 g) were dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 40 mL) at room temperature.The mixture was stirred vigorously for 20 min to form a clear solution before the addition of acetic acid (5 mL). The mixture was then stirred for another 10 min, transferred into a 100 mL Teon-lined stainless steel autoclave, heated at 120  C for 24 h, and then cooled to room temperature. 27 In a typical synthesis, ZrCl 4 (20 mg, 0.086 mmol), BDC (20 mg, 0.12 mmol), FeTCPPCl (1 mg, 0.0012 mmol), and benzoic acid (250 mg, 2.049 mmol) were dissolved in 2 mL DMF by an ultrasonic cleaner. Then, the mixture was transferred into a 7 mL glass vial and heated to 140  C for 12 h in an oven. Aer naturally cooling down to room temperature, the product was collected by centrifuging under 10 000 rpm for 10 min, activated successively with fresh DMF and acetone 3 times at 60  C, and then dried in a vacuum oven under 80  C. 2.2. Synthesis of UiO-66. The UiO-66 sorbent was synthesized by reported method.2 An amount of 0.053 g of ZrCl 4 (0.227 mmol) was dissolved in 24.9 g of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (340 mmol) with ultrasound, and then 0.034 g of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H 2 BDC) (0.227 mmol) was added to the above solution evenly. The reaction solution was transferred to a 50 mL vessel placed in an oven at 120 °C for 24 h. White precipitation was obtained and washed.

Hydrogen peroxide (H 2 O 2 , 30%), nHEP (97%), and sodium nitrate (NaNO 3 , 98.5%) were supplied by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China. Sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 96%) was supplied by Xilong Chemical Co. Ltd., Shantou, China. All reagents were used as received without further puriﬁcation.Synthesis of UiO-66 and H-UiO-66. UiO-66 was synthesized according to the reported literature; 30 ZrCl 4 (0.96 g, 4 mmol) and H 2 BDC (1.328 g, 8 mmol) were dissolved in 160 mL DMF at room temperature in a Teﬂon reaction still (200 mL) and sonicated for 20 min. Then, the mixture was sealed and placed in a preheated oven at 393 K for 24 h, after which it was allowed to cool down to room temperature in air. The generated solid was centrifuged, washed with DMF (twice) and then ethanol (twice), and dried at 333 K for 12 h.

2.2. Preparation of UIO-66. The UIO-66 synthesis procedure is based on the general procedure.33 Typically, ZrCl 4 (2.16 mmol) and H 2 BDC (3.00 mmol) were added to DMF (30 mL) separately and ultrasonicated at room temperature for 1 h to form homogeneous ZrCl 4 /DMF and H 2 BDC/DMF solutions. Thereafter, the two solutions were mixed together prior to the addition of HCl (4 mL).The mixture was transferred to a 100 mL Teﬂon-lined autoclave and heated in an oven at 80 °C for 24 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the resulting white precipitate was collected by centrifugation, washed with DMF, acetone, and deionized water several times to obtain wet products. Finally, pure dry products, named UIO-66, were collected by freeze-drying overnight.2.3. Preparation of UIO-66@OPBI Membranes. OPBI was synthesized based on a previous report, as shown in Scheme S1.

For UiO-66: ZrCl 4 (2.92 g), H 2 BDC (2.075 g), and HCl (37%, 1.1 mL) were mixed in DMF (60 mL). Then, the mixture was ultrasonicated for 1 h and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. After cooling down, the solid was washed with DMF (3 × 100 mL) and methanol (3 × 100 mL). Finally, UiO-66 was obtained by removing the solvent under vacuum at 150 °C for 24 h. For UiO-67: ZrCl 4 (0.23 g), H 2 BPDC (0.24 g), and DMF (30 mL) were mixed and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. Then, the product was collected and washed with DMF (3 × 100 mL) and methanol (3 × 100 mL). Finally, UiO-67 was obtained by removing the solvent under vacuum at 120 °C for 48 h.

Synthesis of MOFs. UiO-66 and functionalized UiO-66 were synthesized 32 to yield powders with a Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface area ranging from 767 to 1447 m 2 /g (Table 2). Brieﬂy, a glass bottle was loaded with 1.25 g (5 mmol) of ZrCl 4 ,50mLof DMF, and 10 mL of concentrated HCl before being sonicated for 20 min until fully dissolved. A total of 5 mmol of ligand and 100 mL of DMF were then added, and the mixture was sonicated an additional 20 min before being heated at 80 °C overnight. The resulting solid was then ﬁltered over a ﬁne frit and washed ﬁrst with DMF (one time) and then with MeOH (three times). The sample was ﬁltered for several hours to remove all residual solvent. With the exception of dried samples, the samples were activated by ﬁrst heating to 90 °C under vacuum until a pressure of 100 mTorr was reached.

Synthesis of UiO-66 Crystals. The general synthesis of pristine and defective UiO-66 crystals is outlined as follows. The detailed procedures for synthesis of the three UiO-66 materials are given in the Supporting Information. Zirconium chloride (ZrCl 4 ), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC), deionized water, and dimethylformamide were added in a Pyrex bottle. For synthesis of modulated UiO-66, the organic acid, benzoic acid or formic acid, was then added. The mixture was sonicated until all solutes dissolved, and then heated at 393 K in an oil bath for 48 or 72 h. Crystals were collected with a centrifuge at 8,500 rpm for 5 min, followed by washing with fresh acetone three times to extract the unreacted precursors and solvent. The collected crystals were dried in an oven at 333 K overnight to remove residual acetone. Before characterization and any other analysis, samples were activated at 190 °C under vacuum for 24 h to remove any residual species.Characterization. Activated UiO-66 crystals were characterized by powder X-ray diﬀraction (PXRD), nitrogen physisorption, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and solution 1 H NMR. PXRD measurements were performed on an X’ Pert Pro P ANalytical X-ray diﬀractometer in reﬂection (Bragg− Brentano) geometry operating with a Cu anode at 45 kV and 40 mA. PXRD patterns were collected with a step size of 0.017° 2θ and scan time of 10 s/step. Surface area and pore volume/size analysis was estimated using nitrogen physisorption isotherms collected at 77 K using a BET surface area analyzer (BELSORP-max, Microtrac). BET surface areas were calculated in individually determined pressure ranges as summarized in the Supporting Information. To determine the chemical composition of synthesized UiO-66 samples, TGA and solution 1 H NMR of UiO-66 adsorbents were conducted with TGA Q500 (TA Instruments) and with Bruker 400 MHz spectrometer, respectively.

Synthesis of UiO-66. The mixture was stirred to form a homogeneous solution, heated in a Pyrex vial at 120 °C for 72 h, and cooled to room temperature. The as-obtained Figure 1. 46,53 Concisely, 43 μL of zirconium propoxide solution (70 wt % in 1-propanol), 2.4 mL of acetic acid, and 4.2 mL of DMF were mixed in a scintillation vial (20 mL) sealed with a poly(tetraﬂuoroethylene) (PTFE)-lined cap and sonicated for 1 min. Afterward, the mixture was placed in an oven at 130 °C for 2 h. After cooling down the obtained solution to room temperature, 49 mg of H 2 BDC and a magnetic stir bar were added into the solution.
