2.2 Synthesis of catalysts 2.2.1 Synthesis of the MOF (UiO-66). UiO-66 was synthesized according to a literature procedure with some modifications. ZrCl 4 (100 mg, 0.429 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc, 71 mg, 0.428 mmol), DMF (20 mL), and CH 3 COOH (771 mg, 12.861 mmol) were transferred into a volumetric vial and heated at 120 °C for 25 h. After the solution was cooled to room temperature in air, the resulting suspension was collected by centrifugation, washed with DMF several times and dried at 65 °C under vacuum overnight to obtain white powdery UiO-66 (unactivated). After the procedure of solvent replacement with ethanol and drying, the activated UiO-66 was prepared for further use.

Synthesis of UiO-66 In order to obtain UiO-66, ZrCl 4 (0.080 g, 0.343 mmol) and the linker precursor, benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid (0.057 g, 0.343 mmol), in an equivalent molar ratio were dissolved in 20 mL of DMF in a 120 mL Teflon-capped glass jar by using ultrasound for about 1 min. 0.7 mL of acetic acid (AcOH, acting as a modulator) was then added into the solution and dispersed by ultrasound for about 1 min. The tightly capped jars were kept in an oven at 120 1C under static conditions for 24 h. White precipitates were produced and were isolated by centrifugation after cooling down to room temperature.

27 Briefly, 250 mg of ZrCl 4 (99.95 + %, J&K) and 246 mg of benzenedicarboxylic acid (H 2 BDC, 99%, Damas-Beta) were dissolved in 30 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99%, GeneralReagent) premixed with 2 mL of concentrated HCl (37%, General-Reagent) by using ultrasonic treatment for 15 min until the solution turned pellucid. Then, the solution was transferred to a glass bottle, and placed in an oven at 80 1C under static conditions for 10 h. Afterwards, the obtained precipitates were cooled down to room temperature and separated by centrifugation. The solids were washed several times with DMF and methanol by centrifugation, and dried under vacuum at room temperature. UiO-66-NH 2 and UiO-66OH were prepared using the same method as UiO-66, while H 2 BDC was changed to 2-aminoterephthalic acid and 2-dihydroxyterephthalic acid, respectively. Noteworthy, this synthetic reaction can be performed as a 10-fold scale up.

Here, 0.581 g (3.5 mmol) terephthalic acid along with 0.815 g (3.5 mmol) ZrCl 4 were dissolved in 40 mL DMF and the resulting solution was put into an autoclave lined with Teflon and heated at 120 1C for 24 h. The obtained solution was centrifuged at 7000 rpm for 10 min to separate the powders and subsequently heated at 100 1C for 2 h.
48 Activation of the MOF powder was performed by immersion of the MOF powder in methanol for three days. Cyclohexane was added to the reaction vessel and the resulting mixture was placed at 0 1C. After freezing, the sample was placed at room temperature. This operation was repeated several times and the sample was finally frozen under vacuum. The resulting white powder was purified by Soxhlet extraction for two days and dried at 120 1C for 24 h (Fig. 1a).

Experimental Chemicals and materials Zirconium tetrachloride (ZrCl 4 , 99.5%), terephthalic acid (H 2 BDC, 98%) and isopropanol (IPA, analytical reagent) were purchased from Aladdin Chemistry, China. Lead acetate (Pb (Ac) 2 ·3H 2 O, 99.5%), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, analytical reagent), ethanol (EtOH, analytical reagent) and benzoic acid (C 6 H 5 COOH, 99.8%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., China. Methylammonium bromide (MABr, 98.0%) was purchased from TCI (Shanghai) Development Co., Ltd. All chemical reagents were used directly without any further purification. Ultrapure water was used throughout.Synthesis of UiO-66 NPs The UiO-66 NPs were synthesized by a solvothermal method, basically according to the reported literature.50 In a typical synthetic process, 0.343 mmol of ZrCl 4 , 0.343 mmol of H 2 BDC and 17 mmol of C 6 H 5 COOH were first dissolved in a 20 mL of DMF solution, then the mixture was sealed in a 25 mL Teflonlined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 24 h, followed by cooling down to RT. The obtained UiO-66 NPs were collected by centrifugation, washed with DMF and EtOH several times, and dried at 60 °C in an oven for 12 h.

Results & discussion Crystals of UiO-66 were prepared by adding ZrCl 4 to a DMF and acetic acid solution mixture containing dissolved 1,4benzene dicarboxylic acid (H 2 BDC; see ESI, section S1†).12 In Fig. 1 General synthetic strategy for engineering linker-induced defects within the zirconium-based metal–organic framework, UiO-66.

Synthesis of UiO-66 UiO-66, [Zr 6 (m 3 -O)(m 3 -OH) 4 (BDC) 6 ] (BDC ¼ benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate, terephthalate), was synthesized using a slightly modied procedure of Lillerud et al., 34 by decreasing the amount of N,N-dimethylformamide, DMF. The molar ratio of the reactants was ZrCl 4 :H 2 BDC : DMF ¼ 1 : 1 : 135. The typical synthesis procedure was as follows: ZrCl 4 (2.33 g, 10 mmol) was dissolved in 55 mL of DMF and terephthalic acid (1.66 g, 10 mmol) in 50 mL of DMF. The ligand solution was slowly added to the metal salt solution and aer 30 min of stirring, the mixture was distributed into three appropriately sized Teonlined autoclaves. The autoclaves were placed in an oven at 120  C for 24 h. The precipitates were collected via centrifugation, thoroughly washed with DMF (20 mL twice) and then immersed in 20 mL of methanol for 3 days. Aer separation, the solid products were dried in an oven at 65  C overnight and then in a vacuum oven (5  10 2 mbar) at 150  C for 12 h. The combined yield was 1.88 g (68%).

Synthesis of UiO-66 nanoparticles ZrCl 4 (21 mg) in a mixed solvent of DMF : ethanol (14 mL : 3 mL) was mixed with PTA (15 mg) in a mixed solvent of DMF : ethanol (13 mL : 6 mL). The mixed solution was heated in an oil bath at 100 1C for 5 h. The product was finally washed with ethanol several times, and UiO-66 nanoparticles were obtained.

2.2 UiO-66 preparation 0.72 g H 2 BDC is mixed with 50 mL DMF and stirred at 50  C until H 2 BDC is completely dissolved in DMF (solution A). With that, 1.03 g ZrCl 4 is added into solution A and then transferred to a stainless steel autoclave, which is kept at 120  C for 24 h. Aerwards, the obtained solid is isolated via centrifugation and washed with DMF once followed by methanol washing twice. The nal solid is dried in an oven at 120  C for 10 h and then shied to a vacuum oven at 100  C for 5 h. The achieved white powder is UiO-66(Zr), which is shortened as UiO-66.

Experimental Materials Na 2 MoO 4 2H 2 O, ZrCl 4 , 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid(BDC), tetrabutylammonium bromide, 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT), dibenzothiophene (DBT), benzothiophene (BT) and 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) were purchased from Aladdin Reagent Co. Ltd. N,N 0 -Dimethylformamide (DMF), ethanol, hydrogen peroxide (H 2 O 2 , 30 wt%), acetonitrile, HCl, n-octane, acetic acid, p-benzoquione and tertiary butanol were purchased from Tianjin Fuyu Chemical Technology Co. Ltd. 1-Butyl-3-methylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate ([BMIM]PF 6 ) were purchased from Shanghai Xushuo Biotechnology Co. Ltd. All the chemicals were analytically pure and used without further purification.Synthesis of UiO-66(Zr) MOF UiO-66(Zr) was synthesized according to a previously reported procedure.38 ZrCl 4 (670 mg, 2.7 mmol) was dissolved in 75 mL DMF containing 5 mL HCl, while BDC (450 mg, 2.7 mmol) was dissolved in 75 mL DMF and were mixed. The mixture was sonicated for 30 min. The reactants were transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and kept at 120 1C for 16 h, and then cooled down to room temperature. The resulting products were filtered and washed three times with DMF and ethanol, respectively. Finally, the sample was dried under vacuum at 100 1C overnight.

Synthetic procedures The nano Pd 0 particles were prepared by the following procedure.32 Firstly, 18.8 mg polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) was dissolved in 5 mL ultra-pure water. Then, the solution was transferred into a 200 mL three-necked flask containing PdCl 2 solution. The outer wall of the flask was immersed in a mixture of ice and water. The mixed solution of PVA and PdCl 2 was stirred under vigorous agitation for 1 h. Secondly, the NaBH 4 solution was added to the mixture to produce Pd 0 . HCl was used to adjust the pH to 7.2–7.5. Finally, the Pd 0 particles were collected by centrifugation of the Pd 0 solid–liquid mixture (15 min, 6000 r min 1 ).The UiO-66(Zr) was prepared by the following procedure.38 Firstly, 0.0334 g zirconium tetrachloride and 0.025 g terephthalic acid were dissolved in 10 mL N,N-dimethylformamide. The mixture was transferred into a 250 mL capacity Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. Secondly, 0.7 mL acetic acid was added to the mixture. The autoclave was placed in a preheated oven at 120 1C for 24 h. After it was cooled to room temperature, the solid was collected by centrifugation at 6000 r min 1 for 10 min. The mixture was transferred into a beaker. It was alternately washed at least 3 times with N,N-dimethylformamide, anhydrous ethanol and ultra-pure water. It was dried in a vacuum drying oven overnightat1201C. Before it was used to synthesize the Pd/UiO66(Zr) material or in a reaction, it was activated in the vacuum drying oven at 120 1Cforatleast2.5h.

2.2 Synthesis of ternary UiO-66@MIL-88B(Fe)/CoTAPc 2.2.1 Synthesis of UiO-66@MIL-88B(Fe). UiO-66 was synthesized firstly through a simple solvothermal route.45 Typically, ZrCl 4 (233.04 mg, 1 mmol) and p-phthalic acid (PTA) (166.13 mg, 1 mmol) were fully dissolved in N,Ndimethylformamide (DMF) (25 mL), and then 3.6 ml of glacial acetic acid was added under ultrasonic treatment within 10 min. After that, the mixed solution was transferred into a 100 ml Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. The formed white particles of UiO-66 were collected, washed and dried at 60 °C under vacuum.

Synthesis of UiO-66 and UiO-66-NH 2 UiO-66 was synthesized by a solvothermal process modified from our report.43 Briefly, zirconium tetrachloride (0.240 g) and terephthalic acid (0.171 g) were dissolved in 60 mL N,Ndimethylformamide (DMF) at room temperature. MOF precipitation can be seen after being heated at 120 °C for 24 hours. Afterward, we removed possible coordinated DMF molecules by solvent exchange with ethanol (20 mL) twice for 6 to 12 hours. As-received UiO-66 was obtained after suction filtration for 15 to 30 minutes. On the other hand, terephthalic acid was replaced with 2-aminoterephthalic acid to obtain UiO-66-NH 2 , followed by the same process as UiO-66 synthesis.

Subsequently, an organic ligand solution comprising 0.1631 g (0.9 mmol) of H 2 BDC-NH 2 , 0.1495 g of H 2 BDC (0.9 mmol) and 20 mL of DMF was slowly added to the above mixture (the theoretical molar ratio of the two organic ligands was 1 : 1), then stirred at 120 1C for 24 h, washed with both 60 mL of DMF and 60 mL of absolute ethyl alcohol, and dried in an 80 1C oven for 8 h to yield a pale yellow powder. Catalysts with diﬀerent theoretical molar ratios (1 : 0, 1 : 0.5, 1 : 2, 1 : 4, and 1 : 8) of the two organic ligands were also synthesized. Scheme 1 shows the progress of synthesizing the UiO-66-NH 2 . The synthesis process of UiO-66 was almost the same as that of UiO-66-NH 2 , with the exception that the organic ligand was H 2 BDC and the catalyst was white powder.

UiO-66 was prepared using a previously reported procedure with slight modification.
37,42 It was synthesized by dissolving terephthalic acid (H 2 BDC) (1.00 g, 6 mmol) and zirconium oxychloride octahydrate (ZrOCl 2 ·8H 2 O) (0.420 g, 1.3 mmol) in glacial acetic acid (40 mL) and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (100 mL) in an oil bath at 90 °C and stirring for ten minutes until the solid powder was fully dissolved and it was allowed to stand at 90 °C for 6 hours. After cooling in air to room temperature, the resulting solid was filtered and washed with methanol at least three times and the complete solvent exchange was verified by TGA analysis with no weight loss between 100 and 150 °C. 2. EXPERIMENTAL SECTION 2.1. Synthesis of UiO-66. ZrCl 4 (0.35 g, 1.5 mmol) and 0.15 mL of concentrated HCl (1.7 mmol, 36 wt %) were dissolved into 15.5 mL of DMF in a 20 mL vial using ultrasound for 5 min. The organic linker terephthalic acid (TPA, 0.25 g, 1.5 mmol) was added into the solution and dissolved by ultrasonic treatment for around 15 min. The vials were kept in an oven at 120 °C for 21 h. White precipitates were produced and isolated by centrifugation after cooling to room temperature.14 The solids were washed with DMF (2*30 mL) to remove the unlinked precursors and with methanol (2*30 mL) to remove the DMF. Then the powder was dried at 50 °C overnight.2.2. Post-treatment. 400 mg of as-prepared UiO-66 was placed in 40 mL of methanol at room temperature and held for 48 h. The obtained mixture was then transferred into a 250 mL round-bottom ﬂask immersed in an oil bath to maintain constant reaction temperature. 2.1.1. Preparation of UiO-66. ZrCl 4 (2 mmol), BDC (2 mmol), benzoic acid (20 mmol), and HCl (37%, 4 mmol) in 36 mL of DMF were ultrasonically dissolved in a Pyrex vial, covered with aluminum foil. The mixture was heated in an oven at 120 °C for 48 h. After cooling down to room temperature, a white powder of UiO-66 nanoparticles (NPs) was harvested by centrifugation and washed with DMF at room temperature.2.1.2. Ice-Templated Chitosan/UiO-66 Monoliths. For preparation of chitosan/UiO-66 composite, 0.2 g of chitosan powder was dissolved in 20 mL of deionized water added with 120 μL of acetic acid with stirring, until a transparent solution formed. Then 0.2 or 0.4 g of UiO66 was added into the 1 wt % chitosan solution, respectively.Following strong stirring, the two composite solutions (weight ratios of chitosan to UiO-66 were 1:1 and 1:2) were transferred into several disposable borosilicate glass test tubes (10 mm × 15 mm, purchased from Fisher Scientiﬁc), with 1 mL of the solution per test tube. The tubes containing the solution were slowly immersed into a bath of liquid nitrogen at a rate of about 0.5 cm min −1 and kept in the bath for 5 min. The frozen samples were freeze-dried for approximately 48 h in a VirTis Advantage freeze-dryer to form dry chitosan/UiO-66 monoliths. The two monoliths with diﬀerent chitosan-to-UiO-66 ratios were denoted as Chitosan/UiO-66-1 (weight ratio of chitosan to UiO-66 was 1:1) and Chitosan/UiO-66-2 (weight ratio of chitosan to UiO-66 was 1:2). For control, 1 wt % chitosan solution without UiO66 was freeze-dried following the same procedure, and the acquired monolith was denoted as Chitosan.

The vial was then covered with aluminum foil and heated in an oven at 120 °C for 48 h. ■ EXPERIMENTAL SECTION Preparation of HP-UiO-66. First, 0.180 g of ZrCl 4 (Alfa Aesar), 0.160 g of H 2 BDC (Aladdin) and 0.223 g of Zn(NO 3 ) 2 (Alfa Aesar) were dissolved in 20 mL of anhydrous N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, Alfa Aesar) to form a solution. The solution underwent sonication for 20 min, and then was transferred to the ﬂask and maintained at 120 °C for 24 h. Afterward, the ﬂask was cooled to room temperature naturally; the resulted precipitation of hybrid MOFs (Zn/ Zr MOFs) was collected by centrifugation and washed several times using DMF and acetone to remove the unreacted precursors. Then, the solid was dispersed in hydrochloric acid solution with pH = 1.0 and then agitated for about 10 min to remove the acid-sensitive ZnMOFs. To remove the decomposed template residues, the ﬁnal product was isolated from the suspension by centrifugation and washed several times using DMF and acetone, respectively, and dried at 60 °C overnight in the oven. The bare Zr-MOFs (UiO-66) was prepared by the same process without Zn(NO 3 ) 2 and the etching.

The preparation of UiO-66-FA was similar to that of UiO-66 but additionally adding formic acid (FA) (14 mL, 100 mmol) to the abovementioned reaction mixture and without other modiﬁcations.

■ EXPERIMENTAL SECTION ZrCl 4 , terephthalic acid, dimethylformamide (DMF), acetic acid, formic acid, diﬂuor oa cet ic ac id, and triﬂuoroacetic ac id we re purchased from commercial suppliers and used as received. Defected UiO-66 was synthesized in 6-dram borosilicate glass vials with screw caps purchased from Fisher Scientiﬁc.Synthesis of UiO-66. Pristine UiO-66 synthesis was adopted from the method described by Shearer et al.6 378.1 mg (1.62 mmol) of ZrCl 4 and 539.7 mg (3.24 mmol) of terephthalic acid were combined in a 6-dram vial with 10 mL of DMF and 286 μLof concentrated HCl. The mixture was stirred at 70 °C for 1 h and pipetted into a 23 mL Teﬂon liner. The liner was placed into a stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 220 °C. After 24 h, the oven was shut oﬀ and the autoclave slowly cooled to room temperature before opening. The powder was isolated by centrifugation and washed four times with DMF. After the ﬁnal wash, the powder was suspended in fresh DMF and soaked for 24 h. DMF soaking was repeated for three days before the isolated powder was dried in an oven overnight at 60 °C. The MOF was activated by heating at 200 °C for 24 h.

Synthesis of UiO-66 and ZrOSO 4 @C. ZrOCl 2 (750 mg), terephthalic acid (740 mg), and glacial acetic acid (4 mL) were dissolved in DMF (90 mL). The mixture was subjected to ultrasonication for 30 min before transferring into a Te ﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave (100 mL) for heating at 120 °C for 24 h. The product, UiO-66, was washed three times using DMF (3 × 30 mL) and ethanol (3 × 30 mL) before drying overnight.

Preparation of the UiO-66 Particle. UiO-66 was prepared via a modiﬁed procedure.40 In a typical experiment, a mixture of ZrCl 4 (53 mg, 0.227 mmol), H 2 BDC (34 mg, 0.227 mmol), and acetic acid (450 μL), in dimethylformamide (DMF) solution (15 mL) was sonicated for 30 min until fully dispersed. The obtained mixture was sealed and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. After cooling in air to the room temperature, the resulting solid was collected through centrifugation, repeatedly washed with DMF and methanol, and vacuum-dried at 60 °C for 24 h.

MHT Synthesis of UiO-66-Type MOFs. In a typical process, organic ligand (∼5 mmol) and Zr(NO 3 ) 4 (1.8 g, ∼5.2 mmol) were suspended in 50 mL of water/acetic acid mixed solvent with various ratios (Table S1 in the Supporting Information), and the reaction mixture was heated under reﬂux for 24 h to yield a powder product.
The product was soaked in anhydrous methanol for 3 days at room temperature, during which time the extract was decanted and fresh methanol was added every day. Then the sample was treated with anhydrous dichloromethane similarly for another 3 days. This process was carried out to wash out residual reagents in the pores. After removal of dichloromethane by decanting, the sample was dried under a dynamic vacuum at 120 °C for 24 h to yield the ﬁnal product with a yield of 63−95% based on the overall weight of ligand and metal salt.

UiO-66. UiO-66 was synthesized and activated as reported by Schoenecker et al.16 UiO-66-DM. Synthesis of UiO-66-DM was performed by using a slightly modiﬁed procedure of Lillerud et al.13 reported for the parent UiO-66 MOF. UiO-66-DM was synthesized by dissolving 0.681 mmol of zirconium(IV) chloride (ZrCl 4 ) and 0.681 mmol of 2,5-dimethyl-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (DMBDC) in 26.5 mL of DMF at room temperature. The resulting mixture was divided equally into t wo 20 mL scintillation vials. These vials were kept in a sand bath inside an oven at 393 K for 24 h. The ﬁnal product was cooled to room temperature and then washed with DMF three times to remove the unreacted reactants before activation at 473 K.

The resulting particles were characterized using gas adsorption isotherms, particle dispersities, and particle size distributions.UIO-66 was synthesized according to a literature procedure 36 in which 5 mmol of terephthalic acid, 4 mmol of zirconium chloride (5:4 ratio), and 3 mL of HCl (35.5%) were mixed in 80 mL of dry DMF within a glass vial before being sealed with Teﬂon tape and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. We decided to evaluate UIO-66 as a suitable MOF system because it is known to be very stable (eliminating unwanted degradation during optimizations) and features pores of 0.8 and 1.1 nm, safely smaller than those of the tested calixarene molecule.

■ EXPERIMENTAL SECTION Synthesis of UiO-66 and NHP-UiO-66. UiO-66 was synthesized by a modiﬁed modulator-induced method according to the previous literature.39 Typically, zirconium chloride (ZrCl 4 ) (0.160 g) and terephthalic acid (BDC) (0.114 g) were co-dissolved in N,N-dime thylfor mamide (DMF) (40 mL) under ultrasonic agitation at room temperature to form a clariﬁed solution. The mixture was sealed in a Teﬂon-lined bomb (100 mL), which was then heated at 120 °C for 48 h. After cooling to room temperature, a white precipitate was obtained by centrifugation and vortex washing with DMF and methanol 3 times. Finally, the products were suspended in methanol and stored at 4 °C in a refrigerator.

Syntheses. A series of UiO-66 with varying defect concentrations was synthesized according to the method previously described in the literature, 29 with some modiﬁcations. The defect concentration in UiO-66 X samples (X, vol % HCl; 25, 50) was achieved by adding 10 or 20 mL of concentrated HCl acid (36−38%) to 2.53 mmol ZrCl 4 and subsequently adding DMF to achieve 40 mL of total solution. To obtain complete dissolution of MOF precursors, the mixture was then sonicated in an ultrasound bath for 30 min. In the next step, 2.53 mmol H 2 BDC was added to the mixture and the volume was adjusted to 80 mL total solution. The ﬁnal mixture was then sonicated in an ultrasonic bath for 30 min and subsequently transferred to Teﬂon liners and placed in an oven at 120 °C for 24 h. Finally, the asreceived samples were washed three times with fresh DMF and ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces www.acsami.org Research Article https://dx.doi.org/10.1021/acsami.0c21508 ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2021, 13, 312−323 313   
methanol and then centrifuged (4000 rpm, 10 min). The washed UiO-66 samples were then activated in a vacuum drier at 110 °C overnight. The samples were denoted UiO-66 12.5% and UiO-66 25%. The reference UiO-66 sample (“ideal” UiO-66 structure; Figure S1B) was synthesized according to the procedure previously described elsewhere.
30 In brief, 1 mmol ZrCl 4 and 2 mmol H 2 BDC were dissolved in 6 mL of DMF and subsequently 0.16 mL of concentrated HCl was added to the mixture. To completely dissolve all reagents, the resulting mixture was sonicated in an ultrasonic bath for 30 min.

Chemical Stability. The stability of MOF samples toward water, acid and base for UiO-66 and the three tagged materials were studied by treating the as-synthesized materials (0.2 g) with solutions (20 mL) of water, 1.0 M HCl, and 1.0 M NaOH, respectively, for 2 h at room temperature. 2.1. Synthesis of MOFs. The synthesis of UiO-66 was a modiﬁed solvothermal method based on a published procedure.
35 About 0.455 g of zirconium tetrachloride (ZrCl 4 99.99%, Sigma-Aldrich), 0.320 g of terephthalic acid (H 2 BDC 99+%, Acros Organics), and 2.44 g of benzoic acid (C 6 H 5 COOH 99.5%, Sigma-Aldrich) were dissolved in 36 mL of N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF HCON(CH 3 ) 2 99.8%, J.T.
Baker), and 0.33 mL of hydrochloric acid (HCl 37%, Honeywell) was further added as a modulator.
11 After sonication for a better mixing, the tightly sealed solution was heated in an oven at 120 °C for 48 h.
The precipitate was isolated by centrifugation after cooling to room temperature and washed with a copious amount of DMF and ethanol (99.8%, J.T. Baker) three times to remove the residual solvent. The white UiO-66 powders (abbreviated as UiO) were collected after drying at 90 °C in air.

Synthesis of UiO-66. The synthesis of UiO-66 was based on modiﬁcation of our previous procedure.19 In short, 106 mg (0.455 mmol) of ZrCl 4 was dissolved in 20 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) in a 40 mL Wheaton vial. ZrCl 4 was fully dissolved under sonication (20 min). Then, 75.6 mg (0.455 mmol) of terephthalic acid was added and the mixture was placed in an ultrasonic bath for 5 min until all linker was dissolved. In the next step, 1 mL of acetic acid (99.8%), a modulator, was added, and the vial was sealed, shaken, and the reaction mixture was placed in a preheated oven (Memmert UF30 Plus) for 24 h at 120 °C. When the reaction mixture cooled down, the white precipitate was isolated by centrifugation (Hettich Rotina 380 R, 10 000 rpm, 5 min), washed four times by DMF and ﬁve times by acetone, and air-dried overnight. Then, as-prepared UiO-66 was activated under dynamic vacuum for 24 h at 100 °C.

2.2. Synthesis of UiO-66 (Zr) Assisted by Microwave and UiO-66-PVA Beads. About 2.0 g of zirconium tetrachloride (ZrCl 4 ) was dissolved in 120 mL of N,Ndimethylformanmide (DMF). Acetic acid (CH 3 COOH) and deionized water were added into the solution. 1.6 g of terephthalic acid (C 6 H 4 (COOH) 2 ) dissolved in DMF (120 mL) was mixed together with the previous solution under stirring and then sonicated for 10 min before heating in a microwave oven from ambient temperature to 120 °C and maintained for 20 min at irradiation of 350 W. After cooling to ambient temperature, the white solid was separated from slurry mixture by centrifugation, cleansed by using DMF and EtOH at 60 °C, and dried overnight at 70 °C. The dried UiO-66 powdery sample was vacuumed at 150 °C prior to use.

Sodium sulfate anhydrate (Na 2 SO 4 , >99.9%), sodium chloride (NaCl, >99.9%), and phenol red (PR, >99%) for OPD and HPD experiments were bought from Sigma-Aldrich.Synthesis of UiO-66 nanoparticles: ZrCl 4 (1.165 g, 5 mmol), BDC (0.8 g, 5 mmol), BA (6.1 g, 50 mmol), and HCl solution (37%, 0.833 mL, 10 mmol) were dissolved in DMF (90 mL) in a Teﬂon-lined autoclave with the assistance of ultrasonication. The autoclave was placed in a heated oven at 120 °C for 24 h. After it cooled to room temperature, the precipitated nanoparticl e powder (∼3g)was collected by centrifugation (10 000 rpm for 20 min). To remove the residual ligands, a washing protocol was followed by three steps: (1) the nanoparticle powders were dispersed by ultrasonication in the washing solvent, DMF (20 mL, 30 min); (2) the solution was harsh stirred (1 h); (3) the precipitated nanoparticle powders were collected at the bottom by centrifugation (10 000 rpm for 20 min).

2. EXPERIMENTAL SECTION 2.1. Materials. ZrCl 4 , 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) were purchased from J&K Scientiﬁc Ltd. (Shanghai, China). 2-Amino-benzenedicarboxylic acid (99%) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Ltd. (Beijing, China). Methanol (HPLC and AR grade), ethanol (AR grade), hydrochloric acid (37%), ammonium acetate, formate, phenol (99.5%), 2,4,6-trinitrophenol, 2,4-dinitrophenol, and 4-nitrophenol were provided by the Jiangtian Chemical Co., Ltd.(Tianjin, China). All of the chemicals were used as received without further puriﬁcation.2.2. Preparation of the Adsorbents. Zr-based framework UiO-66 was synthesized according to the reported procedure with modiﬁcation.22 In a typical synthesis, ZrCl 4 ((2.92 g, 12.5 mmol), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (2.075 g, 12.5 mmol), and 12.5 mmol HCl (HCl, 37%, 1.0739 mL) were dissolved in DMF (60 mL), and then the mixture was ultrasonicated for 30 min. The as-obtained mixture was transferred to a stainless steel Teﬂon-lined autoclave of 120 mL capacity, and the temperature was maintained at 493 K for 16 h. After this time, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature and the resulting solid was ﬁltered, washed with methanol, and dried overnight at 423 K.

2.3. Preparation of UiO-66. UiO-66 wa s pre pared according to the reported method.44 A 50 mL polytetraﬂuoroethylene liner loaded with ZrCl 4 (0.2500 g), DMF (10 mL), and hydrochloric acid (2 mL, 36 wt %) was sonicated for 20 min. Terephthalic acid (0.2460 g) and the remaining DMF (10 mL) were then added into the liner. The mixture was sonicated for additional 20 min, then heated at 80 °C for 16 h. The resulting solid powder was separated and washed ﬁrst with DMF (2 × 30 mL) and then with ethanol (2 × 30 mL). The sample was activated at 90 °C for 3 h under vacuum; then, the temperature was increased to 150 °C for another 3 h.2.4. Boron Adsorption Experiments. Prior to the boron adsorption studies, UiO-66 was activated at 80 °C under vacuum overnight. In a typical boron adsorption experiment, a 50 mL centrifuge tube was loaded with the activated UiO-66 at the dosage of 5 g·L −1 , followed by boric acid aqueous solution with a known concentration. The mixture was placed in the water bath shaker and shaken for 12 h at a speciﬁc temperature.Then, UiO-66 was ﬁ ltered oﬀ with a syringe ﬁlter (aquo system, 0.22 μm), and the ﬁltrate was analyzed for the b oron concentration with ICP-OES.

2.2. Synthesis of UiO-66. To synthesize UiO-66, 0.76 g of ZrCl 4 and 1.06 g of TPA were dissolved in 50 g of DMF at room temperature and then stirred for 30 min. The resulting solution was then introduced to a Teﬂon-lined stainless steel autoclave and kept at 120 °C for 24 h. The product was naturally cooled down to room temperature, ﬁltered, and washed with DMF and ethanol. Then, the nanoparticles were kept in a Soxhlet in ethanol for 5 days. In the end, the prepared nanoparticles were dried under vacuum at 100 °C for 12 h.

MOF Synthesis and Characterisation  All solvents and reagents were purchased from Alfa Aesar, Acros  Organics, Sigma-Aldrich, Merck,  Tokyo  Chemical  Industry,  Thermo  Fischer  Scientific  and  Zymo  Research  USA,  and  used  without  further purification. All MOFs were dried in  vacuo at room temperature for at least 24 hours and  subsequently in the oven at 120 ˚C overnight  before any characterisation or further  experiments  took place.  Synthesis  of  UiO-66:  Zirconium  (IV)  chloride  (0.6839  g,  3  mmol)  was  dissolved  in  30  mL  DMF  (sonication until complete dissolution). In a separate container, terephthalic acid (0.4486 g, 3 mmol)  was dissolved in 30 mL DMF. The two solutions were mixed in a glass pyrex jar, 4.2 mL (7% tot. vol.)  acetic acid was added, and the jar was heated at 120 ˚C for 24 hours. The jar was allowed to cool  down to ambient temperature, the nanoparticles were collected by centrifugation (4500 rpm for 20  minutes), washed with DMF  (×2)  and MeOH (×3)  (sonication  and  centrifugation cycles) and were  dried in vacuo for 72 hours. This synthesis was adapted from a literature source.[S3]  Synthesis of MIL-101(Cr): Chromium (III) nitrate nonahydrate (1.6 eq, 8 mmol) was dissolved in 25  mL deionised water (sonication until complete dissolution). Then, terephthalic acid (1 eq, 5 mmol)  was added and the suspension was sonicated for another 10 minutes. Acetic acid (1 eq, 5 mmol) was  added and the suspension was transferred into a Teflon lined steel autoclave bomb and was heated  at 220 °C for 6 hours. The autoclave bomb was left to cool down to ambient temperature and the  nanoparticles formed were collected with centrifugation and dried in vacuo for 24 hours. The solid  was  loaded into a 100 mL round  bottom flask  and 50 mL  DMF were added. The  suspension was  refluxed under stirring at 140 °C for 4 hours. Then it was centrifuged and dried in vacuo overnight.  The nanoparticles were washed once with DMF and once with MeOH (sonication and centrifugation  cycles)  and  were  dried  in  vacuo  for  72  hours.  This  synthesis  was  adapted  from  a  literature  source.[S4]  Powder  X-Ray  Diffraction  (PXRD):  The  first  part  of  characterisation  of  the  materials  involved  verifying their crystallinity and validating their identity. Both goals were achieved with powder X-ray  diffraction (PXRD). Figure S1 shows the PXRD patterns of the materials compared to the calculated  patterns based on the crystal structures found in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC)  database.  The  high  crystallinity  of  all  the  samples  is  prominent  and  a  very  close  match  of  the  experimentally acquired patterns to the calculated ones is obvious in both cases.

Preparation of UiO-66. Solutions of ZrCl 4 (20.04 mg, 0.086 mmol) and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylicacid (H 2 BDC, 14.29 mg, 0.086 mmol) were dissolved in dimethylformamide (DMF; 2.5 mL), respectively. Then, 0.5 mL of acetic acid was added to the DMF solution containing H 2 BDC. The resulting solution was added to the DMF solution containing ZrCl 4 . In detail, ZrCl 4 (558 mg), BDC (398 mg), and CoCl 2 ·6H 2 O (1710 mg) were added into DMF (30 mL) and dissolved with ultrasonication. ■ MATERIALS AND METHODS Chemicals. Chemicals were received without further puriﬁcation from the following. Aldrich: ferrocenecarboxylic acid (97%), terephthalic acid (H 2 BDC, 98%), ferrocenecarboxaldehyde (98%), malonic acid (99%), and piperidine (99%); Sigma: hydrogen peroxide (H 2 O 2 , 30% (w/w) in H 2 O (with stabilizer)), TCI America: tetrabutylammonium hexaﬂuorophosphate (TBAPF 6 , 98%); Fisher: n,n-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.8%), acetone (≥99.5%), hydrochloric acid (HCl, 36.5−38.0%), zirconium chloride (ZrCl 4 , 98%), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, ≥97%), sulfuric acid (H 2 SO 4 , 95.0− 98.0%), and potassium chloride (KCl, 99%); and Northwestern University Facilities: deionized water and nitrogen.Sample Preparation. UiO-66 was synthesized by following a literature procedure.37 Brieﬂy, in an 8 dram vial, ZrCl 4 (125 mg, 0.54 mmol) and DMF (5 mL) were mixed, followed by addition of HCl (1 mL) and 20 min of sonication. Then, H 2 BDC (123 mg, 0.74 mmol) was added along with DMF (10 mL) and the mixture was sonicated again, until clear. The vial was then transferred to the oven and kept at 80 °C overnight. After cooling, the supernatant was decanted and the white solid was transferred to centrifuge tubes and washed three times with DMF, at 2 h soaking intervals, followed by soaking the sample in DMF overnight. The solid was then washed with acetone, using the same procedure, followed by heating at 80 °C in a vacuum oven.

2.2. Synthesis of UiO-66-R (R = −H, −NH 2 , and −NO 2 ). UiO-66 was prepared according to the literature.92 Among all of the representative methods for synthesizing UiO-66-type MOFs, the selected method resulted in smaller nanoparticles suitable for drug delivery.93 Brieﬂy, ZrCl 4 (0.466 g, 2 mmol) and benzene-1,4dicarboxylic acid (0.32 g, 2 mmol) were dissolved in 230 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) at 25 °C. The mixture was reﬂuxed at 120 °C for 24 h. After cooling in air to room temperature, the resulting solid was ﬁltered, washed ﬁrst with DMF (3 × 20 mL) and then with EtOH (3 × 20 mL), and dried at room temperature. To activate the product, powders obtained from this process were washed and stored in DMF for 2 days (the solvent was reﬁlled three times per day). Using ethanol instead of DMF, a similar process was conducted. A ﬁnal step involved holding the product at 100 °C for 24 h. UiO-66-NH 2 and UiO-66-NO 2 were synthesized by replacing the benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid with equivalent molar amounts of 2-aminobenzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid and 2-nitrobenzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid, respectively.

The starting materials were suspended in 15 mL of acetone, and the solution was transferred to the Teﬂon liner of 40 mL Parr bomb, which was sonicated for approximately 5 min. The liner was then transferred to the Parr bomb and incubated in an oven for 24 h, unless otherwise noted, at various temperatures. UiO-66-NH 2 , UiO-66-NO 2 , and UiO-66-Br were synthesized in an analogous way from zirconium chloride (0.652 mmol) and the respective linker acid (0.652 mmol).

The nanocomposites were collected by centrifugation and washed with DMF and chloroform. In addition, to impart the polymerizable ability of CN@UIO-66, 0.60 g of the nanocomposites were further dispersed in 50 mL of chloroform with 2.46 g of methacrylic anhydride and 0.20 g of triethylamine. After the mixture was stirred and reﬂuxed at 55 °C for 24 h, the product was centrifuged and washed with chloroform three times and dried in vacuum at 60 °C overnight to obtain CN@ UIO-66. Lab-Scale Synthesis (1 L Reactor). UiO-66(Zr) was synthesized in a 1 L round-bottom ﬂask, equipped with a reﬂux condenser and a mechanical Teﬂon-lined stirrer. H 2 BDC (16.6 g, 0.1 mol) (Aldrich, 98%) was dissolved in 500 mL of DMF (474 g, 6.5 mol) at room temperature under stirring. ZrOCl 2 ·8H 2 O (32.2 g, 0.1 mol) (Alfa Aesar, 98%) and 6 mL of 37% HCl (7 g, 0.2 mol) were added to the mixture. The molar ratio of the ﬁnal ZrOCl 2 ·8H 2 O/H 2 BDC/DMF/ HCl mixture is 1:1:65:2. The mixture was heated at reﬂux (T ≈ 423 K) under stirring for 24 h. Mechanical rather than magnetic stirring was found to be of prime importance to avoid the complete solidiﬁcation of the mixture. The obtained white gel-consistency solid was recovered by ﬁltration, washed with DMF at room temperature, and dried at 373 K overnight. The activation was performed in three steps. To remove the free H 2 BDC, 1 g of solid was ﬁrst dispersed in 100 mL of DMF at room temperature under stirring overnight. The same procedure was repeated twice, using methanol (MeOH) instead of DMF to exchange the DMF. Finally, the solid was dried at 373 K overnight to remove MeOH and left under air in atmospheric condition. Yield based on zirconium: 80%.

■ EXPERIMENTAL SECTION Materials. All chemical materials were obtained from the indicated suppliers without additional puriﬁcation and stored under recommended conditions. The UiO-66 MOF precursor materials are prepared following previously reported methods 58 utilizing the less toxic zirconyl chloride octahydrate, ZrOCl 2 ·8H 2 O, (Sigma Alrich, 98%) metal base compared to the more commonly used ZrCl 4 .8 The metal precursor reactant 0.1 mol (35.40 g) ZrOCl 2 ·8H 2 O was dissolved in 200 mL (2.58 mol) of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) anhydrous (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.8%) and 1 mL of acetic acid (SigmaAldrich, 99%) by stirring, and sonicated for 5 min in an ultrasonic bath. The organic precursors, 0.1 mol (18.24g) H 2 BDC and 200 mL (2.58 mol) of DMF, were combined, stirred in a second ﬂask, and also ultrasonically treated for 5 min.

Materials andmethods Reagents andsolutions All materials used in this assay are in the analytical grade  without any puriﬁcation. Terephthalic acid  (H 2 BDC, 99%),  zirconium chloride  (ZrCl 4 , 98%), N, N-dimethylformamide  (DMF), and acetic acid (HAc, 99.5%) were supplied by  Sigma-Aldrich for the synthesis of UiO-66. Extra pure  disodium tetraborate decahydrate  (Na 2 B 4 O 7 ·10   H 2 O) and  PVA were purchased from Merck for forming a hydrogel  matrix. For the preparation of sodium dihydrogen phosphate   (NaH 2 PO 4 ) buﬀer with diﬀerent pHs, sodium hydroxide  (NaOH) and hydrochloric acid (HCl) were used which were  all received from Merck (www. merck. com). For synthesizing CQDs, tris (hydroxymethyl) amino methane hydrochloride powder was prepared from Merck, Germany. A stock  solution of pethidine (1000μg mL −1 ) was attained from  Temad Pharmaceutical Company (Tehran, Iran) and properly  diluted with ultrapure deionized water which was achieved  from (Ghazi Pharmaceutical Co., Tabriz, Iran, www. sgco-  infus ion. com). Drug-free quality control (QC) plasma samples (donated by the blood transfusion organization of Eastern Azerbaijan, Tabriz, Iran) were kept in polypropylene  micro-tubes and frozen at − 20°C. 2.2.3   UiO‑66 UiO-66 was synthesized using a method adapted from Cavka  etal. [8].   ZrCl 4  (0.053g, 0.227mmol) and  H 2 BDC (0.034g,  0.227mmol) were dissolved in DMF (24.9g, 340mmol) at  room temperature in an ultrasound bath. The obtained solution was transferred to a Teﬂon-lined high-pressure reactor  at 120°C for 24h. The product was washed with DMF three  times and centrifuged. MOF activation was performed in  methanol for 24h under stirring at room temperature, followed by centrifugation and activation at 120°C for 24h  under vacuum.2.2.4   UiO‑66(NH 2 ) UiO-66(NH 2 ) was synthesized following the procedure adapted from Chavan etal. [9].   ZrCl 4  (0.3956g,  0.227mmol) and  H 2 BDC-NH 2  (0.3074g, 0.227mmol)  were dissolved in 46mL of DMF (24.9g, 340mmol) and  39 µL of deionized water in an ultrasound bath. Then, the  solutions were mixed and kept under ultrasound for 10min  and transferred to a high-pressure reactor lined with Teﬂon  at 100°C for 72h. The resulting white solid was separated  by centrifugation and washed three times in DMF (40mL),  followed by solvent exchange in water under stirring for 2h  at 85°C. Finally, the solid was dried at 60°C for 24h under  vacuum.

2.2 Synthesis of UiO-66 and Pd@UiO-66 The UiO-66 was prepared according to the procedure reported by Michael [34]. ZrCl 4 (500 mg, 2.16 mmol) was dispersed in HCl (4 mL)/DMF (20 mL) to give a clear solution under ultrasonic. Then, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (BDC) (492 mg, 3 mmol) dispersed in 40 mL DMF was added into the above solution. Finally, the mixed solution was placed into the microwave oven and irradiated at 100 °C for 2 h. After centrifugation, the obtained UiO-66 was washed two times with water and dried in vacuum at 150 °C overnight.

2   Experimental 2.1   Catalyst  Preparation UiO-66 was synthesized according to the literature procedure [23]. Brieﬂy, 250mg (1.0mmol) of  ZrCl 4  (99.95+%,  J&K) and 246mg (1.5mmol) benzene-dicarboxylic acid   (H 2 BDC, 99%, Damas-Beta) were dissolved in 30ml N,Ndimethylformamide (DMF, 99%, General-Reagent) which  premixed with 2ml concentrated HCl (37%, General-Reagent). After ultrasonic treating at room temperature for  10min. Then the clear mixture was transferred to a glass  bottle and heated at 80°C under static condition for 10h.  The produced white precipitates were separated by centrifugation after cooling to room temperature (RT). The solids  were washed with DMF three times to remove unreacted   H 2 BDC and with methanol six times to remove DMF.  Then, the powder was dried under vacuum and stored in a  desiccator for standby application. This synthesized reaction can carry out by a 10-fold scale up.

2.2   Preparation ofUiO‑66 andIts Sulfonic Acid  Derivative 2.2.1   Preparation  ofUiO‑66 ZrCl 4  (1.20g; 5.00mmol) and  H 2 BDC (0.83g; 5.00mmol)  were mixed and added to 50mL of a mixed solution containing acetic acid and DMF (the volume of acetic acid  was 5, 10, 15, 20, or 25mL). The mixture was completely  dissolved, and the resulting solution was crystallized in a  pressure bomb for 40h at 120°C. The resulting white precipitate was obtained via centrifugation, and then washed  twice with DMF and twice with anhydrous methanol (for  3h each time). After vacuum drying for 24h at 130°C,  the obtained white powder samples were denoted as UiO66(5), UiO-66(10), UiO-66(15), UiO-66(20), and UiO66(25), corresponding to acetic acid volumes of 5, 10, 15,  20, and 25mL, respectively. The UiO-66 sample prepared  without acetic acid was mixed with 5mL of formic acid  and 45mL of DMF, while the other reaction conditions  were the same as described above. The obtained white  powder was denoted as UiO-66.

UiO-66 was synthesized as follows: Terephthalic acid (0.86 mol, 142 g) and ZrCl 4 (0.86 mol, 200 g) were added to 6266 mL of DMF (86 mol, 100 eq) in a 10-L glass bottle and stirred using a magnetic bar at room temperature for 2 h to dissolve the compounds.A 37 wt% HCl solution (0.86 mol, 95 g) was added, and the reaction was allowed to proceed in a 120 °C conventional oven for 24 h to dissolve the compounds. After diluting with DMF, the mixture was ﬁltered, and a white precipitate was collected. The solid was washed with excess DMF and ethanol three times for 24 h each. Finally, the obtained UiO-66 was dried at 80 °C for 12 h (total yield: * 60%).The number average molecular weight (M n ) and the polydispersity (M w /M n ) were determined by GPC (PL-GPC 220, Agilent Technologies, USA) performed at 25 °C using THF as the eluent at a ﬂow rate of 1 mL min -1 using polystyrene calibration standards. FTIR spectroscopy was performed in the transmittance mode (NICOLET 6700, Thermo Electron Co., USA) in the range of 600–4000 cm -1 with a resolution of 4 cm -1 . The specimens were measured after forming KBR pellets. The particle size was measured using a particle size analyzer (ELS-Z2, Otsuka Electronics Co., Japan) at 25 °C in distilled water. The measurements were repeated three times, and the average size was recorded.

Preparation of UiO-66 and modulated UiO66 Pristine UiO-66 was synthesized based on the traditional solvothermal method [47]. In brief, ZrCl 4 (0.212 g, 0.91 mmol) and H 2 BDC (0.136 g, 0.82 mmol) were sequentially added to DMF (20 mL). The mixture was ultrasonicate d to aid dissolution, and the clear solution was transferred to a 25-mL Teﬂon-lined autoclave and maintained at 120 °C for 24 h. The product was separated by centrifugation. After washing three times with DMF and EtOH, it was ﬁnally dried in a vacuum oven. Modulated UiO-66M-x was fabricated in the same way as pristine UiO66, except that a certain amount of 2-MI was added.The resulting products are denoted as UiO-66-M-x, where x represents the molar ratio of 2-MI to H 2 BDC (0.3, 0.7, and 1.0).Photocatalytic performance tests The photocatalytic performance of the catalysts was investigated by measuring the UV–Vis absorbance of RhB aqueous solution in the degradation process.

2.2   Preparation ofAntidotal Agents UiO-66 was prepared according to the procedure reported  in previous studies [25, 36]. 0.53g of zirconium (IV) chloride   (ZrCl 4 ) was completely dissolved in 30mL of DMF at  room temperature and stirred vigorously until a clear solution was formed. 0.38g of terephthalic acid was added to  the homogenous solution and stirred for 1h. Subsequently,  the homogenous solution was transferred to a 50mL Teﬂonlined autoclave and was placed in a preheated oven to allow  crystal growth at 120°C for 24h. The product obtained was  collected by centrifuge and washed three times with DMF  and three times with chloroform under sonication for 10min  to remove the unreacted reactants. The solid was solvent  exchanged by soaking for 5days in 2 × 15 of chloroform followed by sonication for 10min. Finally the white powder was  dried at 100°C under dynamic vacuum for 24h to remove  the solvents from the pores.  NH 2 -UiO-66 was prepared in  accordance with the same procedure and using 2-aminoterephthalic acid (0.41g) instead of terephthalic acid.2.3   Characterization ofAntidotal Agents Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded  on a 100-FT-IR Spectrometer, Perkin-Elmer. The spectra  were scanned from 500 to 4000cm −1  with a wavenumber  resolution of 4cm −1 . 2.2   Synthesis  ofadsorbents UiO-66 was synthesized using the reported method [25]. Zirconium chloride (2.34g) and 1, 4-benzene dicarboxylic acid  (1.66g) were dissolved in 60mL N, N-dimethylformamide.  The mixture was placed in 100mL Teﬂon lined autoclave and  heated at 120°C for 24h then cooled to room temperature,  ﬁltered, washed with N, N-dimethylformamide, and methanol.  Finally, it was vacuum dried at 150°C for 12h. Tetraethylenepentamine incorporated UiO-66 was prepared by impregnation  method [22]. About, 0.3g of TEPA was dissolved in 10mL  ethanol until a homogeneous solution was obtained then 0.7g  of UiO-66 was added to it. Stirred for 1h at room temperature  then dried at 80°C for overnight. Finally, we got TEPA incorporated UiO-66. It was denoted as 30TEPA/UiO-66.

Deionized water (Grade 1), self-made  in the laboratory.2.2   Catalyst  preparation 2.2.1   Preparation  ofUiO‑66 ZrCl 4  (1.20g, 5mmol) and  H 2 BDC (0.83g, 5mmol) dissolved in a mixed solution of 90mL DMF and 10mL formic  acid, crystallized in a pressure bomb for 40h at 150°C. The  resulting white precipitate was obtained via centrifugation,  washed twice with DMF and then twice with anhydrous  methanol (each time for 3h), After vacuum drying for 12h  at 130°C, the obtained white powder was named UiO-66.

UiO-66 was synthesized according to the previously  reported procedure [19–21]. Accordingly, 1060mg of  ZrCl 4 ,  760mg of TPA, and 60 gr DMF were mixed at room temperature. After complete dissolution of solid materials in the  solvent, the ﬁnal solution was transferred into a Teﬂon-lined  autoclave and was placed in a preheated air oven for 24h at  120 °C. Then, the autoclave was cooled down slowly to room  temperature. Afterward, the ﬁnal suspension was washed  with DMF and subsequently with ethanol. It is well known that amino group always serve as soft donors for actinides and have a better selectivity toward U(VI) over other metal ions. In this work, the UiO-66 and UiO-66-NH 2 were prepared and ﬁrstly explored for U(VI) capture from aqueous solution. The prepared UiO-66 and UiO-66-NH 2 were characterized by XRD, FT-IR, N 2 sorption and TGA. The effectiveness of these two MOFs for U(VI) sorption was assessed. The effect of various parameters such as contact time, pH, ion strength and initial U(VI) concentration on the sorption, as well as the selectivity of the sorbents for U(VI) were investigated in detail. This work promises to develop another simple and effective U(VI) sorbent for environmental remediation and extraction of uranium from seawater.Experiment section Materials ZrCl 4 was purchased from Alfa Aesar. 1, 4-benzene dicarboxylic acid (H 2 BDC) and 2-amine-benzenedicarboxylic acid (NH 2 -H 2 BDC) were purchased from Aladdin Ltd. (Shanghai, China). UO 2 (NO 3 ) 2 6H 2 O was purchased from Merck, Germany. All other chemicals obtained from Beijing Chemical Corp. were of analytical grade or better and used without further puriﬁcation. Milli-Q-water (18.2 MX cm, Millipore Co.) was used in all experiments.Preparation of isor eticular UiO-66 In a typical synthesis [24], terephthalic acid (0.233 mmol) along with ZrCl 4 (0.233 mmol) and DMF (3 mL) were placed in a 15 mL Teﬂon lined autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. After cooling, the microcrystalline precipitate was recovered by centrifugation. Residual DMF and terephthalic acid precursors still attached on UiO-66 were removed by reﬂux in DMF at 160 °C for 24 h, and washed by DMF (3 9 5 mL) and ethanol (3 9 5 mL). The product solid was ﬁnally dried overnight at 80 °C under air atmosphere. UiO-66-NH 2 was synthesized using the same strategy except that H 2 N-H 2 BDC instead of H 2 BDC and additional 100 lL concentrated hydrochloric acid were used.

Experimental Materials andreagents All representative inorganic salts such as  M I NO 3  (M = Li,  Na, K, Rb and Cs),  M II NO 3  (M = Mg, Ca, Sr and Ba),   M III (NO 3 ) 3 ·6H 2 O (Ln = Y, La, Nd, Yb and Fe, Co, Ni),   (NH 4 ) 6 Mo 7 O 24 ·4H 2 O and ZrO(NO 3 ) 2 ·2H 2 O were of  analytical grade. Two liquid reagents, palladium nitrate  solution with 5.0 % (w/w) Pd(II) and ruthenium nitrosyl  nitrate solution with 1.5 % (w/w) Ru(III) were provided  by Shaanxi Kaida Co., Ltd., China and Alfa-Aesar Co.,  Ltd. USA, respectively. Trivalent La(III), Y(III), Nd(III)  and Yb(III) were used to understand the adsorption of all  rare earths REs(III), Am(III), and Cm(III). The  HNO 3 solutions of different contents containing the metals  were temporarily prepared. The contents of the metals  were 0.5 mM. 25,27-bis(iso-propoxyl)-calix[4]arene-26,  28-crown-5 (iPCC5) as shown in Fig.1a with a purity  of greater than 99 % was prepared by a technical route  developed [22]. The metal–organic framework, UiO-66 as  shown in Fig.1b, was one of the Zr-MOFs carrier. It was  synthesized in laboratory scale and characterized using  X-ray powder diﬀraction and others [48]. The preparation  of UiO-66 was described as follows: 15.0g (64.4 mmol)   ZrCl 4 , 10.7g (64.4 mmol) 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid  (BDC) and 440  cm 3  (7.73mol) acetic acid were dissolved  with 500  cm 3  of DMF, and then 75  cm 3    H 2 O was added.  The homogeneous mixture was heated at 393K in oil bath  under stirring for 15min before it was cooled to room temperature. The product was separated by centrifugation at  10,000rpm for 5min and further puriﬁed with ethanol for  three to ﬁve times. The results were consistent with those  of the compositions and structures of UiO-66 previously  reported. All other reagents were of analytical grade and  used without further puriﬁcation.

Sample preparation In this study, UiO-66 and UiO-66-NH 2  were synthetized  via a simple solvothermal method [29]. For the synthesis  of UiO-66-NH 2 , 1.600g  ZrCl 4 , 1.242g BDC-NH 2 , 14mL  HAc and 400mL DMF were mixed and sonicated for 30min  in a conical ﬂask (sealed with tin foil to make ﬁne holes).  Then, the mixture was heated and reacted at 120°C for 24h.  The ﬁnal adsorbent material was collected by centrifugation (8000rpm), washed three times with DMF (once an  hour), and then soaked with methanol for 24h (methanol  was replaced every 8h). The resulting UiO-66-NH 2  samples  were obtained after drying at 75°C for 24h in an oven. UiO66 was prepared by the same method with equimolar BDC  instead of BDC-NH 2 .

Crystallization was carried out under static condition.After cooling down to room temperature, a white precipitate was filtered off and harvested by centrifugation, then washed with DMF to remove the excessive unreacted organic linker twice. Finally, the product was soaked in acetone for 6 h at 60 °C and then centrifuged the suspension. The procedure was repeated for three times to exchange the trapped DMF. The mixture was finally centrifuged and the acetone was removed by decanting. The obtained UiO-66 nanoparticles were dried at 80 °C in vacuum oven overnight.

Materials andmethods Materials The chemicals for preparing UiO-66 nanoparticles are zirconium chloride  (ZrCl 4 ; > 99.5%, Merck Co.), terephthalic  acid   (C 6 H 4 (CO 2 H) 2 ; > 98%, Sigma-Aldrich Co.), N,Ndimethylformamide (DMF)  (C 3 H 7 NO; > 99.8%, Merck Co.),  and hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37%; Merck Co.). Equimolar quantities (5mmol) of   ZrCl 4  and terephthalic acid were solved in 50mL of DMF.  One milliliter of HCl solution was added as the modulator. The crystal formation period was determined as 16h in previous works (Katz  etal. 2013; Qiu etal. 2017). The precipitate was removed  from the reaction mixture by ﬁltration. The obtained crystals were washed with ethanol and water several times. Synthesis ofadsorbent (UiO‑66 andUiO‑66/MWCNT  composite) The synthesis of UiO-66 was carried by hydrothermal  method according to the procedure mentioned by Cavka  etal. (2008) with a small modiﬁcation. DMF and HCl were  taken in a 5:1 ratio v/v, and in this, 0.54 mmol of zirconium tetrachloride was dissolved. Another beaker was taken  that contained 2.32 g  H 2 BDC predissolved in 10 mL DMF.  The two beakers that contained the solutions of  ZrCl 4  and   H 2 BDC were then mixed with each other. In the resulting  mixture, the molar ratio of  ZrCl 4  and  H 2 BDC was maintained as 1:1.4. In this solution, HCl was used as modulating  agent which assists in enhancing the solubility of  ZrCl 4  in  DMF (Katz etal. 2013). The subsequent mixture was taken  in an autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. After that,  crystallisation was done out under static conditions. A ﬁne  white powder settles after few hours when the crystallisation process was completed. After centrifugation, and several times washing with DMF, the resulting solid (powder)  was then dried in a hot air oven at 110 °C.

Materials andmethods Synthesis ofUiO‑66 andUiO‑66  NH 2 Zircomium tetrachloride  (ZrCl 4 , 99.0%) and benzoic acid  (ACS grade, 99.9%) were purchased from Hi-Media®,  benzene-dicarboxylic acid  (H 2 BDC, 98.0%) or terephthalic  acid was purchased from SRL Chemicals, and 2-aminoterephthalic acid  (NH 2 -BDC, 99.0%) was purchased from Alfa  Aesar. The solvents used for the puriﬁcation of MOF were  purchased from SRL Chemicals. The direct blue-6 (DB-6)  was purchased from Hi-Media®. For the synthesis of UiO66,   ZrCl 4  and  H 2 -BDC (benzene-1, 4, dicarboxylic acid)  were taken in equimolar quantities (0.86mM) and dissolved  in 100mL of N, N′-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.0%) with  benzoic acid as modulator. The components were added in a  250-mL screw cap bottle and dissolved by ultrasonication for  0.17h. The bottle was then kept in hot air oven maintained  at 120°C for a period of 24h. The resulting white precipitate was then recovered by ﬁltration and washed thrice with  DMF and methanol (analytical grade, 99.8%) to remove the  unreacted organic linker, modulator, and zirconium. Then  the material was kept in acetone (molecular biology grade,  99.5%) overnight to exchange the DMF and was heated at  80°C overnight to remove the traces of DMF and acetone.  Similar protocol was followed for the synthesis of UiO-66   NH 2 , with a modiﬁcation that amino benzene-dicarboxylic  acid was used instead of benzene-dicarboxylic acid. 2.2 Preparation of UiO-66 UiO-66 was prepared based on the method described by Peterson et al. In a proper beaker, 19.07 mmol of ZrCl 4 and terephthalic acid were mixed in 742 mL of DMF and stirred until completely dissolved. The obtained solution was divided into three identical portions and move d to the same jars and placed in an oven to heat for 24 h at 120 °C. The mixture was cooled to room temperature and frequently washed with DMF.

After that, the mixture was transferred to a Teﬂonlined stainless-steel autoclave and moved to an oven to heat 110 °C for 20 h. Finally, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature; then, the mixture was centrifuged, and the residual precipitates were washed three times with ethanol and ﬁnally dried. In this work, UiO-66, UiO-66-NH 2  and pip-UiO-66-NH 2 were synthesized successfully and  CO 2  and  CH 4  adsorption  and desorption were carried out and compared on these  materials. Then, ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) was  applied to calculate and evaluate the selectivity of  CO 2  over   CH 4  on these MOFs.Experimental procedure Materials All the materials were reagent grade and used without  further puriﬁcation. The speciﬁcations and sources of the  chemicals used in this work are summarized in Table 1.  Materials were balanced using analytical balance with  accuracy of 0.1 mg (Mettler, model AE 200).Synthesis of UiO‑66 and UiO‑66‑NH 2 UiO-66 and UiO-66-NH 2  were prepared following the procedure described by Katz et al. [24] and our previous work  [25] with solvothermal method. A 500-cm 3  stainless steel  autoclave was loaded with 50 ml DMF and 1.25 g  ZrCl 4 (5.4 mmol) and 10 ml concentrated HCl and was mixed  for 20 min. 7.5 mmol of ligand (1.23 g terephthalic acid  for UiO-66 and 1.34 g 2-aminoterephthalic acid for UiO66-NH 2 ) and 100 ml of the DMF were then added, and the  mixture was put in an ultrasonic bath for 20 min. Then,  autoclave was sealed and heated to 120 °C and let to crystallize for 24 h. The light yellow precipitate was observed. The  solvent exchange was preformed with DMF (2 × 30 ml) and  then with EtOH (2 × 30 ml). The precipitate was separated  from the supernatant by ﬁltration, and the residual solvent  was removed in vacuum at 120 °C for overnight.

Synthesis ofUiO‑66 The UiO-66 was prepared via modiﬁcation of the previously reported procedure [21]. To a suspension of  ZrCl 4 (0.63g, 2.7mmol) in DMF (25mL) was added concentrated HCl (5mL) and the mixture sonicated with ultrasound  for several minutes until it becomes clear. Terephthalic acid  (0.62g; 3.75mmol) dissolved in DMF (50mL) was then  added into the  ZrCl 4  and the mixture stirred at 80°C for  24h. After cooling to RT, the white solid was separated  and resuspended in DMF. After stirring for 24h in RT, the  precipitate was separated by ﬁltration and washed with DMF  (4 × 10mL). It was then resuspended in MeOH and stirred  for 24h at RT followed by ﬁltration and washing the solid  with MeOH. This procedure was repeated twice in order to  remove all impurities.

The solid sample  was ﬁltered and washed with methanol three times. Finally,  the prepared solid sample was dried under vacuum at 100°C  for 12h.

Synthesis ofUiO‑66 sample ZrOCl 2 .8H 2 O (6.44g) was dissolved in 100mL of N,  N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solvent (solution A) and   H 2 BDC (3.32g) was dissolved in 150mL of DMF solvent  (solution B). Solution A was added slowly to solution B, and  the mixture was sonicated for 30min for homogenization.  A total of 3.2mL of 36% HCl was added to the homogenous mixture and stirred well for 30min. The solution was  transferred to a ﬂask and allowed for reactions at 120°C for  24h. Synthesis of UiO-66. The UiO-66 samples were synthesized using an already reported procedure.32 ZrCl 4 (0.24 g, 1 eqv.) and benzoic acid (1.88 g, 13 eqv.), acetic acid (1.0 mL, 17 eqv.), or formic acid (0.6 mL, 16 eqv.) were mixed in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (40 mL, 500 eqv.) followed by addition of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.17 g, 1 eqv.). The solution was heated for 24 h at 120 °C with magnetic stirring before ﬁnally being ﬁltrated twice with 20 mL of hot DMF and three times with 20 mL of acetone. To remove any residual solvents, the UiO-66 samples were ﬁltrated continuously overnight using a Soxhlet extractor ﬁlled with acetone.

UIO-66. The previously reported synthesis method 16 was implemented as follows: ZrCl 4 (0.636 g, 2.73 mmol) and terephthalic acid (TPA) (0.453 g, 2.73 mmol) were dissolved via stirring in 106 mL of DMF. The solution was divided up equally and placed in ten 20 mL scintillation vials. The vials were placed in a sand bath at 120 °C and reacted for 20 h. The resultant product was rinsed with DMF three times before activation at 200 °C. The amino version of UiO-66 was synthesized following the same procedure, substituting terephthalic acid with amino-terephthalic acid (ATPA).

Synthesis procedures Synthesis of UiO-66 In a typical procedure, 2.70 g of H 2 BDC and 1.90 g of ZrCl 4  were  dissolved in 50ml of DMF solution. Then, 1.43ml of HCl was added  into the above solution. To ensure the complete dissolution of reagents, mild heating and stirring were applied for synthesis process.  Subsequently, the above mixture was placed in a preheated oven at  120°C for 3 days. Last, the powders were collected by centrifugation  and thoroughly washed three times with DMF and ethanol in turn,  followed by drying at 80°C under vacuum for 12hours.

■ EXPERIMENTAL SECTION Synthesis of UiO-66 and UiO-66-NH 2 Precursors. UiO-66 was prepared via a facile hydrothermal method. Brieﬂy, 0.233 g of ZrCl 4 , 0.1662 g of 1,4-H 2 BDC, 0.54 mL of H 2 O, and 3.773 mL of formic acid were dissolved in 20 mL of N,N′-dimethylformamide successively. Then, the mixture was hydrothermally treated at 120 °C for 24 h. The obtained white product was washed several times with DMF and methanol. Subsequently, the solid product was put into excess methanol and stirred overnight. The washed product was collected by centrifugation and dried overnight in an oven set to 80 °C. UiO-66-NH 2 was synthesized according to the same procedure, only replacing H 2 BDC with H 2 BDC-NH 2 .

3.1.1. Synthesis of UiO-66. UiO-66 was synthesized by a reported solvothermal method 43 with slight modiﬁcation. In a typical synthesis, both ZrCl 4 (1.631 g, 7 mmol) and H 2 BDC (1.163 g, 7 mmol) were dissolved separately in 40 mL of a DMF solution and stirred for 30 min, and then the ZrCl 4 −DMF solution was transferred into the H 2 BDC− DMF solution and stirred for 30 min. The so-formed mixed solution is then transferred to a 100 mL Teﬂon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and subjected to hydrothermal treatment in a hotair oven at 120 °C for 24 h. After cooling naturally to room temperature, the sample was isolated by centrifugation, and the residuals DMF and H 2 BDC were removed from the crystalline pores by subsequent rinsing with methanol several times. Then it was allowed to soak in methanol for 3 days and isolated by centrifugation, followed by drying under vacuum (100 °C, 12 h), and the ﬁnal obtained white sample was named UiO-66.

2.2. Synthesis of UiO-66 Crystal in Supercritical CO 2 .
In a typical setup, deionized water (0.4 mL), DMF (0.5 mL), acetic acid (0.5 mL), zirconium metal precursor (0.644 mmol), and a certain amount of terephthalic acid were mixed and put into a reaction kettle after hydrolysis. The reactor was heated to 60 °C and pressurized to 30 MPa and then depressurized after 5 h. The product was washed two times with DMF (10 mL) and absolute ethanol (10 mL), respectively, and dried at 60 °C for 16 h. Finally, a white powder of UiO-66 was obtained.

UiO-66 MOFs were prepared by a procedure with slight modiﬁcations.38 1.087 g of ZrCl 4 and 0.664 g of PTA were dissolved in 100 mL of DMF and 15 mL of acetic acid, respectively. Both solutions mixed together after stirred for 15 min, and then the mixed solution was stirred for 20 min. Finally, the solution was allowed to react in a microwave reactor at 120 °C for 6 h. Then, the product was activated with methanol for 48 h. UiO-66 was soaked in 100 mL of methanol for 24 h. Finally, UiO-66 was vacuum ﬁltered and dried at 85 °C for 10 h.

EXPERIMENTAL DETAILS Synthesis of UiO-66, UiO-66-NH 2 , and UiO-66-TU.UiO-66 and UiO-66-NH 2 particles were synthesized according to the literature with a slight modiﬁcation.36,37 Brieﬂy, ZrCl 4 (233 mg, 1 mmol), PTA (166 mg, 1 mmol), or BDC-NH 2 (181 mg, 1 mmol), acetic acid (1.2 g, 20 mmol), and 0.16 mL HCl (37%, 2 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of DMF, which was subsequently sealed in a Pyrex vial at 120 °C for 24 h. After that, UiO-66 or UiO-66-NH 2 was collected by centrifugation.Subsequently, these solid products were soaked in 20 mL of DMF containing 0.5 mL of HCl at 100 °C for 6 h to clear the free PTA or BDC-NH 2 and the trapped modulator of acetic acid.

Diverse compounds including amino acids, unsaturated fatty acids, bisphenols (BPs), oligosaccharides, peptides, protein, and polyethylene glycol (PEG) with diﬀerent average molecular weights were selected to evaluate the application ranges of the UiO-66-GA substrate. Good salt tolerance and high sensitivity obtained with the UiO-66-GA substrate made it possible for quantit ative analysis of perﬂuorooctanoic sulfonate (PFOS) in human urine and serum samples. In addition, the mechanism of the synergistic eﬀect between UiO66 and GA for enhancement in the LDI process was also discussed.2. EXPERIMENTAL SECTION 2.1. Synthesis of UiO-66. UiO-66 was prepared by a solvothermal method as described elsewhere.40 In brief, the mixture of zirconium chloride (ZrCl 4, 932 mg) and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 72 mL) was sonicated for 15 min until dissolved. 1,4Benzenedicarboxylic acid (660 mg), benzoic acid (BA, 9.66 g), and concentrated hydrochloric acid (HCl, 0.67 mL) were then added to the above solution, and the mixture was further ultrasonically treated for 10 min and then heated at 120 °C for 24 h without stirring. The product was collected by centrifugation, washed with DMF and ethanol several times, and ﬁnally dried overnight at 100 °Cina vacuum oven.

4.2. Synthesis of UiO- 66. UiO-66 was prepared in accordance with the methods described previously.
26 Brieﬂy, in a 3000 mL round-bottom ﬂask, ZrCl 4 (3.72 g, 16 mmol) was dissolved under stirring in a mixture of DMF (1000 mL) and glacial acetic acid (288 g, 274.6 mL, 4.8 mol). In another 2000 mL round-bottom ﬂask, terephthalic acid (2.66 g, 16 mmol) was dissolved completely in DMF (1000 mL). The terephthalic acid solution was slowly added into the ZrCl 4 solution, and the resulting mixture was stirred to a homogeneous solution. The solution was separated into 100 vials. The vials were closed and heated at 120 °C for 24 h, then cooled to room temperature.
The reaction mixture in the vials was gathered, and the white powder UiO-66 product was collected through centrifugation and rinsed with methanol to get a white solid (3.0 g, 70% yield). The UiO-66 product was activated at 150 ° C under high vacuum for 12 h, stored at room temperature.

UiO-66 was synthesized based on the reported method 22 with slight modiﬁcations by the following procedure: 0.50 g of ZrCl 4 , 20 mL of DMF, and 4 mL of concentrated HCl were added in sequence. For complete dissolution, the obtained mixture was sonicated for 20 min. Then, 0.492 g of terephthalic acid and another 20 mL of DMF were added to the mixture. The obtained mixture was sonicated for another 20 min for complete dissolution. The ﬁnal mixture was sealed in a 50 mL Teﬂon-lined autoclave and placed in a preheated oven at 353 K overnight. The microcrystalline powder was then isolated by centrifugation and washed three times with 30 mL of DMF and ethanol. At last, the material was activated at 373 K under vacuum overnight.2.3. Adsorption Measurement System and Procedure. Adsorption measurements were carried out with a gravimetric sorption analyzer (Rubotherm, Germany; since 2016, TA instruments, USA) incorporating a magneticsuspension balance. This type of instrument has been widely used for accurate adsorption measurements at high pressures, 4,23,24 and it is able to measure the adsorption of nonporous materials after improvements in accuracy.

Finally, UiO-66 was activated by removing the solvent under vacuum for 24 h at 100 °C. UiO-66-NH 2 : UiO-66-NH 2 was synthesized by dissolving ZrCl 4 (125 mg, 0.54 mmol) and 2-amino-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (134 mg, 0.75 mmol) in DMF (20 mL) with ultrasonication for 30 min. The resulting solid was ﬁltered, repeatedly washed with CHCl 3, and dried at room temperature.

The white powder was washed with DMF and MeOH and dried in vacuum.Bim-UiO-66 was prepared on the basis of previous reports with minor modiﬁcations.46 ZrCl 4 (0.0235 g, 0.1 mmol), Bim-H 2 BDC (0.0282 mg, 0.1 mmol), DMF (5 mL), and HAc (0.5 mL) were added to a 25 mL Teﬂon vessel of a steel autoclave, and the mixture was heated to 120 °C for 72 h and then cooled slowly to room temperature in 12 h. The light-pink powder was washed with DMF and MeOH and then dried in vacuum.

■ EXPERIMENTAL SECTION Synthesis of PI-COOH. A polycondensation reaction was used to synthesize carboxylated polyimide (PI-COOH).33 The used diamines of 2,3,5,6-tetramethyl-1,4-phenylenediamine (durene diamine) and 3,5-diaminobenzoic acid (DABA) were in the ratio of 3:2. After the reaction, methanol was used to precipitate the PI-COOH from the polymer solution. Subsequently, the precipitated polymer was washed no less than three times using methanol and hexane. The ﬁnal polymer could be obtained after being dried at 120 °C for 24 in a vacuum oven.Synthesis of UiO-66 Nanoparticles. UiO-66 nanoparticles were synthesized from a solution of ZrCl 4 and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid in DMF using a solvothermal method.34 A total of 813.33 mg ZrCl 4 and 574.66 mg 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid were added to 200 mL of DMF. A homogeneous solution was obtained after sonication for 20 min, and then 3 mL acetic acid and 1.61 mL deionized water were added. The solution was kept at 120 °C for 24 h, followed by natural cooling to room temperature. The obtained crystals were centrifuged and washed with DMF no less than three times. At last, the crystals were saved in a DMF solution.
